--- +++ @@ -1,101 +1,98 @@ {{Infobox election | election_name = 1962 United States Senate elections | country = United States | type = legislative | ongoing = no | previous_election = 1960 United States Senate elections | previous_year = 1960 | next_election = 1964 United States Senate elections | next_year = 1964 | seats_for_election = 39 of the 100 seats in the [[United States Senate]] | majority_seats = 51 | election_date = November 6, 1962 | 1blank = Seats up | 2blank = Races won -| image_size = 165x180px +| image_size = 165x136px | party1 = Democratic Party (US) | image1 = Michael Joseph Mansfield.jpg | leader1 = [[Mike Mansfield]] | leader_since1 = January 3, 1961 | leaders_seat1 = [[List of United States Senators from Montana|Montana]] | seats_before1 = '''64''' | seats_after1 = '''68''' -| seat_change1 = {{increase}} 4 +| seat_change1 = {{Increase}} 4 | popular_vote1 = '''20,832,503''' | percentage1 = '''50.4%''' -| swing1 = {{decrease}} 4.7% +| swing1 = {{Decrease}} 4.7% | 1data1 = '''19''' | 2data1 = '''23''' | party2 = Republican Party (US) | image2 = EverettDirksen.jpg | leader2 = [[Everett Dirksen]] | leader_since2 = January 3, 1959 | leaders_seat2 = [[List of United States Senators from Illinois|Illinois]] | seats_before2 = 36 | seats_after2 = 32 -| seat_change2 = {{decrease}} 4 +| seat_change2 = {{Decrease}} 4 | popular_vote2 = 20,245,509 | percentage2 = 49.0% -| swing2 = {{increase}} 4.8% +| swing2 = {{Increase}} 4.8% | 1data2 = 15 | 2data2 = 11 | map_image = Us 1962 senate election map.svg | map_size = 320px | map_caption = '''Results of the elections:'''
{{Legend0|#0000FF|Democratic gain}} {{Legend0|#00007F|Democratic hold}}
{{Legend0|#FF0000|Republican gain}} {{Legend0|#800000|Republican hold}}
{{Legend0|#D3D3D3|No election}} | title = [[Majority Leader of the United States Senate|Majority Leader]] | before_election = [[Mike Mansfield]] | before_party = Democratic Party (US) | after_election = [[Mike Mansfield]] | after_party = Democratic Party (US) }} {{For|related races|1962 United States elections}} The '''1962 United States Senate elections''' was an election for the [[United States Senate]] which was held in the middle of President [[John F. Kennedy]]'s term. His [[United States Democratic Party|Democratic Party]] made a net gain of four seats from the [[United States Republican Party|Republicans]], increasing their control of the Senate. Both Republican-held senate seats in New Hampshire were up on election day due to a special election. The appointee lost election to a full term to the Democratic challenger while the incumbent Republican was reelected. As such, this is the last time that one of a state's two senate seats, both up on election day, that were held by the same party changed parties. == Retirements == Through open seats due to retirements, Democrats gained two seats. === Democratic seats held by Democrats === -# Hawaii: [[Oren E. Long]] (D) was replaced by [[Daniel Inouye]] (D). -# Massachusetts (Class 1): Appointee [[Benjamin A. Smith II]] (D) was replaced by [[Ted Kennedy]] (D) for the last two years of the term President Kennedy was elected to in 1960 +# [[#Hawaii|Hawaii]]: [[Oren E. Long]] (D) was replaced by [[Daniel Inouye]] (D). +# [[#Massachusetts (Special)|Massachusetts (Special)]]: Appointee [[Benjamin A. Smith II]] (D) was replaced by [[Ted Kennedy]] (D) for the last two years of the term President Kennedy was elected to in 1960 === Republicans replaced by Democrats === -# Connecticut: [[Prescott Bush]] (R) was replaced by [[Abraham Ribicoff]] (D) -# Maryland: [[John Marshall Butler]] (R) was replaced by [[Daniel Brewster]] (D) +# [[#Connecticut|Connecticut]]: [[Prescott Bush]] (R) was replaced by [[Abraham Ribicoff]] (D) +# [[#Maryland|Maryland]]: [[John Marshall Butler]] (R) was replaced by [[Daniel Brewster]] (D) == Losing incumbents == Democrats had a net gain of two seats in election upsets. === Democrats lost to Republicans === -# Colorado : [[John A. Carroll]] (D) lost to [[Peter H. Dominick]] (R) -# Wyoming (Class 2): Appointee [[John J. Hickey]] (D) lost to [[Milward Simpson]] (R) +# [[#Colorado|Colorado ]]: [[John A. Carroll]] (D) lost to [[Peter H. Dominick]] (R) +# [[#Wyoming|Wyoming ]](Class 2): Appointee [[John J. Hickey]] (D) lost to [[Milward Simpson]] (R) === Republicans lost to Democrats === -# Indiana: [[Homer E. Capehart]] (R) lost to [[Birch Bayh]] (D) -# New Hampshire (Class 2): Appointee [[Maurice J. Murphy Jr.]] (R) lost renomination to [[Perkins Bass]] (R). Bass lost the general election to [[Thomas J. McIntyre]] (D). -# South Dakota: Appointee [[Joseph H. Bottum]] (R) lost to [[George McGovern]] (D) -# Wisconsin: [[Alexander Wiley]] (R) lost to [[Gaylord Nelson]] (D) +# [[#Indiana|Indiana]]: [[Homer E. Capehart]] (R) lost to [[Birch Bayh]] (D) +# [[#New Hampshire (Special)|New Hampshire (Special)]]: Appointee [[Maurice J. Murphy Jr.]] (R) lost renomination to [[Perkins Bass]] (R). Bass lost the general election to [[Thomas J. McIntyre]] (D). +# [[#South Dakota|South Dakota]]: Appointee [[Joseph H. Bottum]] (R) lost to [[George McGovern]] (D) +# [[#Wisconsin|Wisconsin]]: [[Alexander Wiley]] (R) lost to [[Gaylord Nelson]] (D) == Other changes == The Democrats' four-seat net gain was reduced by one seat between the election and the next Congress. # New Mexico: On November 18, 1962, Democrat [[Dennis Chávez]], who was not up for election that year, died. He was replaced on November 30, 1962 by Republican appointee [[Edwin L. Mechem]]. - -== Subsequent changes == -* September 16, 1964: South Carolina — [[Strom Thurmond]] switched parties from Democratic to Republican. == Change in composition == === Before the elections === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" width=100% |- | {{Party shading/Democratic}} | D{{Sub|1}} | {{Party shading/Democratic}} | D{{Sub|2}} | {{Party shading/Democratic}} | D{{Sub|3}} | {{Party shading/Democratic}} | D{{Sub|4}} | {{Party shading/Democratic}} | D{{Sub|5}} | {{Party shading/Democratic}} | D{{Sub|6}} | {{Party shading/Democratic}} | D{{Sub|7}} | {{Party shading/Democratic}} | D{{Sub|8}} @@ -478,1927 +475,1928 @@ | {| class=wikitable |- | align=center {{Party shading/Democratic}} | D{{Sub|#}} | [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |- | align=center {{Party shading/Republican}} | R{{Sub|#}} | [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |- | align=center {{Party shading/Vacant}} | V{{Sub|#}} | Vacant |} |} == Race summaries == - === Special elections during the 87th Congress === In these special elections, the winner was seated during 1962 or before January 3, 1963; ordered by election date, then state. {| class=wikitable |- valign=bottom ! rowspan=2 | State ! colspan=3 | Incumbent ! rowspan=2 | Results ! rowspan=2 | Candidates |- ! Only Young filed as a Republican, and the endorsed Democratic candidate was Lanier, who had previously faced Young in a special election held in [[1946 United States Senate election in North Dakota|1946]] to fill the seat which was vacated by the late [[John Moses (American politician)|John Moses]]. Young and Lanier won the primary elections for their respective parties. Johnston]] + | after_party = Democratic Party (US) +}} {{Main|1962 United States Senate election in South Carolina}} {{See also|List of United States senators from South Carolina|1962 United States House of Representatives elections in South Carolina}} Incumbent Democratic Senator [[Olin D. Johnston]] defeated [[Governor of South Carolina|Governor]] [[Ernest Hollings|Fritz Hollings]] in the Democratic primary and [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[W. D. Workman Jr.]] in the general election. The [[South Carolina Democratic Party]] held their [[Primary election|primary]] on June 12, 1962. [[Olin D. Johnston]], the incumbent [[United States Senate|Senator]], faced stiff competition from [[Governor of South Carolina|Governor]] [[Ernest Hollings|Fritz Hollings]] who argued that Johnston was too liberal and not representative of South Carolina interests. Johnston merely told the voters that he was doing what he thought was best for the agriculture and textile workers of the state. Hollings was decisively defeated by Johnston because Johnston used his position as [[United States Senate Committee on Post Office and Civil Service|Post Office and Civil Service Committee]] to build 40 new post offices in the state and thus demonstrate the pull he had in [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] to bring home the bacon. {{Election box begin no change - | title= Democratic primary}} -{{Election box winning candidate with party link no change - |party = Democratic Party (US) - |candidate = [[Olin D. Johnston]] - |votes = 216,918 - |percentage = 66.3 -}} -{{Election box candidate with party link no change - |party = Democratic Party (US) - |candidate = [[Ernest Hollings|Fritz Hollings]] - |votes = 110,023 - |percentage = 33.7 -}} -{{Election box end}} + | title = Democratic primary +}} +{{Election box winning candidate with party link no change + | party = Democratic Party (US) + | candidate = [[Olin D. Johnston]] + | votes = 216,918 + | percentage = 66.3 +}} +{{Election box candidate with party link no change + | party = Democratic Party (US) + | candidate = [[Ernest Hollings|Fritz Hollings]] + | votes = 110,023 + | percentage = 33.7 +}} +{{End}} [[W. D. Workman Jr.]], a correspondent for the ''[[The Post and Courier|News and Courier]]'', faced no opposition from [[South Carolina Republican Party|South Carolina Republicans]] and avoided a [[primary election]]. Both Johnston and Workman supported [[Racial segregation|segregation]], so the campaign centered on the economic issues of the state. Workman tried to persuade the voters that Johnston's policies were socialist and that he was too closely aligned with the [[John F. Kennedy|Kennedy]] administration. Johnston was a consistent supporter of socialized health care proposals and Workman was able to win considerable support from the medical establishment. However, the state's citizens were much poorer than that of the rest of the nation and Johnston's class based appeals made him a very popular figure for the downtrodden of both the white and black races. The competitive nature of this race foresaw the eventual rise of the Republican Party and that South Carolinians were growing increasingly suspicious of policies generated at the federal level. {{Election box begin | title =South Carolina U.S. Senate Election, 1962 }} {{Election box winning candidate with party link | party = Democratic Party (US) | candidate = [[Olin D. edits.entity: Jill Karofsky
edits.diff:
--- +++ @@ -1,17 +1,17 @@ {{Short description|American judge, justice of the Wisconsin Supreme Court}} -{{Infobox judge +{{Infobox officeholder | honorific-prefix = The Honorable | name = Jill J. Karofsky | image = | alt = | caption = | office = [[List of justices of the Wisconsin Supreme Court|Justice]] of the [[Wisconsin Supreme Court]] | term_start = August 1, 2020 | term_end = | predecessor = [[Daniel Kelly (Wisconsin judge)|Daniel Kelly]] | successor = | office1 = [[Wisconsin circuit courts|Wisconsin Circuit Court]] Judge for the {{nobreak|[[Dane County, Wisconsin|Dane]] Circuit}}, {{nobreak|Branch 12}} | term_start1 = August 1, 2017 | term_end1 = July 31, 2020 | predecessor1 = Clayton Kawski | successor1 = [[Chris Taylor (politician)|Chris Taylor]] @@ -21,39 +21,39 @@ | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | spouse = {{marriage|Jason Knutson|1998|2017|end=divorce}} | children = 2 | education = [[Duke University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] ([[Master of Arts|MA]], [[Juris Doctor|JD]]) | website = {{url|jillforjustice.com|Campaign website}} }} '''Jill Judith Karofsky''' (born July 15, 1966) is an American attorney, judge, and justice of the [[Wisconsin Supreme Court]]. Karofsky served as a [[Wisconsin circuit courts|Wisconsin Circuit Court]] Judge in [[Dane County, Wisconsin|Dane County]] from 2017 until her election to the Wisconsin Supreme Court. == Early life and education == Jill Karofsky was born on July 15, 1966, in south-central Wisconsin to Judy Karofsky, a former [[Middleton, Wisconsin]] city council member and the city's mayor from 1975 to 1977, and her then-husband Peter Karofsky, a pediatrician. Karofsky was a state tennis champion while at [[Middleton High School (Middleton, Wisconsin)|Middleton High School]], where she graduated in 1984. She later played [[NCAA Division I|Division I]] sports for [[Duke University]], where she received her [[Bachelor of Arts]] in 1988. Karofsky received her [[Juris Doctor]] from the [[University of Wisconsin Law School]] in 1992.{{Cite web |title=Hon. Jill J. Karofsky Lawyer Profile on Martindale.com |url=https://www.martindale.com/attorney/hon-jill-j-karofsky-1793206/ |access-date=July 5, 2020 |website=www.martindale.com}} She married attorney Jason Knutson in July 1998, though they later divorced. == Career == -Karofsky entered civil service as a deputy [[district attorney]] for [[Dane County, Wisconsin|Dane County]]. She has also served in the [[Wisconsin Department of Justice]] as Assistant Attorney General working as Wisconsin's [[Violence against women|Violence Against Women]] resource prosecutor, and later leading the Office of Crime Victim Services.{{Cite web|last=Milwaukee|first=Urban|title=AG Schimel Appoints Experienced, Award-Winning Prosecutor to Lead Office of Crime Victim Services|url=https://urbanmilwaukee.com/pressrelease/ag-schimel-appoints-experienced-award-winning-prosecutor-to-lead-office-of-crime-victim-services/|access-date=2020-06-14|website=Urban Milwaukee|language=en}} +Karofsky entered civil service as a deputy [[district attorney]] for [[Dane County, Wisconsin|Dane County]]. She has also served in the [[Wisconsin Department of Justice]] as Assistant Attorney General working as Wisconsin's [[Violence against women|Violence Against Women]] resource prosecutor, and later leading the Office of Crime Victim Services.{{Cite web|last=Milwaukee|first=Urban|title=AG Schimel Appoints Experienced, Award-Winning Prosecutor to Lead Office of Crime Victim Services|url=https://urbanmilwaukee.com/pressrelease/ag-schimel-appoints-experienced-award-winning-prosecutor-to-lead-office-of-crime-victim-services/|access-date=2020-06-14|website=Urban Milwaukee|language=en}} In 2017, Karofsky was elected as a judge on the Dane County Circuit Court, beating municipal judge Marilyn Townsend by 15 points.{{Cite web|last=Journal|first=Ed Treleven {{!}} Wisconsin State|title=Jill Karofsky bests Marilyn Townsend for Dane County judge|url=https://madison.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/elections/jill-karofsky-bests-marilyn-townsend-for-dane-county-judge/article_fdab1e49-f532-55c5-9c7a-ad7d0831283b.html|access-date=2020-06-14|website=madison.com|language=en}} === Wisconsin Supreme Court === ==== 2020 Election ==== Judge Karofsky challenged incumbent [[Wisconsin Supreme Court]] Justice [[Daniel Kelly (Wisconsin judge)|Daniel Kelly]] in Wisconsin's 2020 election.{{Cite web|url=https://ballotpedia.org/Wisconsin_Supreme_Court_elections,_2020|title=Wisconsin Supreme Court elections, 2020|website=Ballotpedia|language=en|access-date=2020-04-15}} Kelly had been appointed to the Supreme Court by Republican then-Governor [[Scott Walker (politician)|Scott Walker]] in 2016 and was endorsed by [[Donald Trump|President Donald Trump]].{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1247546362473975809|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200407152822/https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1247546362473975809|url-status=dead|archive-date=2020-04-07|title=Donald J. Trump on Twitter: "Wisconsin, get out and vote NOW for Justice Daniel Kelly. Protect your 2nd Amendment!"|date=2020-04-07|access-date=2020-04-15}} Judge Karofsky was endorsed by over 100 current and former Wisconsin judges, including incumbent Wisconsin Supreme Court Justice [[Rebecca Dallet]]. She also received endorsements from U.S. Senator [[Tammy Baldwin]], former governor [[Jim Doyle]], and former U.S. senators [[Russ Feingold]] and [[Herb Kohl]].{{cite web|url= https://www.jillforjustice.com/endorsements |title= Endorsements |website= Jill for Justice |accessdate= April 15, 2020 }} In the final days before the election, Judge Karofsky was endorsed by both the remaining [[2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries|2020 Democratic Party presidential primary]] candidates—former Vice President [[Joe Biden]] and U.S. Senator [[Bernie Sanders]].{{cite news|url= https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/04/03/joe-biden-endorses-jill-karofsky-wisconsin-supreme-court-race/2945893001/ |title= Joe Biden endorses Jill Karofsky for state Supreme Court while Donald Trump reaffirms backing of Daniel Kelly |date= April 3, 2020 |last= Glauber|first= Bill |newspaper= [[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]] |accessdate= April 15, 2020 }}{{cite news|url= https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/2020/04/02/bernie-sanders-endorses-jill-karofsky-wisconsin-supreme-court/5110621002/ |title= Karofsky gets Sanders' endorsement in Supreme Court race after criticizing Kelly for getting Trump's backing |date= April 2, 2020 |last= Marley |first= Patrick |newspaper= [[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]] |accessdate= April 15, 2020 }} -The election set amount|url=https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/2020/07/16/wisconsin-supreme-court-race-brought-record-spending-10-million/5453157002/|access-date=2020-07-21|website=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|language=en-US}} On April 13, 2020, Judge Karofsky was declared the winner of the election, taking roughly 55% of the vote. She took office on August 1, 2020, and became the ninth woman in Wisconsin history to serve on the state's high court. Karofsky's upset election has been cited by [[Tom Perez]], the [[Democratic National Committee]] Chair, as being indicative of the results of the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 presidential election]]. ===== Attack ad controversy ===== During her campaign for Wisconsin Supreme Court, Karofsky was the target of television [[attack ad]]s funded by supporters of her opponent [[Daniel Kelly (Wisconsin judge)|Daniel Kelly]]. The ads falsely claimed Karofsky, as deputy district attorney, struck a [[Plea bargain|plea deal]] with a man charged with [[sexual assault]] of a minor resulting in no jail time. On March 27, 2020, Karofsky's campaign announced intent to file a [[cease and desist]] order against the ads. On April 6, 2020, [[Milwaukee County, Wisconsin|Milwaukee County]] Circuit Judge Timothy Witkowiak blocked Karofsky's [[injunction]] against the ads on the grounds of unlawful [[prior restraint]]. ==== Swearing in ceremony ==== In keeping with her marathon hobby, on August 1, 2020, Judge Karofsky was sworn into office following the thirty-fifth mile of an "ultramarathon," by Wisconsin Supreme Court Justice [[Rebecca Dallet]] in a ceremony also attended by former governor Jim Doyle. She then ran another sixty-five miles.{{Cite news |url= https://wisconsinexaminer.com/brief/karofsky-to-be-sworn-in-during-100-mile-run/ |title= Karofsky to be sworn in during 100-mile run |work= Wisconsin Examiner |date= July 27, 2020 |last= Redman |first= Henry |accessdate= 2020-07-28 |language= en-US}}{{cite news|url= https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/2020/08/01/wisconsin-supreme-court-justice-sworn-middle-100-mile-run/5563957002/ |title= A Wisconsin Supreme Court justice was sworn in after she ran 35 miles. Then she started running another 65 |newspaper= [[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]] |date= August 1, 2020 |last= Marley |first= Patrick |accessdate= August 1, 2020 }} == Personal life == A single mother of two children (a son and a daughter), Karofsky lives in [[Middleton, Wisconsin]].  [[File:Liz Cheney 15800286.jpg|upright|thumb|Cheney in 2016]]
 After incumbent [[Cynthia Lummis]] announced her retirement in the Fall of 2015, Cheney announced she was considering running for her seat in 2016. It is the same seat her father occupied for ten years. On February 1, 2016, Cheney announced her candidacy for Wyoming's lone seat in the U.S. House of Representatives and was widely considered the frontrunner for the seat.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hancock|first1=Laura|title=Liz Cheney leading in GOP primary for U.S. House, over 50 percent undecided|url=http://trib.com/news/state-and-regional/govt-and-politics/liz-cheney-leading-in-gop-primary-for-u-s-house/article_893cc8bd-364b-508b-8852-956c06f43425.html|work=Casper Star-Tribune|date=July 27, 2016|location=[[Casper, Wyoming]]}}</ref>
 Oil tycoon [[Simon Kukes]] contributed to her campaign.<ref name="os">{{cite web |url=http://www.opensecrets.org/news/2016/09/russian-born-oil-magnate-gives-big-to-trump-victory/ |title=Russian-born oil magnate gives big to Trump Victory |publisher=The Center for Responsive Politics |work=Open Secrets |date=September 26, 2016 |accessdate=October 1, 2016 |author=Ashley Balcerzak}}</ref>
 She was elected with over 60% of the vote in the general election.
 
 ====2018====
 {{main|2018 United States House of Representatives election in Wyoming}}
 In the November 6 general election, Cheney was re-elected as Wyoming's sole member of the House of Representatives. She won 127,951 votes, defeating Democrat Greg Hunter (59,898 votes), Libertarian Richard Brubaker (6,918) and Constitution Party candidate Daniel Clyde Cummings (6,069). Cheney won 21 of 23 counties, losing Albany and Teton Counties to Greg Hunter. On November 14, Cheney was elected by the Republican membership as the Chair of the House Republican Conference for the 116th Congress. In this post, she is the third-ranking Republican in the chamber, behind Minority Leader [[Kevin McCarthy (California politician)|Kevin McCarthy]] and Minority Whip [[Steve Scalise]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://apnews.com/ca74a2e03537423584447fe1e6b4fbf6|title=Liz Cheney poised for ascent into Republican leadership|accessdate=November 14, 2018|agency=AP}}</ref> She is also the highest-ranking Republican woman in Congress.
 
 ===Tenure===
 Cheney was sworn into office on January 3, 2017.
 She co-sponsored legislation that would end protection for grey wolves in the [[Endangered Species Act of 1973|Endangered Species Act]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2017/01/republican-controlled-government-sees-chance-to-weaken-endangered-species-act/|title=Republican-controlled government sees chance to weaken Endangered Species Act|work=Ars Technica|accessdate=March 11, 2017}}</ref>
 
 In May 2019, Cheney said that [[Peter Strzok]] and another FBI agent who sent personal text messages where they disparaged various politicians (including President Donald Trump) sounded as if they were planning a "coup" and may be guilty of "treason".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/445588-liz-cheney-statements-by-agents-investigating-trump-could-well-be|title=Liz Cheney: Statements by agents investigating Trump 'could well be treason'|last=Zilbermints|first=Regina|date=May 26, 2019|website=TheHill|language=en|access-date=May 26, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/cheney-refuses-respond-trump-tweet-praising-kim-jong/story?id=63277503|title=Cheney doesn't comment on tweet about N. Korea, Biden, says she supports Trump policy|website=ABC News|language=en|access-date=May 26, 2019}}</ref>
 
-On March 7, 2019, Cheney joined 22 Republican representatives in opposing HR183 which condemned "anti-Semitism as hateful expressions of intolerance" and "anti-Muslim discrimination and bigotry." Critics of the bill cites their concern with it being too broad, as it was initially meant to chastise comments made by [[Ilhan Omar]], and her name and comments were removed from the bill.{{cn|date=March 2020}} 
+On March 7, 2019, Cheney joined 22 Republican representatives in opposing HR183 which condemned "anti-Semitism as hateful expressions of intolerance" and "anti-Muslim discrimination and bigotry." Critics of the bill cites their concern with it being too broad, as it was initially meant to chastise comments made by [[Ilhan Omar]], and her name and comments were removed from the bill.{{citation needed|date=March 2020}}
 
 In June 2019, [[Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez]] compared the holding centers for illegal immigrants at the [[Mexico–United States border]] to "concentration camps". Cheney strongly criticized her words, saying they showed "disrespect" for [[Holocaust]] victims.<ref>{{cite news |title=Yad Vashem to Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez: Learn about concentration camps |url=https://www.jpost.com/American-Politics/Yad-Vashem-to-AOC-Learn-about-concentration-camps-593059 |work=The Jerusalem Post |date=June 20, 2019}}</ref>
 
 Speaking as Chairwoman at a House Republican Conference in August 2019,  Cheney stated that the successful litigation (''[[Crow Tribe]] et al v. [[Ryan Zinke|Zinke]]'') by Native tribes and environmentalists to return the grizzly bear in [[Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem|Greater Yellowstone]] to the [[Endangered Species Act]] "was not based on science or facts” but motivated by plaintiffs “intent on destroying our Western way of life."  Her statements drew comments from indigenous tribal nations and environmentalists.  Tribal nations hold the grizzly to be sacred and they and environmentalists have voiced concerns about trophy hunts, livestock and logging interests, and the gas, coal, and oil extraction industries.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Brulliard |first1=Karin |title=Court restores federal protections for Yellowstone-area grizzly bears |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/science/2018/09/25/court-restores-federal-protections-yellowstone-area-grizzly-bears/ |website=The Washington Post |accessdate=August 2, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Online staff |title=REP. CHENEY ACCUSES TRIBES OF "DESTROYING OUR WESTERN WAY OF LIFE" OVER SACRED GRIZZLY PROTECTIONS |url=https://nativenewsonline.net/currents/rep-cheney-accuses-tribes-of-destroying-our-western-way-of-life-over-sacred-grizzly-protections/ |website=Native News Online |accessdate=August 2, 2019}}</ref>
 
 Cheney condemned the [[2019 Rojava offensive|Turkish invasion]] of the [[Rojava|Kurdish areas in Syria]], which was made possible by President Trump's decision to withdraw US military forces that served as a buffer between Turkey and the Kurdish areas in Syria, stating that "The U.S. is abandoning our ally the Kurds, who fought ISIS (Islamic State) on the ground and helped protect the U.S. homeland. This decision aids America’s adversaries, Russia, Iran, and Turkey, and paves the way for a resurgence of ISIS."<ref>{{cite news |title=Turkey opens ground assault on Syria's Kurds; U.S. Republicans turn on Trump |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-syria-security-turkey-usa/turkey-opens-ground-assault-on-syrias-kurds-u-s-republicans-turn-on-trump-idUSKBN1WO05Z |agency=Reuters |date=October 9, 2019}}</ref> Cheney partly blamed the Democratic Party and the impeachment inquiry into Trump for Turkey's actions, saying “It was not an accident that the Turks chose this moment to roll across the border."<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/liz-cheney-syria-trump-democrats_n_5da48f5ce4b087efdbb267da|title=Liz Cheney: Impeachment Inquiry Partly To Blame For Turkey's Invasion Of Syria|last=Miller|first=Hayley|date=October 14, 2019|website=HuffPost|language=en|access-date=October 15, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newsweek.com/gop-liz-cheney-fox-news-turkey-invaded-syria-because-democrats-impeachment-inquiry-trump-1465003|title=Liz Cheney tells Fox News Turkey invaded Syria because Democrats launched impeachment inquiry against Trump|last=EDT|first=Jason Lemon On 10/14/19 at 9:04 AM|date=October 14, 2019|website=Newsweek|language=en|access-date=October 15, 2019}}</ref> A spokesperson for House Speaker [[Nancy Pelosi]] described Cheney's claim about the impact of U.S. presidential impeachment proceedings on the invasion as "delusional".<ref name=":0" />
 
 At a House Republican Conference in July 2020, Cheney was criticized by some fellow Republicans, including [[Jim Jordan (American politician)|Jim Jordan]] of [[Ohio]] and [[Andy Biggs]] of [[Arizona]], for defending [[Dr. Fauci]], amidst the [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|COVID pandemic]], and for previously endorsing [[Kentucky]] Congressman [[Thomas Massie]]'s primary opponent. Calls for Cheney to step down as chair of the House Republican Conference soon came from [[Florida]] Congressman [[Matt Gaetz]] and [[Donald Trump Jr.]]<ref>https://www.politico.com/news/2020/07/21/house-cheney-gop-conference-375812</ref>
 
-Cheney voiced support for [[Israel]]i plan to [[proposed Israeli annexation of the West Bank|annex]] parts of [[Palestinian territories|Palestinian territory]] in the occupied [[West Bank]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Republicans sign letter backing Israel’s right to set its own borders |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/republicans-sign-letter-backing-israels-right-to-set-its-own-borders/ |work=The Times of Jerusalem |date=23 June 2020}}</ref> She signed a letter addressed to Israeli Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] that reaffirms "the unshakeable alliance between the United States and Israel".<ref>{{cite news |title=Democrats Can’t Allow Israel to Pursue Annexation Without Consequences |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/07/20/democrats-israel-west-bank-palestine-annexation-without-consequences/ |work=Foreign Policy |date=July 20, 2020}}</ref> 
+Cheney voiced support for [[Israel]]i plan to [[proposed Israeli annexation of the West Bank|annex]] parts of [[Palestinian territories|Palestinian territory]] in the occupied [[West Bank]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Republicans sign letter backing Israel’s right to set its own borders |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/republicans-sign-letter-backing-israels-right-to-set-its-own-borders/ |work=The Times of Jerusalem |date=23 June 2020}}</ref> She signed a letter addressed to Israeli Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] that reaffirms "the unshakeable alliance between the United States and Israel".<ref>{{cite news |title=Democrats Can’t Allow Israel to Pursue Annexation Without Consequences |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/07/20/democrats-israel-west-bank-palestine-annexation-without-consequences/ |work=Foreign Policy |date=July 20, 2020}}</ref>

[[University of Washington]] ([[Juris Doctor|JD]]) }} '''Jenny Anne Durkan''' (born May 19, 1958) is an American attorney and [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] politician serving as [[mayor of Seattle]]. She is the daughter of [[Martin Durkan]], who was once considered one of the most powerful politicians in the state. After earning her J.D. degree from [[University of Washington School of Law]] in 1985, Durkan began practicing law as a prosecutor; she had many prominent cases both on behalf of the government and for private parties. During this time she also worked for many nonprofits and advocacy groups, and was briefly Governor [[Mike Lowry]]'s chief lawyer. In October 2009, President [[Barack Obama]] appointed her [[United States Attorney]] for the [[United States District Court for the Western District of Washington|Western District of Washington]]. She held that position until September 2014.Jerry Markon and Juliet Eilperin (September 25, 2014). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/attorney-general-eric-holder-to-step-down/2014/09/25/9b1dbb7a-44c3-11e4-b47c-f5889e061e5f_story.html "Attorney General Eric Holder to Step Down," Washington Post] Durkan was elected the 56th mayor of Seattle in [[Seattle mayoral election, 2017|2017]], becoming the city's first female mayor [[Bertha Knight Landes|since the 1920s]] and its second openly [[LGBT]] elected mayor.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/jenny-durkan-lesbian-seattle-mayor-first-woman-win-victory-election-a8044676.html|title=Seattle has just elected its first lesbian mayor|date=November 8, 2017|publisher=}}{{cite news |last=Beekman |first=Daniel |date=November 7, 2017 |title=Jenny Durkan defeats Cary Moon to become Seattle's first woman mayor since the 1920s |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/seattle-mayoral-race-jenny-durkan-cary-moon/ |work=[[The Seattle Times]] |accessdate=November 7, 2017}}{{cite news |last=Beekman |first=Daniel |date=November 8, 2017 |title=Cary Moon concedes to Jenny Durkan in Seattle mayoral election |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/cary-moon-concedes-to-jenny-durkan-in-seattle-mayoral-election/ |work=The Seattle Times |accessdate=November 8, 2017}} She took first place in the nonpartisan August primary and defeated urban planner and political activist [[Cary Moon]] in the November general election, with over 60% of the vote.{{cite news |last1=Beekman |first1=Daniel |date=August 1, 2017 |title=Jenny Durkan leads in Seattle mayor's race, followed by Cary Moon and Nikkita Oliver|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/seattle-mayors-race/ |work=The Seattle Times |accessdate=August 1, 2017}} She and her partner, Dana Garvey, have two sons. Durkan's legal career and mayoralty have garnered controversy. She has received criticism for her decision not to prosecute [[Washington Mutual]], her response to the [[George Floyd protests in Washington (state)#Seattle|George Floyd protests in Seattle]], and her handling of law enforcement during the [[Capitol Hill Organized Protest]]. In July 2020 a [[King County Superior Court]] judge ruled that her use of [[tear gas]] during the protests was sufficient for a petition to [[Recall election|recall]] her as mayor to move forward.{{cite news |date=July 13, 2020 |title=Petition to recall Seattle Mayor Jenny Durkan clears first hurdle|url=https://mynorthwest.com/2015233/mayor-jenny-durkan-recall-petition-clears-first-hurdle/|work=My Northwest|accessdate=July 16, 2020}} ==Early life and education== -Jenny Durkan was born in Seattle on May 19, 1958. She was raised in a large Irish Catholic family of eight siblings. The family lived on [[Mercer Island]] in the mid-1950s{{cite news |title=50 From County Will Attend Prelegislative Conference |publisher=The Seattle Times |date=December 6, 1956 |accessdate=June 28, 2020}} and [[Bellevue, Washington|Bellevue]] in the early 1960s,{{cite news |title=Dominic A. Noonan |publisher=The Seattle Times |date=October 16, 1962 |accessdate=June 28, 2020}} before settling in rural [[Issaquah]] during a time "when there [wasn't] any development."{{cite web |url=https://www.seattlemet.com/news-and-city-life/2018/01/jenny-durkan-when-donald-trump-was-elected-the-world-started-spinning-differently-for-me |title=Jenny Durkan: “When Donald Trump Was Elected, the World Started Spinning Differently for Me” |publisher=seattlemet.com |date=January 26, 2018 |accessdate=August 3, 2020}}{{cite news |title=Senate Gets First of Bills on Sunday Closure of Businesses |last1=Cunningham |first1=Ross |last2=Burt |first2=Lyle |publisher=The Seattle Times |date=January 23, 1963 |accessdate=June 28, 2020}} Her father, [[Martin Durkan]], was a prominent Seattle-area lawyer, Democratic legislator, and lobbyist whose career included 16 years in the state Senate and two unsuccessful runs for governor.{{cite web |last=Drosendahl |first=Glenn |date=December 26, 2010 |title=Durkan, Martin J. Sr. (1923-2005) |url=http://www.historylink.org/File/9674 |work=[[HistoryLink]] |accessdate=June 18, 2020}} Her mother was primarily a homemaker who supported her husband’s career, though she eventually became an executive editor of the ''[[Ballard News-Tribune]]'' and wrote editorials.{{cite news |last=Willmsen |first=Christine |date=February 25, 2008 |title=Lorraine Durkan, 83, "always willing to listen" |page=B4 |url=http://old.seattletimes.com/html/obituaries/2004199242_durkanobit25.html |work=The Seattle Times |accessdate=November 8, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171109135610/http://old.seattletimes.com/html/obituaries/2004199242_durkanobit25.html |archive-date=November 9, 2017 |url-status=dead }} +Jenny Durkan was born in Seattle on May 19, 1958. She was raised in a large Irish Catholic family of eight siblings. The family lived on [[Mercer Island]] in the mid-1950s{{cite news |title=50 From County Will Attend Prelegislative Conference |publisher=The Seattle Times |date=December 6, 1956 |accessdate=June 28, 2020}} and [[Bellevue, Washington|Bellevue]] in the early 1960s,{{cite news |title=Dominic A. Noonan |publisher=The Seattle Times |date=October 16, 1962 |accessdate=June 28, 2020}} before settling in rural [[Issaquah]] during a time "when there [wasn't] any development."{{cite web |url=https://www.seattlemet.com/news-and-city-life/2018/01/jenny-durkan-when-donald-trump-was-elected-the-world-started-spinning-differently-for-me |title=Jenny Durkan: "When Donald Trump Was Elected, the World Started Spinning Differently for Me" |publisher=seattlemet.com |date=January 26, 2018 |accessdate=August 3, 2020}}{{cite news |title=Senate Gets First of Bills on Sunday Closure of Businesses |last1=Cunningham |first1=Ross |last2=Burt |first2=Lyle |publisher=The Seattle Times |date=January 23, 1963 |accessdate=June 28, 2020}} Her father, [[Martin Durkan]], was a prominent Seattle-area lawyer, Democratic legislator, and lobbyist whose career included 16 years in the state Senate and two unsuccessful runs for governor.{{cite web |last=Drosendahl |first=Glenn |date=December 26, 2010 |title=Durkan, Martin J. Sr. (1923-2005) |url=http://www.historylink.org/File/9674 |work=[[HistoryLink]] |accessdate=June 18, 2020}} Her mother was primarily a homemaker who supported her husband’s career, though she eventually became an executive editor of the ''[[Ballard News-Tribune]]'' and wrote editorials.{{cite news |last=Willmsen |first=Christine |date=February 25, 2008 |title=Lorraine Durkan, 83, "always willing to listen" |page=B4 |url=http://old.seattletimes.com/html/obituaries/2004199242_durkanobit25.html |work=The Seattle Times |accessdate=November 8, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171109135610/http://old.seattletimes.com/html/obituaries/2004199242_durkanobit25.html |archive-date=November 9, 2017 |url-status=dead }} Durkan attended [[Forest Ridge School of the Sacred Heart]], a private Catholic girls' school in Bellevue.{{cite news|first=Ellis E.|last=Conklin|title=Score 2 for the defense; Attorneys compile winning record as firm's 'dynamic duo'|work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]|page=C1|date=August 10, 1992}} She spent part of her junior year of high school as an exchange student in London and said that "the best part of the experience was traveling through England to Scotland, France, Austria, Switzerland and Germany."{{cite news |title=Exchange sends girls to farflung schools |last=Dunphy |first=Mary Elayne |publisher=The Seattle Times |date=February 16, 1975 |accessdate=July 1, 2020}} A high-school classmate of Durkan's remembers her as “super independent, and rough-and-tumble…strong-willed and adventurous.”{{cite web|url=https://issuu.com/peggyoc/docs/mes_amis_spring_2018_final |title=Seattle’s New Mayor is a ‘Woman Who Can’ |publisher=Forest Ridge School of the Sacred Heart |date=Spring 2018 |accessdate=August 3, 2020}} Durkan earned her B.A. degree from the [[University of Notre Dame]] in 1980.{{cite web |last1=Durkan |first1=Jenny |title=Biography |url=https://www.seattle.gov/documents/Departments/CommunityPoliceCommission/Durkan_Biography.pdf |website=Seattle.gov |accessdate=14 June 2020}} At Notre Dame, she tried out for the basketball team before being cut and ending up as the team’s statistician.{{cite web |title=Hoops prophet? Seattle Mayor Jenny Durkan correctly predicted men’s and women’s NCAA tournament winners |author=Percy Allen |publisher=The Seattle Times |date=April 3, 2018 |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/sports/college-basketball/seattle-mayor-jenny-durkan-picked-ncaa-tournament-winners/ }} After graduating, Durkan spent two years in Alaska, teaching high-school English and coaching a girls' basketball team in the Yup’ik Eskimo community through the Jesuit Volunteer Corps.{{cite web|url=https://magazine.washington.edu/feature/u-s-attorney-jenny-durkan-is-known-as-a-straight-shooter/ |author=Julie Garner |title= U.S. Attorney Jenny Durkan is known as a straight shooter |publisher=University of Washington Magazine |date=September 2014 |accessdate=August 3, 2020}} After a summer working as a baggage handler for [[Wien Air Alaska]] in St. Mary’s, Alaska as a dues-paying Teamster, Durkan enrolled in the [[University of Washington School of Law]], earning her J.D. degree in 1985.Callaghan, Peter. [http://blogs.thenewstribune.com/politics/2009/05/15/obama_names_jenny_durkan_u_s_attorney_fo "Obama names Jenny Durkan U.S. Attorney for Western District"], ''[[The News Tribune]]'', May 15, 2009.{{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090930115131/http://blogs.thenewstribune.com/politics/2009/05/15/obama_names_jenny_durkan_u_s_attorney_fo |date=September 30, 2009}} "I wanted to be a lawyer since I was 5 years old," she told the ''[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]'' in 1992. "When I graduated from law school, my mother said, 'Finally someone is going to pay you to argue."' ==Career== ===Private practice=== While in law school, Durkan participated in a pilot criminal defense clinic, working with the public defender's office to represent individuals charged in Seattle municipal court. She continued the work on a pro bono basis, until she moved to [[Washington, D.C.]] to practice law with the firm of [[Williams & Connolly]]. There she did a range of civil and criminal cases, including representing reporters subpoenaed by the government. Durkan returned to Seattle in 1991, and established a successful practice focusing on criminal defense and work on behalf of plaintiffs, including the family of Lt. Walter Kilgore, who died in the [[Seattle Fire Department#Pang warehouse fire|Pang warehouse fire]],{{Cite news|url=http://blog.seattlepi.com/seattle911/2011/01/05/wednesday-marks-anniversary-of-deadly-seattle-fire/|title=Wednesday marks anniversary of deadly Seattle fire|last=McNerthney|first=Caset|date=January 5, 2011|newspaper=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]|access-date=May 4, 2017|language=en-US}} the case of Stan Stevenson (a retired firefighter who was stabbed leaving a Mariners game) and the case of [[Kate Fleming]], who died in a flash flood in her Madison Valley basement during the [[Hanukkah Eve windstorm of 2006]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.washington.edu/alumni/columns-magazine/september-2014/features/durkan/|title=Straight Shooter {{!}} Columns Archive, September 2014 {{!}} Past issues of Columns, the University of Washington Alumni Magazine|website=www.washington.edu|language=en-US|access-date=May 4, 2017}}{{citation|title=What killed Kate Fleming?|author=[[Knute Berger]]|date=April 19, 2007|work=[[Crosscut.com]]|url=http://crosscut.com/2007/04/what-killed-kate-fleming/|accessdate=November 10, 2017}} In 1994 Durkan became executive council and political director to Governor [[Mike Lowry]], making her Lowry's chief lawyer. Lowry had been a campaign manager to and protege of her father in 1972, and Durkan worked for then congressman Lowry in the 1980s. After initially recommending that an independent investigator represent Lowry, Durkan resigned in February 1995 after deputy press secretary Susanne Albright accused him of sexual harassment.{{cite news |url=https://www.spokesman.com/stories/1995/feb/14/governors-top-legal-adviser-calls-it-quits-lowry/ |title=Governor’s Top Legal Adviser Calls It Quits Lowry Insists Resignation Not Tied To Sex Harassment Case |last=Ammons |first=David |publisher=The Spokesman Review |date=February 14, 1995 |accessdate=June 18, 2020}}{{cite news |url=https://www.baltimoresun.com/news/bs-xpm-1995-02-07-1995038116-story.html |title=Washington governor to face outside investigator in sex-harassment case |publisher=The Baltimore Sun |date=February 7, 1995 |accessdate=June 18, 2020}} @@ -121,42 +121,42 @@ ===Police chief selection=== Durkan's selection of a permanent chief of the [[Seattle Police Department]] in May 2018 ran into controversy after her list of finalists excluded interim chief [[Carmen Best]], who had also served as deputy chief. After receiving criticism from community activists and the police officers' guild for choosing out-of-state finalists, Durkan defended her decision as the recommendation of a search committee.{{cite news |last1=Miletich |first1=Steve |last2=Beekman |first2=Daniel |date=May 29, 2018 |title=Despite mounting criticism, Durkan defends selection process for Seattle police chief |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/despite-mounting-criticism-durkan-defends-selection-process-for-seattle-police-chief/ |work=The Seattle Times |accessdate=August 25, 2019}} Durkan nominated Best as a finalist after another finalist withdrew to take a different position within the department,{{cite news |last1=Miletich |first1=Steve |last2=Beekman |first2=Daniel |date=July 17, 2018 |title=Carmen Best, once rejected, is Seattle mayor's pick for top cop |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/carmen-best-picked-as-new-seattle-police-chief/ |work=The Seattle Times |accessdate=August 25, 2019}} and the city council confirmed Best as police chief in August 2018.{{cite news |last=Beekman |first=Daniel |date=August 13, 2018 |title=Carmen Best confirmed as Seattle police chief |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/carmen-best-confirmed-as-seattle-police-chief/ |work=The Seattle Times |accessdate=August 25, 2019}} ===Workplace conduct=== In April 2019, two of Durkan's staffers accused her of mistreatment and called the working environment "toxic". One alleged that Durkan had "grabbed her face and forcibly turned her head" when the employee was making suggestions on how to handle the anniversary of the death of community leader [[Donnie Chin International Childrens Park#Donnie Chin|Donnie Chin]]. The other described a hostile work environment where she was "set up to fail" despite having a good track record at previous jobs, and wanted $1.6 million in lost wages and emotional distress. Both employees were Asian women, a fact the second employee pointed out. Durkan's office denied both employees' allegations.{{cite news |last=Kroman |first=David |date=April 17, 2019 |title=Two former Durkan staffers alleged mistreatment in Seattle mayor's office |url=https://crosscut.com/2019/04/two-former-durkan-staffers-alleged-mistreatment-seattle-mayors-office |work=[[Crosscut.com]] |accessdate=August 25, 2019}} ===Homeless sweeps during COVID-19 pandemic=== [[File:Winter Homeless Seattle.jpg|thumb|A homeless camp in Seattle, under the [[Alaskan Way Viaduct]], 2019]] During the [[COVID-19 pandemic]], Durkan continued sweeping [[Tent city#Seattle, Washington|homeless encampments]], forcing homeless people to leave their campsite and find a different place to live. [[Homeless shelters]] had gone on lock down in late March and had limited capabilities.{{citenews |url=https://www.thenation.com/article/society/seattle-homeless-sweeps-coronavirus/ |title=Seattle Destroyed Homeless Encampments as the Pandemic Raged |last1=Kim Jr. |first1=Dae Shik |last2=Oron |first2=Guy |publisher=The Nation |date=April 2, 2020 |accessdate=June 12, 2020}} The [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] had stated that "Clearing encampments can cause people to disperse throughout the community and break connections with service providers. This increases the potential for infectious disease spread."{{citeweb |url=https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/homeless-shelters/unsheltered-homelessness.html |title=Interim Guidance on Unsheltered Homelessness and Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) for Homeless Service Providers and Local Officials |publisher=Center for Disease Control and Prevention |date=March 2020 |accessdate=June 12, 2020}} Durkan said that these encampments were cleared for the safety of both the people in the encampment and the community, but that the encampments had "shootings, human trafficking and other violent crimes."{{citenews |url=https://www.kuow.org/stories/durkan |title=Mayor Durkan on clearing homeless encampments during the pandemic |last=Radke |first=Bill |publisher=[[KUOW-FM|KUOW]] |date=May 21, 2020 |accessdate=June 12, 2020}} Advocates argued that the homeless were more susceptible to COVID-19 and, given that the homeless in Seattle were also experiencing an outbreak of [[Hepatitis A]], the ability to quarantine in a tent was their best option.{{citenews |url=https://southseattleemerald.com/2020/05/27/opinion-mayor-durkan-if-you-care-about-public-health-stop-the-sweeps/ |title=OPINION: Mayor Durkan, if You Care about Public Health, Stop the Sweeps |last1=Alson |first1=Julianna |last2=Garakani |first2=Omid Bagheri |last3=Vargas |first3=Miranda |publisher=South Seattle Emerald |date=May 27, 2020 |accessdate=June 12, 2020}} On May 15 [[Seattle City Council]] members [[Tammy Morales]], [[Teresa Mosqueda]] and [[Kshama Sawant]] introduced an ordinance to ban sweeps of encampments during the Coronavirus pandemic.{{citeweb |url=http://seattle.legistar.com/LegislationDetail.aspx?ID=4539142&GUID=5C6549D2-42E8-4F64-9D95-67285890F381&FullText=1 |title=Council Bill number 119796 |publisher=Office of the City Clerk of Seattle, WA |date=May 15, 2020 |accessdate=June 12, 2020}} Durkan objected to the bill and no agreement was reached by the council.{{citeweb |url=https://patch.com/washington/seattle/seattle-struggles-act-proposal-halt-encampment-sweeps |title=Seattle Struggles To Act On Proposal To Halt Encampment Sweeps |last=Woodman |first=Charles |publisher=patch.com |date=May 28, 2020 |accessdate=June 12, 2020}} The bill is not expected to receive enough votes to pass, and Deputy Mayor Mike Fong told the Council that the bill would be vetoed by the mayor because "Fundamentally we simply don’t believe that this particular issue with regard to encampment removals is something that should be legislated."{{citeweb |url=https://www.theurbanist.org/2020/06/09/seattle-must-reform-homeless-encampment-rules/ |title=Seattle Must Reform Homeless Encampment Rules to Protect Rights and Public Health |last=Dekom |first=Anton |publisher=The Urbanist |date=June 9, 2020 |accessdate=June 12, 2020}} ===Handling of George Floyd protests=== [[File:BLM Seattle on June 7, 2020 - 4.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Flier inside |date=July 3, 2020 |accessdate=July 4, 2020}} and on July 10 she ruled that one of the seven allegations had sufficient evidence to move forward, allowing petitioners to gather signatures for a recall election. The allegation is that Durkan violated her oath of office: "To the extent the allegations pertain to failure to step in to stop the use of chemical crowd control agents after Mayor Durkan is alleged to have become aware of and opposed to their alleged use on peaceful protesters as a means of crowd control, such allegations are legally and factually sufficient to go forward."{{cite news |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/king-county-superior-court-judge-allows-petition-to-recall-mayor-jenny-durkan-to-move-forward/ |title=King County Superior Court judge allows petition for election to recall Mayor Jenny Durkan to move forward |publisher=The Seattle Times |date=July 11, 2020 |accessdate=July 11, 2020}} Durkan's legal team asked Roberts to reconsider the ruling, arguing that the charge was the responsibility of Police Chief Carmen Best, but Roberts declined.{{cite news |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/mayor-jenny-durkan-appeals-recall-decision-to-washington-state-supreme-court/ |title=Mayor Jenny Durkan appeals recall decision to Washington state Supreme Court |last=Gutman |first=David |publisher=The Seattle Times |date=August 12, 2020 |accessdate=August 30, 2020}} On August 12 Durkan's legal team appealed the decision to the Washington State Supreme Court. The petitioners for the recall requested that the Supreme Court reconsider two of the charges that Roberts dismissed. 50,000 signatures of Seattle voters are needed for the recall to occur. +Police officers continued using [[tear gas]] to combat protesters, and on June 5 Durkan ordered a 30-day ban.{{cite news |title=Seattle bans police use of tear gas for 30 days |url=https://www.king5.com/article/news/local/seattle-bans-police-use-of-tear-gas-for-30-days/281-2d557bfc-c6dd-428f-9715-b418301dfaa6 |accessdate=July 7, 2020 |work=King 5 |date=June 5, 2020}} Nevertheless on June 6 the police used pepper spray and blast balls to disperse protesters outside the East Precinct,{{cite news |title=Seattle police use blast balls, pepper spray to try to disperse Saturday protesters |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/seattle-area-protests-demonstrators-prepare-for-ninth-day-of-action-after-george-floyds-killing/ |accessdate=July 7, 2020 |work=The Seattle Times |date=June 6, 2020}} and on June 7 "unleashed a barrage of tear gas and flash bangs" on a crowd outside the precinct.{{cite news |last1=Beekman |first1=Daniel |last2=Brownstone |first2=Sydney |title=Seattle council members vow ‘inquest’ into police budget; some say mayor should consider resigning |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/seattle-council-members-vow-inquest-into-police-budget-some-say-mayor-should-consider-resigning/ |work=The Seattle Times |date=June 8, 2020 |accessdate=July 7, 2020}} On June 8, Seattle City Council members Morales, Mosqueda and Sawant called on Durkan to resign or be impeached "for gassing her own people".{{citeweb|url=https://www.kuow.org/stories/3-seattle-council-members-say-mayor-durkan-should-resign-after-police-response-to-protests|title=3 Seattle council members say Mayor Durkan should resign after police response to protests|publisher=[[KUOW-FM|KUOW]]|date=June 9, 2020|accessdate=June 10, 2020}} On June 9, hundreds of protesters occupied City Hall to demand her resignation,.{{citeweb|url=https://nypost.com/2020/06/10/seattle-protesters-march-on-city-hall-to-demand-mayor-resigns/|title=Seattle protesters march on city hall to demand Mayor Durkan’s resignation|publisher=[[New York Post]]|date=June 10, 2020|accessdate=June 10, 2020}}{{cite web |url=https://crosscut.com/2020/06/mayor-jenny-durkan-not-trailblazer-seattle-needs |title=Mayor Jenny Durkan is not the trailblazer Seattle needs |last=Peters |first=Lola E. |publisher=Crosscut |date=June 9, 2020 |accessdate=June 13, 2020}} and on June 28 protesters marched to Durkan's home.{{cite news |url=https://www.king5.com/article/news/local/protests/seattle-city-councilmember-kshama-sawant-joined-a-large-group-of-protesters-outside-the-chop-zone-who-marched-to-durkans-house-on-sunday-afternoon/281-b8177945-8696-4cfb-afa8-dfda5f9ccf1f |title=Protesters march to Seattle Mayor Durkan's house as 'CHOP' scene continues |publisher=King 5 News |date=June 28, 2020 |accessdate=June 7, 2020}} A (non-legally binding) change.org petition to recall Durkan, started by residents effected by the use of tear gas, gathered over 43,000 signatures beginning in June.{{cite news |url=https://southseattleemerald.com/2020/08/13/heres-whats-going-on-with-the-mayoral-recall-election-fight-without-all-the-legalese/ |title=Here’s What’s Going On With the Mayoral Recall Election Fight — Without All the Legalese |last=Bick |first=Carolyn |publisher=South Seattle Emerald |date=August 13, 2020 |accessdate=August 29, 2020}} On July 2, [[King County Superior Court]] judge Mary Roberts heard arguments for two separate petitions to [[Recall election|recall]] Durkan,{{cite news |url=https://www.kiro7.com/news/local/judge-hears-dual-petitions-recall-seattle-mayor/4WVFOQAHHZCIZDR3AO5MBRNYVA/ |title=Judge hears dual petitions to recall Seattle mayor |publisher=KIRO News |date=July 3, 2020 |accessdate=July 4, 2020}} and on July 10 she ruled that one of the seven allegations had sufficient evidence to move forward, allowing petitioners to gather signatures for a recall election. The allegation is that Durkan violated her oath of office: "To the extent the allegations pertain to failure to step in to stop the use of chemical crowd control agents after Mayor Durkan is alleged to have become aware of and opposed to their alleged use on peaceful protesters as a means of crowd control, such allegations are legally and factually sufficient to go forward."{{cite news |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/king-county-superior-court-judge-allows-petition-to-recall-mayor-jenny-durkan-to-move-forward/ |title=King County Superior Court judge allows petition for election to recall Mayor Jenny Durkan to move forward |publisher=The Seattle Times |date=July 11, 2020 |accessdate=July 11, 2020}} Durkan's legal team asked Roberts to reconsider the ruling, arguing that the charge was the responsibility of Police Chief Carmen Best, but Roberts declined.{{cite news |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/mayor-jenny-durkan-appeals-recall-decision-to-washington-state-supreme-court/ |title=Mayor Jenny Durkan appeals recall decision to Washington state Supreme Court |last=Gutman |first=David |publisher=The Seattle Times |date=August 12, 2020 |accessdate=August 30, 2020}} On August 12 Durkan's legal team appealed the decision to the Washington State Supreme Court. The petitioners for the recall requested that the Supreme Court reconsider two of the charges that Roberts dismissed. 50,000 signatures of Seattle voters are needed for the recall to occur. Durkan has also been criticized by conservatives. Trump criticized the responses of Durkan and Governor [[Jay Inslee]], claiming that they had not been effective in dealing with protesters, especially regarding the [[Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone|Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone/Capitol Hill Occupied Protest]] and the Seattle police's abandonment of the East Precinct. He threatened to retake the city if local leaders did not reassert their authority.{{cite news |last1=Baker |first1=Mike |title=‘Take Back Your City’ From Protesters, Trump Tells Seattle Mayor |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/11/us/capitol-hill-autonomous-zone-seattle-trump.html |work=The New York Times |date=June 10, 2020}} Durkan called the creation of the police-free autonomous zone an attempt to "de-escalate interactions between protesters and law enforcement".{{Cite web|last=Mazza|first=Ed|date=June 11, 2020|title=Politicians Tell Trump To Go Back To The Bunker After His Threat To ‘Take Back’ Seattle|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/politics/politicians-tell-trump-to-go-back-to-the-bunker-after-his-threat-to-take-back-seattle/ar-BB15kw8q|website=www.msn.com}} On June 12, she visited the police-free zone and told a [[The New York Times|''New York Times'']] reporter that she did not know of any serious crime reported in the area.{{Cite news|date=2020-06-13|title=Live Updates on George Floyd Protests: Judge Is Assigned to Officers’ Murder Trial|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/12/us/protests-george-floyd-black-lives-matter.html|issn=0362-4331}} On June 20, a shooting in the zone left one man dead and another in critical condition.{{Cite news|date=2020-06-20|title=Shooting in Seattle protest zone leaves 1 dead, 1 injured|language=en-US|work=Associated Press|url=https://apnews.com/416aed8cc09583e1999fea553fc46042}} Chilton Williamson, Jr., of the right-wing ''Catholic World Reporter'' said that Durkan's attitude towards CHOP indicated that she "could have felt comfortable and at home in the [[Weimar Republic]] during its final days.”{{cite web |url=https://www.catholicworldreport.com/2020/06/28/will-nothing-good-happen-here/ |title=Will Nothing Good Happen Here? |last=Williamson Jr. |first=Chilton |publisher=Catholic World Reporter |date=June 28, 2020 |accessdate=June 28, 2020}} ==See also== * [[List of mayors of the 50 largest cities in the United States]] * [[List of United States political families (D)|List of United States political families]] ==References== -{{ref list}} +{{reflist}} ==External links== * {{C-SPAN|jennydurkan}} {{s-start}} {{s-legal}} {{s-bef|before=[[John McKay (attorney)|John McKay]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[United States Attorney|U.S. Attorney]] for the [[United States District Court for the Western District of Washington|Western District of Washington]]|years=2009–2014}} {{s-aft|after=Annette Hayes
{{small|Acting}}}} |- {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Tim Burgess (politician)|Tim Burgess]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Mayor of Seattle]]|years=2017–present}} {{s-inc}} {{s-end}} @@ -175,15 +175,16 @@ [[Category:American women lawyers]] [[Category:Lawyers from Seattle]] [[Category:Bisexual politicians]] [[Category:LGBT appointed officials in the United States]] [[Category:LGBT lawyers]] [[Category:LGBT mayors of places in the United States]] [[Category:LGBT people from Washington (state)]] [[Category:Mayors of Seattle]] [[Category:People from Island County, Washington]] [[Category:People from Issaquah, Washington]] [[Category:United States Attorneys for the Western District of Washington]] [[Category:University of Notre Dame alumni]] [[Category:University of Washington School of Law alumni]] [[Category:Washington (state) Democrats]] [[Category:Women mayors of places in Washington (state)]] +[[Category:20th-century women lawyers]]

edits.entity: Cassandra Butts
edits.diff:
--- +++ @@ -1,17 +1,17 @@ {{short description|American lawyer}} -{{Infobox politician +{{Infobox officeholder |name = Cassandra Butts |birth_date = {{birth date|1965|8|10}} |birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. |death_date = {{death date and age|2016|5|25|1965|8|10}} |death_place = [[Washington, D.C.]], U.S. |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |education = [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill|University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[Harvard University]] ([[Juris Doctor|JD]]) }} '''Cassandra Quin Butts''' (August 10, 1965 – May 25, 2016) was an American lawyer, policy expert, and Deputy White House counsel. On December 23, 2008, Butts was selected by President-elect [[Barack Obama]] to serve as Deputy White House Counsel, focusing on domestic policy and ethics.{{cite web|url=http://thinkprogress.org/2008/12/23/obama-butts|title=Obama appoints Cassandra Butts as Deputy White House Counsel|publisher=Think Progress|date=2008-12-23|accessdate=2008-12-23|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090604143043/http://thinkprogress.org/2008/12/23/obama-butts/|archive-date=2009-06-04|url-status=dead}} She was on the advisory board for then-[[President-elect of the United States|president-elect]] Barack Obama's [[Presidential transition of Barack Obama|presidential transition team]].{{cite web| url=https://www.usnews.com/articles/news/campaign-2008/2008/11/05/obama-names-transition-team.html|title=Obama Names Transition Team|accessdate=2008-11-06}} She stepped down as Deputy White House Counsel in November 2009 and served as Senior Advisor in the Office of the Chief Executive Officer at the [[Millennium Challenge Corporation]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.mcc.gov/pages/about/profile/bio-butts-cassandra |title=Cassandra Q. Butts-Senior Advisor-Millennium Challenge Corporation |access-date=2014-07-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140604093617/http://www.mcc.gov/pages/about/profile/bio-butts-cassandra |archive-date=2014-06-04 |url-status=dead }} In February 2014, Obama nominated her to be the ambassador to the Bahamas, but by February 1, 2015, the Senate had not confirmed her to the post. She was re-nominated to the position on February 5, 2015.{{Cite news|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2015/02/05/presidential-nominations-sent-senate|title=Presidential Nominations Sent to the Senate|publisher=WhiteHouse.gov|date=February 5, 2015}} ==Biography== Butts was born on August 10, 1965, in [[Brooklyn, New York]], and at age nine moved to [[Durham, North Carolina]]. She graduated from the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]] and in 1991 from [[Harvard Law School]] where she was a classmate of Barack Obama and the two became close friends.{{cite news|url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/sweet/222679,CST-NWS-sweet22.article|title=Obama's campaign staff a work in progress|accessdate=2008-11-07|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905065142/http://www.suntimes.com/news/sweet/222679%2CCST-NWS-sweet22.article|archivedate=September 5, 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://www.law.harvard.edu/news/2008/11/06_hls-alumni.html|title=Obama names HLS alumni to transition team posts|accessdate=2008-11-07}} @@ -26,39 +26,41 @@ ==Millennium Challenge Corporation== On November 6, 2009, Obama named Butts to serve as a senior advisor in the Office of the Chief Executive Officer of the [[Millennium Challenge Corporation]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/president-obama-taps-cassandra-butts-serve-senior-advisor-millennium-challenge-corp|title=President Obama Taps Cassandra Butts to Serve as Senior Advisor at the Millennium Challenge Corporation|publisher=WhiteHouse.gov|date=November 6, 2009|access-date=2009-11-14|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091113071615/http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/president-obama-taps-cassandra-butts-serve-senior-advisor-millennium-challenge-corp|archive-date=2009-11-13|url-status=dead}} Butts' departure was considered to be one of the highest-level departures up to that point from the office of the [[White House Counsel]], and it was followed one week later by the announcement of the departure of Butts' then-boss, White House Counsel [[Gregory Craig]].{{cite news|last1=Zeleny, Jeff|first1=Jeff|last2=Baker|first2=Peter|title=President's Top Lawyer to Step Down|agency=New York Times|work=New York Times|date=November 14, 2009|ref=pg. A12}} ==Nomination to be Ambassador to the Bahamas== On February 7, 2014, Butts was nominated by President Obama to be [[United States Ambassador to the Bahamas]]. The Senate held a committee hearing on her nomination in May 2014, but took no action the rest of the year, and her nomination lapsed with the end of the [[113th United States Congress]].{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} With the new Congress, Obama renominated her to the post on February 5, 2015. The [[United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations]] reported her nomination to the full U.S. Senate on May 21, 2015. However, Butts' nomination was blocked by several Republican senators. First, Sen. [[Ted Cruz]] placed a blanket hold on all U.S. State Department nominees after he was upset with Obama for the [[Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action|Iran nuclear deal]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/07/opinion/an-obama-nominees-crushed-hopes.html|title=An Obama Nominee's Crushed Hopes|date=June 7, 2016|work=The New York Times|accessdate=August 2, 2016}} However, after Cruz lifted those holds, Sen. [[Tom Cotton]] then stepped in and once again, to protest an issue unrelated to the specific nominees, blocked Butts' nomination and the nominations of ambassador nominees to Sweden and Norway after the Secret Service had leaked private information about a fellow member of Congress. Cotton later lifted his holds on the nominees to Sweden and Norway, but kept his hold on Butts' nomination. Butts told New York Times columnist [[Frank Bruni]] that she had visited Cotton about his objections to her nomination, and Cotton told her that because he knew that Obama and Butts were friends, blocking Butts was a way to "inflict special pain on the president," Bruni wrote. According to Bruni's article, a spokeswoman for Cotton did not dispute Butts' account, but did emphasize Cotton's respect for Butts and for her career. Butts died on May 25, 2016, still awaiting a Senate vote. For several weeks after Butts' death, her nomination had remained pending before the U.S. Senate on its executive calendar. Obama formally withdrew her nomination on June 9, 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2016/06/10/presidential-nominations-and-withdrawal-sent-senate|title=Presidential Nominations and Withdrawal Sent to the Senate|date=June 9, 2016|work=whitehouse.gov|accessdate=August 2, 2016}} ==Death== Butts was found dead in her [[Washington, D.C.]] home by her sister on May 25, 2016. According to a statement from her family she had suffered from a brief illness.{{cite web|title=Cassandra Q. Butts, Obama law school classmate and adviser, dies at 50|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/cassandra-q-butts-obama-law-school-classmate-and-adviser-dies-at-50/2016/05/28/20950d2c-24e1-11e6-9e7f-57890b612299_story.html|date=May 28, 2016|accessdate=January 19, 2018|publisher=washingtonpost.com}} Bruni wrote that she had suffered from acute leukemia and had not felt ill until just beforehand. + ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *https://cassandrabuttsartscholarship.org/ *[http://www.politicalbase.com/people/cassandra-q-butts/30967/photos/ Photo] *[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/choice2008/interviews/butts.html Frontline interview] *[https://www.npr.org/blogs/tellmemore/2007/02/we_knew_them_when.html NPR Interview with Cassandra Butts] {{Obama Executive Office|state=collapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Butts Cassandra}} [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:2016 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century American lawyers]] [[Category:21st-century American lawyers]] [[Category:African-American women lawyers]] [[Category:American women lawyers]] [[Category:African-American lawyers]] [[Category:Harvard Law School alumni]] [[Category:Obama administration personnel]] [[Category:People from Brooklyn]] [[Category:People from Durham, North Carolina]] [[Category:University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill alumni]] +[[Category:20th-century women lawyers]]

 The '''2020 United States presidential election in Kansas''' is scheduled to take place on Tuesday, November 3, 2020, as part of the [[2020 United States elections]] in which all 50 states plus the [[Washington, D.C.|District of Columbia]] will participate.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-elections-key-dates-midterms-2020-presidential-house-congress-senate-a8472821.html|title=US elections key dates: When are the 2018 midterms and the 2020 presidential campaign?|last=Kelly|first=Ben|date=August 13, 2018|work=[[The Independent]]|access-date=January 3, 2019}}</ref> [[Kansas]] voters will choose electors to represent them in the [[United States Electoral College|Electoral College]] via a popular vote. The state of Kansas has 6 electoral votes in the Electoral College.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.archives.gov/federal-register/electoral-college/allocation.html|title=Distribution of Electoral Votes|website=[[National Archives and Records Administration]]|access-date=January 3, 2019}}</ref>
 
 By the time that the primary elections were held in Kansas, incumbent President [[Donald Trump]] was already the Republican Party's [[presumptive nominee]], being the only viable declared major candidate left. On the Democratic Party's side, [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Joe Biden]] became the presumptive nominee after [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Bernie Sanders]], his last competitor, withdrew on April 8, 2020.
 
 ==Primary elections==
 ===Canceled Republican primary===

 The '''2020 United States presidential election in Connecticut''' is scheduled to take place on Tuesday, November 3, 2020, as part of the [[2020 United States presidential election]] in which all 50 states plus the [[Washington, D.C.|District of Columbia]] will participate.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-elections-key-dates-midterms-2020-presidential-house-congress-senate-a8472821.html|title=US elections key dates: When are the 2018 midterms and the 2020 presidential campaign?|last=Kelly|first=Ben|date=August 13, 2018|work=[[The Independent]]|access-date=January 3, 2019}}</ref> [[Connecticut]] voters will choose electors to represent them in the [[United States Electoral College|Electoral College]] via a popular vote. The state of Connecticut has seven electoral votes in the Electoral College.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.archives.gov/federal-register/electoral-college/allocation.html|title=Distribution of Electoral Votes|last=|first=|date=|website=[[National Archives and Records Administration]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=January 3, 2019}}</ref>
 
 Due to the [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|COVID-19 pandemic]], the state's primary elections were postponed until August 11, 2020, marking the first time that the modern presidential primary season has extended into August. By that time, incumbent President [[Donald Trump]] of the Republican Party and former Vice President [[Joe Biden]] of the Democratic Party had already clinched enough delegates to become the presumptive nominees of their respective parties. Furthermore, both the Democratic and Republican National Conventions were scheduled one and two weeks afterwards, respectively, essentially making the Connecticut primary races ''[[pro forma]]''.

 The '''2020 United States presidential election in Louisiana''' is scheduled to take place on Tuesday, November 3, 2020, as part of the [[2020 United States elections]] in which all 50 states plus the [[Washington, D.C.|District of Columbia]] will participate.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-elections-key-dates-midterms-2020-presidential-house-congress-senate-a8472821.html|title=US elections key dates: When are the 2018 midterms and the 2020 presidential campaign?|last=Kelly|first=Ben|date=August 13, 2018|work=[[The Independent]]|access-date=January 3, 2019}}</ref> [[Louisiana]] voters will choose electors to represent them in the [[United States Electoral College|Electoral College]] via a popular vote. The state of Louisiana has 8 electoral votes in the Electoral College.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.archives.gov/federal-register/electoral-college/allocation.html|title=Distribution of Electoral Votes|website=[[National Archives and Records Administration]]|access-date=January 3, 2019}}</ref>
 
 Due to the [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|COVID-19 pandemic]], the state's primary elections were postponed until July 11, 2020. By that time, incumbent President [[Donald Trump]] of the Republican Party and former Vice President [[Joe Biden]] of the Democratic Party had already clinched enough delegates to become the presumptive nominees of their respective parties.

On March 14, they were moved to May 19 due to concerns over the [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|COVID-19 pandemic]].{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/03/14/coronavirus-georgia-presidential-primaries-postponed-until-may/5052124002/|title=Georgia presidential primaries postponed over coronavirus concerns|work=Associated Press|publisher=USA Today|date=March 14, 2020}} On April 9, the primary elections were again rescheduled to June 9.{{cite news|author=Mark Niesse|title=Georgia primary delayed again to June 9 during coronavirus emergency|url=https://www.ajc.com/news/state--regional-govt--politics/georgia-primary-delayed-again-june-during-coronavirus-emergency/W5ElsYWTsP5clpNAVTYXnO/|newspaper=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution|date=April 9, 2020|accessdate=April 9, 2020}} ===Republican primary=== Incumbent President [[Donald Trump]] ran unopposed in the Republican primary, and thus received all of Georgia's 76 delegates to the [[2020 Republican National Convention]].{{cite web|title=Georgia Republican Delegation 2020|url=https://www.thegreenpapers.com/P20/GA-R|publisher=The Green Papers|accessdate=June 10, 2020}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:right;" |+ style="background-color:#f2f2f2;margin-bottom:-1px;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em 0.4em" |2020 Georgia Republican primary

 {{ElectionsGA}}
 The '''2020 United States presidential election in Georgia''' is scheduled to take place on Tuesday, November 3, 2020, as part of the [[2020 United States elections]] in which all 50 states plus the [[Washington, D.C.|District of Columbia]] will participate.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-elections-key-dates-midterms-2020-presidential-house-congress-senate-a8472821.html|title=US elections key dates: When are the 2018 midterms and the 2020 presidential campaign?|last=Kelly|first=Ben|date=August 13, 2018|work=[[The Independent]]|access-date=January 3, 2019}}</ref> [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] voters will choose electors to represent them in the [[United States Electoral College|Electoral College]] via a popular vote. The state of Georgia has 16 electoral votes in the Electoral College.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.archives.gov/federal-register/electoral-college/allocation.html|title=Distribution of Electoral Votes|website=[[National Archives and Records Administration]]|access-date=January 3, 2019}}</ref>
 
 Although the Peach State has not voted for a Democrat since 1992, [[Donald Trump|Trump's]] margin was more narrow in the [[2016 United States presidential election in Georgia|2016 election]] due to the state's fast-growing and diverse population, as seen in the "flipping blue" of several of Atlanta's inner suburban counties for the first time since favorite son [[Jimmy Carter|Carter's]] campaign. Georgia is seen as a key [[battleground state]] in both the presidential and [[2020 United States Senate election in Georgia|Senatorial]] elections.
 
 By the time that the primary elections were held in the state on June 9, 2020, incumbent President [[Donald Trump]] was already the Republican Party's [[presumptive nominee]], being the only viable declared major candidate left. On the Democratic Party's side, [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Joe Biden]] became the presumptive nominee after [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Bernie Sanders]], his last competitor, withdrew on April 8, 2020.
 
 ==General election==
