 The '''2020 United States presidential election in Nebraska''' is scheduled to take place on Tuesday, November 3, 2020, as part of the [[2020 United States elections]] in which all 50 states plus the [[Washington, D.C.|District of Columbia]] will participate.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-elections-key-dates-midterms-2020-presidential-house-congress-senate-a8472821.html|title=US elections key dates: When are the 2018 midterms and the 2020 presidential campaign?|last=Kelly|first=Ben|date=August 13, 2018|work=[[The Independent]]|access-date=January 3, 2019}}</ref> [[Nebraska]] voters will choose electors to represent them in the [[United States Electoral College|Electoral College]] via a popular vote. The state of Nebraska has 5 electoral votes in the Electoral College, 2 from the state at large, and 1 each from the three congressional districts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.archives.gov/federal-register/electoral-college/allocation.html|title=Distribution of Electoral Votes|website=[[National Archives and Records Administration]]|access-date=January 3, 2019}}</ref>
 
 By the time that the primary elections were held in Nebraska on May 12, 2020, incumbent President [[Donald Trump]] was already the Republican Party's [[presumptive nominee]], being the only viable declared major candidate left. On the Democratic Party's side, [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Joe Biden]] became the presumptive nominee after [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Bernie Sanders]], his last competitor, withdrew on April 8, 2020.
 
 ==Primary elections==
 The primary elections were held on May 12, 2020.
 ===Republican primary===

 {{ElectionsAL}}
 
 The '''2020 United States presidential election in Alabama''' is scheduled to take place on Tuesday, November 3, 2020, as part of the [[2020 United States elections]] in which all 50 states plus the [[Washington, D.C.|District of Columbia]] will participate.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-elections-key-dates-midterms-2020-presidential-house-congress-senate-a8472821.html|title=US elections key dates: When are the 2018 midterms and the 2020 presidential campaign?|last=Kelly|first=Ben|date=August 13, 2018|work=[[The Independent]]|access-date=January 3, 2019}}</ref> [[Alabama]] voters will choose electors to represent them in the [[United States Electoral College|Electoral College]] via a popular vote. The state of Alabama has 9 electoral votes in the Electoral College.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.archives.gov/federal-register/electoral-college/allocation.html|title=Distribution of Electoral Votes|website=[[National Archives and Records Administration]]|access-date=January 3, 2019}}</ref>
 
 In the [[2016 United States presidential election]], Trump won Alabama by a large margin (62.08% to [[Hillary Clinton]]'s 34.36%). Alabama has voted for the Republican candidate in every election since it was won by [[Ronald Reagan]] in the [[1980 United States presidential election|1980 election]], generally by large margins. Given this, Trump is very strongly favored to win Alabama in 2020.
 
 [[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]] was a potential host for the [[2020 Democratic National Convention]] but was ultimately not selected.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.al.com/business/index.ssf/2016/08/m.html|title=Mayor Bell: Birmingham will seek the DNC again in 2020|last1=Poe|first1=Kelly|date=August 1, 2016|work=AL.com|accessdate=February 1, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.al.com/news/birmingham/index.ssf/2018/04/yes_birmingham_is_once_again_v.html|title=Yes, Birmingham is again vying for the Democratic national convention|last1=Poe|first1=Kelly|date=April 20, 2018|work=AL.com|accessdate=April 20, 2018}}</ref>

 The '''2020 United States presidential election in Maryland''' is scheduled to take place on Tuesday, November 3, 2020, as part of the [[2020 United States elections]] in which all 50 states plus the [[Washington, D.C.|District of Columbia]] will participate.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-elections-key-dates-midterms-2020-presidential-house-congress-senate-a8472821.html|title=US elections key dates: When are the 2018 midterms and the 2020 presidential campaign?|last=Kelly|first=Ben|date=August 13, 2018|work=[[The Independent]]|access-date=January 3, 2019}}</ref> [[Maryland]] voters will choose electors to represent them in the [[United States Electoral College|Electoral College]] via a popular vote. The state of Maryland has 10 electoral votes in the Electoral College.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.archives.gov/federal-register/electoral-college/allocation.html|title=Distribution of Electoral Votes|website=[[National Archives and Records Administration]]|access-date=January 3, 2019}}</ref>
 
 By the time that the primary elections were held in the state on June 2, 2020, incumbent President [[Donald Trump]] was already the Republican Party's [[presumptive nominee]], being the only viable declared major candidate left. On the Democratic Party's side, [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Joe Biden]] became the presumptive nominee after [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Bernie Sanders]], his last competitor, withdrew on April 8, 2020.
 
 [[Martin O'Malley]], former [[governor of Maryland]] and [[Martin O'Malley 2016 presidential campaign|Democratic primary candidate in 2016]], declined to run for president, while encouraging [[Beto O'Rourke]] to do so.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Merica |first1=Dan |title=Martin O'Malley rules out 2020 bid, urges Beto O'Rourke to run |url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/01/03/politics/martin-omalley-2020-beto/index.html |publisher=CNN |date=3 January 2019}}</ref>
 
 ==Primary elections==
 The primary elections were originally scheduled for April 28, 2020. On March 17, they were moved to June 2 due to concerns over the [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|COVID-19 pandemic]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/03/17/maryland-postpones-april-28-primary-election-over-coronavirus-133776|title=Maryland postpones April 28 primary election over coronavirus |work=Politico|date=March 17, 2020}}</ref>

edits.entity: Amy Klobuchar
edits.diff:
--- +++ @@ -25,30 +25,31 @@ | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1960|5|25}} | birth_place = [[Plymouth, Minnesota]], U.S. | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[John Bessler]]|1993}} | children = 1 | relatives = [[Jim Klobuchar]] (father) | education = [[Yale University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[University of Chicago]] ([[Juris Doctor|JD]]) | signature = Amy Klobuchar Signature.svg | website = {{url|www.klobuchar.senate.gov/public/|Senate website}} }} {{Amy Klobuchar series}} '''Amy Jean Klobuchar''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|l|oʊ|b|ə|ʃ|ɑr}} {{Respell|KLOH|bə|shar}}; born May 25, 1960) is an American lawyer and politician serving as the [[Seniority in the United States Senate|senior]] [[United States Senate|United States senator]] from [[Minnesota]] since 2007. A member of the [[Minnesota Democratic–Farmer–Labor Party]] (DFL), Minnesota's affiliate of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]], she previously served as the [[Hennepin County, Minnesota|Hennepin County]] [[County attorney|attorney]]. She announced [[Amy Klobuchar 2020 presidential campaign|her candidacy]] for the [[2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries|Democratic nomination]] for [[President of the United States]] in the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 election]] on February 10, 2019; on March 2, 2020, she suspended her campaign and endorsed [[Joe Biden]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/03/02/klobuchar-to-drop-out-of-2020-campaign-endorse-biden-118823|title=Klobuchar to drop out of 2020 campaign, endorse Biden|last=Schneider|first=Elena|date=March 2, 2020|work=Politico|access-date=March 2, 2020|language=en|url-status=live}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/03/02/politics/amy-klobuchar-ends-2020-campaign/index.html|title=Amy Klobuchar ends 2020 presidential campaign and endorses Joe Biden|author1=Dan Merica |author2=Kyung Lah |author3=Jasmine Wright |author4=Kate Sullivan|website=CNN}} Born in [[Plymouth, Minnesota]], Klobuchar is a graduate of [[Yale University]] and the [[University of Chicago Law School]]. She was a partner at two [[Minneapolis]] law firms before being elected [[county attorney]] for Hennepin County in 1998, making her responsible for all [[criminal prosecution]] in Minnesota's most populous county. Klobuchar was first elected to the Senate in [[2006 United States Senate election in Minnesota|2006]], becoming Minnesota's first elected [[Women in the United States Senate|female United States senator]], and was reelected in [[2012 United States Senate election in Minnesota|2012]] and [[2018 United States Senate election in Minnesota|2018]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/amy-klobuchar-2020-democrat-president-elected-minnesota-reactions-2018-11|title=Amy Klobuchar is being talked up as a 2020 contender who could 'bury' Trump after she won re-election in Minnesota|author=Bostock, Bill|date=November 7, 2018|work=Business Insider|access-date=November 9, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181109153358/https://www.businessinsider.com/amy-klobuchar-2020-democrat-president-elected-minnesota-reactions-2018-11|archive-date=November 9, 2018|url-status=live}} In 2009 and 2010, she was described as a "rising star" in the Democratic Party.{{Cite news|url=http://m.startribune.com/huffington-post-names-klobuchar-the-smartest-u-s-senator/87658327/?section=politics/blogs|title=Huffington Post names Klobuchar the smartest U.S. Senator|last=Tsukayama|first=Hayley|date=March 15, 2010|access-date=May 14, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910125233/http://m.startribune.com/huffington-post-names-klobuchar-the-smartest-u-s-senator/87658327/?section=politics%2Fblogs|archive-date=September 10, 2017|url-status=live}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.minnpost.com/politics-policy/2009/05/states-only-senator-klobuchar-gains-sympathetic-attention|title=As state's only senator, Klobuchar gains sympathetic attention|last=Dizikes|first=Cynthia|date=May 20, 2009|work=MinnPost|access-date=May 14, 2017|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910083544/https://www.minnpost.com/politics-policy/2009/05/states-only-senator-klobuchar-gains-sympathetic-attention|archive-date=September 10, 2017|url-status=live}} + ==Early life and education== Born in [[Plymouth, Minnesota]], Klobuchar is the daughter of Rose (née Heuberger) and [[Jim Klobuchar]]. Her mother taught second grade until she retired at age 70.{{Cite news|last=Nelson|first=Tim|url=https://www.mprnews.org/story/2010/08/02/rose-klobuchar|title=Rose Klobuchar, mother of Sen. Amy Klobuchar, dies|access-date=February 22, 2017|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170223125452/https://www.mprnews.org/story/2010/08/02/rose-klobuchar|website=MPR News|date=August 2, 2010|archive-date=February 23, 2017}} Her father Jim, a retired sportswriter and columnist for the ''[[Star Tribune]]'',{{Cite news | first=Doug|last=Smith|url=http://www.startribune.com/born-to-ride-jim-klobuchar-and-the-birth-of-the-minnesota-bike-tour/320920321/ | title=Born to ride: Jim Klobuchar and the birth of the Minnesota bike tour | newspaper=[[Star Tribune]] | date=August 7, 2015| access-date=February 22, 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170223044030/http://www.startribune.com/born-to-ride-jim-klobuchar-and-the-birth-of-the-minnesota-bike-tour/320920321/ | archive-date=February 23, 2017 | url-status=live | df=mdy-all }} is of [[Slovene American|Slovene]] descent; his grandparents were immigrants from [[Slovenia]]'s [[White Carniola]] region. His father was a miner on Minnesota's [[Iron Range]].{{cite web|url=https://novice.svet24.si/clanek/novice/svet/5c0935b32ddfb/druga-slovenka-ki-bo-trumpu-spodnesla-tla|title= Druga Slovenka, ki bo Trumpu spodnesla tla|website=Svet24.si – Vsa resnica na enem mestu}}{{cite web|url=https://www.delo.si/magazin/zanimivosti/po-sledeh-slovenskih-prednikov-amy-klobuchar-148291.html|title=Po sledeh slovenskih prednikov Amy Klobuchar|first1=Simona|first2= Simona|last1=Bandur|last2=Fajfar|date=February 11, 2019|website=delo.si}} Amy Klobuchar's maternal grandparents emigrated from [[Switzerland]] to the United States.{{Cite news|first=Lori |last=Sturdevant |authorlink= |title= For Amy Klobuchar, if immigration then were like immigration now … |newspaper=[[Star Tribune]]|date=August 28, 2015 |url= http://www.startribune.com/for-klobuchar-if-immigration-then-were-like-immigration-now/323278261/ |quote=...includes a less familiar story about her mother’s line, the Heubergers. Those grandparents were Swiss immigrants who settled in Milwaukee.}} Klobuchar's parents divorced when she was 15 years old. The divorce took a toll on the family; her relationship with her father was not fully restored until he quit drinking in the 1990s.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RkhsCgAAQBAJ|title=The Senator Next Door: A Memoir from the Heartland|last=Klobuchar|first=Amy|date=2015|publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers|Macmillan]]|location=New York City|isbn=978-1627794176|language=en}} Klobuchar attended public schools in Plymouth and was [[valedictorian]] at [[Wayzata High School]].{{cite web | url=http://www.wayzata.k12.mn.us/Page/7803 | title=WHS Involvement / WHS Distinguished Alumni | website=wayzata.k12.mn.us | language=en | access-date=March 16, 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170317054642/http://www.wayzata.k12.mn.us/Page/7803 | archive-date=March 17, 2017 | url-status=dead }}{{cite web | url=http://www.amyklobuchar.com/about | title=About Amy | website=Amy Klobuchar for U.S. Senate | language=en | access-date=March 16, 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170425061726/http://www.amyklobuchar.com/about | archive-date=April 25, 2017 | url-status=dead | df=mdy-all }} She received her [[Bachelor of Arts]] ''[[Latin honors|magna cum laude]]'' in political science in 1982 from [[Yale University]].1982 ''Yale Banner,'' p. 394. While at Yale, Klobuchar spent time as an intern for then-Vice President and former Senator [[Walter Mondale]].{{Cite magazine | url=http://www.elle.com/culture/career-politics/a11015/the-audacity-of-minnesota-senator-amy-klobuchar-439048/ | title=The Audacity of Minnesota: Meet Senator Amy Klobuchar | last=DePaulo | first=Lisa | magazine=[[Elle (magazine)|ELLE]] | date=March 30, 2010| access-date=May 14, 2017 | language=en | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170503105813/http://www.elle.com/culture/career-politics/a11015/the-audacity-of-minnesota-senator-amy-klobuchar-439048/ | archive-date=May 3, 2017 | url-status=live | df=mdy-all }} Her senior thesis, ''Uncovering the Dome'',{{cite book | last = Klobuchar | first = Amy | title = Uncovering the Dome | year=1986 | publisher = Waveland Press | edition = reprint | isbn = 978-0-88133-218-6}} a 250-page history of the ten years of politics surrounding the building of the [[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome]] in Minneapolis, was published by Waveland Press in 1986. After Yale, Klobuchar enrolled at the [[University of Chicago Law School]], where she served as an associate editor of the ''[[University of Chicago Law Review]]'' and earned her [[Juris Doctor]] ''magna cum laude'' in 1985.{{Cite web|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/politics/elections/ct-cb-amy-klobuchar-2020-election-bio-20191215-vt7kt33uz5fgzktxdgrfx7ciwu-story.html|title=Who is Amy Klobuchar?|date=December 14, 2019|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|publisher=[[Tribune Media Services]]|location=Chicago, IL|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=January 7, 2020}} ==Early career== After law school, Klobuchar worked as a corporate lawyer. Before seeking public office, besides working as a prosecutor, Klobuchar was a partner at the Minnesota law firms [[Dorsey & Whitney]] and [[Gray Plant Mooty]], where she specialized in "regulatory work in telecommunications law".{{cite web | url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=k000367 | title=Klobuchar, Amy – Biographical Information | website=bioguide.congress.gov|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070201220009/http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=K000367|archive-date=February 1, 2007|url-status=dead|access-date=May 14, 2017}}{{cite web | url=http://minnesota.publicradio.org/collections/special/2006/campaign/senate/klobuchar/ | title=MPR: Campaign 2006: U.S. Senate: Amy Klobuchar|website=Minnesota Public Radio| language=en | access-date=May 14, 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170322122031/http://minnesota.publicradio.org/collections/special/2006/campaign/senate/klobuchar/ | archive-date=March 22, 2017 | url-status=live | df=mdy-all }}{{cite web|url=https://www.mprnews.org/story/2019/02/10/amy-klobuchar-timeline | title = Klobuchar timeline: A life of law and politics led to presidential aspirations|first1=Briana|last1=Bierschbach|first2=Cody|last2=Nelson|first3=Jiwon|last3=Choi|work=MPR News|date=February 10, 2019|accessdate=September 18, 2020}} Her first foray into politics came after she gave birth and was forced to leave the hospital 24 hours later, a situation exacerbated by the fact that Klobuchar's daughter, Abigail, was born with a disorder that prevented her from swallowing. The experience led Klobuchar to appear before the [[Minnesota Legislature|Minnesota State Legislature]], advocating for a bill that would guarantee new mothers a 48-hour hospital stay. Minnesota passed the bill and President Clinton later made the policy federal law. Klobuchar was first a candidate for public office in 1994 when she ran for [[Hennepin County, Minnesota|Hennepin County]] attorney. But she had pledged to drop out if the incumbent, [[Michael O. Freeman|Michael Freeman]], got back in the race after failing to win the endorsement of the Minnesota Democratic–Farmer–Labor (DFL) Party for governor. Klobuchar quit the race in June 1994 and supported Freeman for reelection.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WuTCBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA115&lpg=PA115&dq=mike+freeman+amy+klobuchar+1994 |title=The Senator Next Door: A Memoir from the Heartland |author= Amy Klobuchar |via=Books.google.com |year= 2015 |accessdate=December 14, 2018|isbn=978-1627794183 }} He did not seek another term in 1998. Before running for office, Klobuchar was active in supporting DFL candidates, including Freeman in 1990. The county attorney election is nonpartisan, but Freeman, like Klobuchar, is a Democrat. Klobuchar was elected Hennepin County attorney in 1998 and reelected in 2002 with no opposition.{{Cite news | url=https://www.msnbc.com/transcripts/rachel-maddow-show/2015-09-01 | title=The Rachel Maddow Show| date=September 1, 2015 | work=MSNBC | access-date=May 14, 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180115001249/http://www.msnbc.com/transcripts/rachel-maddow-show/2015-09-01 | archive-date=January 15, 2018 | url-status=live | df=mdy-all }} ''Minnesota Lawyer'' named her "Attorney of the Year"."Amy Klobuchar." ''Gale Biography Online Collection''. Gale, 2007. Retrieved via ''Gale In Context: Biography'' database, September 17, 2019.{{cite news |url=http://minnlawyer.com/2001/12/31/minnesota-lawyer-recognizes-10-as-8216attorneys-of-the-year8217-2/ | title=Minnesota Lawyer recognizes 10 as 'Attorneys of the Year' | work=Minnesota Lawyer | date=December 31, 2001 | accessdate=March 21, 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170322111747/http://minnlawyer.com/2001/12/31/minnesota-lawyer-recognizes-10-as-8216attorneys-of-the-year8217-2/ | archive-date=March 22, 2017 | url-status=live | df=mdy-all }}{{subscription required}} Klobuchar was President of the Minnesota County Attorneys Association from November 2002 to November 2003.{{Cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=01nm_wrOOXcC&lpg=PT82&dq=Klobuchar%20Minnesota%20County%20Attorneys%20Association&pg=PT82 | title=51 Women Senators?: Will We Ever Have 51 Women Senators? When? How Will They Represent Us? | last1=Herzig | first1=Frolik & Winnie Frolik & Billy|last2=Herzig|first2=Winnie Frolik & Billy | year=2017 | publisher=iUniverse | isbn=978-1440193033 | language=en}} After the May [[Death of George Floyd|2020 death of George Floyd]] in Minneapolis Police custody, Klobuchar was criticized for her lack of prosecution of police misconduct during her tenure, including a case involving the officer accused of murdering Floyd, though the case was not heard until after she left office.{{Cite web|title=Amy Klobuchar didn't prosecute officer at center of George Floyd's death after previous conduct complaints|url=https://www.theweek.com/speedreads/916926/amy-klobuchar-didnt-prosecute-officer-center-george-floyds-death-after-previous-conduct-complaints|date=May 28, 2020|work=The Week|language=en|access-date=May 28, 2020}}{{Cite web|title=Amy Klobuchar Criticized for Declining to Prosecute Police Shootings as Minnesota County Attorney|author=Mahadevan, Tara C.|url=https://www.complex.com/life/2020/05/amy-klobuchar-declined-prosecute-police-shootings|website=Complex|language=en|access-date=May 28, 2020}}{{Cite web|title=Amy Klobuchar missed chance to prosecute Minneapolis cop now at center of George Floyd death|author=Varney, James|url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2020/may/28/amy-klobuchar-passed-prosecuting-derek-chauvin-min/|date=May 28, 2020|website=The Washington Times|language=en-US|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=May 28, 2020}}

edits.entity: Patrick Leahy
edits.diff:
--- +++ @@ -49,31 +49,31 @@ |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1940|3|31}} |birth_place = [[Montpelier, Vermont]], [[United States|U.S.]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |spouse = {{marriage|Marcelle Pomerleau|1962}} |children = 3 |education = [[Saint Michael's College]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[Georgetown University]] ([[Juris Doctor|JD]]) |signature = Pat Leahy Signature.svg |website = {{url|leahy.senate.gov|Senate website}} }} '''Patrick Joseph Leahy''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|l|eɪ|h|i}}; born March 31, 1940) is an American politician serving as the [[Seniority in the United States Senate|senior]] [[United States Senate|United States Senator]] from [[Vermont]], a seat to which he was first elected in [[United States Senate election in Vermont, 1974|1974]]. A member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]], Leahy held the position of [[president pro tempore of the United States Senate]] from December 17, 2012 to January 3, 2015, and was thus during that time third in the [[United States presidential line of succession|presidential line of succession]]. Now in his eighth six-year [[term of office]], he is currently (since the December 2012 death of [[Daniel Inouye]]) the [[Seniority in the United States Senate|most senior member of the Senate]], and is also the last of the Senate's "[[Watergate Babies]]"{{snd}}Democrats first elected to [[United States Congress|Congress]] in 1974, following [[President of the United States|President]] [[Richard Nixon]]'s August 9, 1974 resignation over the [[Watergate scandal]].{{cite news| last=Garcia| first=Eric| title=Congress' 'Watergate babies' compare, contrast current events| url=http://www.duluthnewstribune.com/news/4294049-congress-watergate-babies-compare-contrast-current-events| date=July 6, 2017| work=[[Duluth News Tribune]]|location=Duluth, Minnesota| accessdate=July 6, 2018}} Additionally, Leahy remains the only sitting U.S. Senator to have served during the presidency of [[Gerald Ford]]. Leahy received the title of [[President pro tempore of the United States Senate|President pro tempore emeritus]] in January 2015. The current dean of the state's congressional delegation, Leahy is [[List of United States Senators from Vermont|Vermont's longest-serving U.S. Senator]], and as of 2020 is the only Democrat the state has ever elected to the Senate. He is the former chairman of the [[United States Senate Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition and Forestry|Agriculture]] and [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary|Judiciary]] Committees, and has served as the ranking member of the [[United States Senate Committee on Appropriations|Appropriations Committee]] since 2017. In 2001, Leahy was one of the two U.S. Senators targeted by the [[2001 anthrax attacks|anthrax attacks]] that killed five people. -He is the longest-serving Democrat in the current [[116th United States Congress|Congress (116th)]]. + ==Early life and family== Leahy was born in [[Montpelier, Vermont]], the son of Alba ([[married and maiden names|née]] Zambon) and Howard Francis Leahy, a printer. His maternal grandparents were [[Italy|Italian]], and his father was of [[Ireland|Irish]] ancestry; some of his ancestors came to Vermont in the 19th century to work at the granite [[Quarry|quarries]] and manufacturing plants in [[Barre (town), Vermont|Barre Town]] and [[Barre (city), Vermont|Barre City]].{{cite news|title=Senate's Leahy finds peace on his Vermont farm |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/31767381|publisher=NBC News|date=July 6, 2009|agency=Associated Press}} Leahy is a 1957 graduate of St. Michael's High School.{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5EWgWPBUBYMC&pg=PA273&lpg=PA273&dq=patrick+leahy+st+michaels+high+school#q=patrick%20leahy%20st%20michaels%20high%20school|title=Official Congressional Directory|last1=Congress|first1=United States|last2=Michael|first2=W. H.|year=2001}} He graduated from [[Saint Michael's College]] in 1961 with a [[bachelor of arts]] degree in political science, and received his [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] from [[Georgetown University Law Center]] in 1964.{{cite book |last1=Nutting |first1=Brian |last2=Hawkins |first2=David |date=2003 |title=Politics In America 2004 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TySHYpwgDCcC&q=%22patrick+j.+leahy%22+%22st.+michael%27s+college%22+%22political+science%22&dq=%22patrick+j.+leahy%22+%22st.+michael%27s+college%22+%22political+science%22 |location=Washington, DC |publisher=CQ Press |page=1026|isbn=9781568028132 }} He was an associate at the firm headed by [[Philip H. Hoff]], then [[Governor of Vermont]].{{cite news |date=May 7, 1966 |title=State's Attorney, City Grand Juror Resign |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/200219120/ |newspaper=Burlington Free Press |location=Burlington, VT |page=13 |url-access=subscription }} In May 1966 Hoff appointed him to fill a vacancy as [[State's Attorney]] of [[Chittenden County, Vermont|Chittenden County]].{{cite news |date=May 10, 1966 |title=Leahy Sworn in as State's Atty. |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/200224429/ |newspaper=Burlington Free Press |location=Burlington, VT |page=13 |url-access=subscription }} Leahy was elected to a full term in 1966{{cite news |date=November 9, 1966 |title=Chittenden County Democratic |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/199324696/ |newspaper=Burlington Free Press |location=Burlington, VT |page=15 |url-access=subscription }} and reelected in 1970.{{cite news |last=Boardman |first=William |date=August 12, 2012 |title=Vermont Attorney General Race Doesn't Have a Lot of Rules |url=http://ivn.us/2012/08/12/vermont-attorney-general-race-doesnt-have-a-lot-of-rules/ |newspaper=Independent Voter Project |location=San Diego, CA}} His service as state's attorney was notable for his participation in a [[sting operation]] that caught Paul Lawrence, an undercover police officer for several agencies in Vermont who falsely claimed to have purchased illegal drugs from several people, which resulted in convictions based on his false testimony.{{cite book |last1=Duffy |first1=John J. |last2=Hand |first2=Samuel B. |last3=Orth |first3=Ralph H. |date=2003 |title=The Vermont Encyclopedia |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uTBCXqOou0YC&pg=PA184 |location=Hanover, NH |publisher=University Press of New England |page=184 |isbn=978-1-58465-086-7}} Leahy married Marcelle Pomerleau in 1962; she is bilingual with French Canadian heritage from Quebecois immigrants to Vermont. They have resided in a farmhouse in [[Middlesex, Vermont]], since moving from Burlington, and have three children: Kevin, Alicia and Mark. In 2012 the Leahys celebrated their 50th anniversary, with Leahy saying, ''We hate it when we're apart from one another.''{{cite web|title=Boston.com - Sen. Leahy and wife, Marcelle, celebrate 50 years|url=https://www.boston.com/news/local/vermont/2012/08/26/sen-leahy-and-wife-marcelle-celebrate-years/X10EhhcijK5k4WZjflLMbN/story.html|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|accessdate=September 2, 2012}}{{dead link|date=October 2020}} Leahy has been legally [[blindness|blind]] in his left eye since birth.{{cite book |last=United States Senate |date=1983 |title=An Amendment to the National Security Act of 1947: Hearings Before the Select Committee on Intelligence of the United States Senate |url=http://nsarchive.gwu.edu/NSAEBB/NSAEBB138/CIA%20Information%20Act%20-%20Senate%20Hearing.pdf |location=U.S. Government Printing Office |publisher=Washington, DC |pages=25–26}}{{cite news |last=Gaudiano |first=Nicole |date=January 19, 2013 |title=Vermont Sen. Leahy Takes Shots Like No One Else |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2013/01/19/senator-patrick-leahy-photographer/1847279/ |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |location=Tysons Corner, VA|accessdate=October 4, 2020}} ==U.S. Senator== ===Early career (1975–1999)=== [[File:Patrick Leahy 1979 congressional photo.jpg|thumb|200px|left|1979 Senate portrait of Leahy]] Leahy was elected to the United States Senate for the first time in November 1974, in the wake of the [[Watergate scandal]] that had resulted in the resignation of President [[Richard Nixon]] in August of that year. He won a close race against Vermont's lone congressman, [[Richard Mallary]], and succeeded retiring 34-year incumbent [[George Aiken]].{{cite web | url=https://www.senate.gov/states/VT/senators.htm | title=Vermont Senators| publisher=[[United States Senate]]|website=senate.gov|date=April 15, 2013|accessdate=October 4, 2020}} At 34 years old, he was the youngest Senator in Vermont history.{{cite web | url=http://www.oregonlive.com/today/index.ssf/2012/12/patrick_leahy_sworn_in_as_pres.html | title =Patrick Leahy sworn in as president pro tempore of Senate after Daniel Inouye's death |work=[[The Oregonian]]| agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=December 18, 2012|accessdate=October 4, 2020}} After Minnesota Representative [[Rick Nolan]] retired from Congress in 2019, Leahy became the only remaining Watergate baby in Congress.{{Cite news|url=http://www.duluthnewstribune.com/news/4401206-nolan-wont-seek-re-election|title=Nolan won't seek re-election|access-date=2018-02-09|language=en|website=Duluth News Tribune|last1=Lundy|first1=John|date=February 9, 2018}}

Leahy and wife, Marcelle, celebrate 50 years|url=https://www.boston.com/news/local/vermont/2012/08/26/sen-leahy-and-wife-marcelle-celebrate-years/X10EhhcijK5k4WZjflLMbN/story.html|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|accessdate=September 2, 2012}}{{dead link|date=October 2020}} Leahy has been legally [[blindness|blind]] in his left eye since birth.{{cite book |last=United States Senate |date=1983 |title=An Amendment to the National Security Act of 1947: Hearings Before the Select Committee on Intelligence of the United States Senate |url=http://nsarchive.gwu.edu/NSAEBB/NSAEBB138/CIA%20Information%20Act%20-%20Senate%20Hearing.pdf |location=U.S. Government Printing Office |publisher=Washington, DC |pages=25–26}}{{cite news |last=Gaudiano |first=Nicole |date=January 19, 2013 |title=Vermont Sen. Leahy Takes Shots Like No One Else |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2013/01/19/senator-patrick-leahy-photographer/1847279/ |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |location=Tysons Corner, VA|accessdate=October 4, 2020}} ==U.S. Senator== ===Early career (1975–1999)=== [[File:Patrick Leahy 1979 congressional photo.jpg|thumb|200px|left|1979 Senate portrait of Leahy]] Leahy was elected to the United States Senate for the first time in November 1974, in the wake of the [[Watergate scandal]] that had resulted in the resignation of President [[Richard Nixon]] in August of that year. He won a close race against Vermont's lone congressman, [[Richard Mallary]], and succeeded retiring 34-year incumbent [[George Aiken]].{{cite web | url=https://www.senate.gov/states/VT/senators.htm | title=Vermont Senators| publisher=[[United States Senate]]|website=senate.gov|date=April 15, 2013|accessdate=October 4, 2020}} At 34 years old, he was the youngest Senator in Vermont history.{{cite web | url=http://www.oregonlive.com/today/index.ssf/2012/12/patrick_leahy_sworn_in_as_pres.html | title =Patrick Leahy sworn in as president pro tempore of Senate after Daniel Inouye's death |work=[[The Oregonian]]| agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=December 18, 2012|accessdate=October 4, 2020}} After Minnesota Representative [[Rick Nolan]] retired from Congress in 2019, Leahy became the only remaining Watergate baby in Congress.{{Cite news|url=http://www.duluthnewstribune.com/news/4401206-nolan-wont-seek-re-election|title=Nolan won't seek re-election|access-date=2018-02-09|language=en|website=Duluth News Tribune|last1=Lundy|first1=John|date=February 9, 2018}} Leahy was nearly defeated in 1980 by Republican Stewart Ledbetter, winning by only 2,700 votes amid [[Ronald Reagan]]'s landslide victory.{{cite web | url =http://vermont-elections.org/elections1/1980GEUSSen.pdf | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20101227212245/http://vermont-elections.org/elections1/1980GEUSSen.pdf | url-status =dead | archive-date =December 27, 2010 | title =U.S. Senator - 1980 General Election Results - Vermont | publisher =vermont-elections.org | date =April 15, 2013 }} In 1986, he faced what was on paper an even stronger challenger in former Governor [[Richard Snelling]], but Leahy turned it back, taking 63 percent of the vote.{{Cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/member_info/electionInfo/1986election.pdf|title=Statistics of the Congressional Election of November 4, 1986|last=Dendy, Jr.|first=Dallas|date=May 29, 1987|website=clerk.house.gov|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}} In 1992, [[Secretary of State of Vermont]] [[Jim Douglas]] held him to 54 percent of the vote.{{Cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/member_info/electionInfo/1992election.pdf|title=Statistics of the Presidential and Congressional Election of November 3, 1992|last=Dendy, Jr.|first=Dallas|date=May 31, 1993|website=clerk.house.gov|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}} Leahy has not faced a substantive Republican challenger since then.{{Citation needed|date=April 2020}}

@@ -48,30 +48,32 @@
 |branch        = {{flag|United States Marine Corps}}
 |serviceyears  = 1970–1976
 |rank          = [[File:USMC-E5.svg|18px]] [[Sergeant]]
 |unit          = [[File:Marine Forces Reserve insignia (transparent background).png|18px]] [[United States Marine Corps Reserve|U.S. Marine Corps Reserve]]
 }}
 '''Richard Blumenthal'''<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/11/nyregion/westport-lawyer-prepares-for-us-role.html|title=Westport Lawyer Prepares for U.s. Role|first=Robert E.|last=Tomasson|date=October 11, 1981|publisher=|newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref> ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|l|uː|m|ə|n|θ|ɔː|l}}; born February 13, 1946) is an American attorney and politician who is the [[Seniority in the United States Senate|senior]] [[United States Senator]] from [[Connecticut]] having served since 2011. He is a member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]]. The state's senior senator since 2013, he is ranked as one of the wealthiest members of the Senate,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.opensecrets.org/personal-finances/net-worth/Richard-Blumenthal?cid=N00031685&year=2015|title=Richard Blumenthal- Net Worth - Personal Finances|first1=The Center for Responsive Politics 1300 L. St|last1=NW|first2=Suite 200|last2=Washington|first3=DC 20005 telelphone857-0044|last3=info|website=OpenSecrets}}</ref> with a net worth of over $100 million.<ref name="Anand"/> Previously, he served as [[Connecticut Attorney General|Attorney General of Connecticut]] from 1991 to 2011.
 
 Born in [[Brooklyn, New York]], Blumenthal attended [[Riverdale Country School]], a private school in the Bronx. He graduated from [[Harvard College]], where he was editorial chairman of ''[[The Harvard Crimson]]''. He studied for a year at [[Trinity College, Cambridge]], in [[England]] before attending [[Yale Law School]], where he was editor-in-chief of the ''[[Yale Law Journal]]''. While at Yale, he was a classmate of [[Bill Clinton|Bill]] and  [[Hillary Clinton]]. From 1970 to 1976, Blumenthal served in the [[United States Marine Corps Reserve]], where he attained the rank of [[Sergeant#United States|sergeant]].
 
 After law school, Blumenthal passed the bar and served as administrative assistant and law clerk for several [[Washington, D.C.]] figures. From 1977 to 1981, he was [[United States Attorney]] for the [[United States District Court for the District of Connecticut|District of Connecticut]]. In the early 1980s he worked in private law practice, including serving as volunteer counsel for the [[NAACP Legal Defense Fund]].
 
 He first served one term in the [[Connecticut House of Representatives]] from 1985 to 1987; in 1986 he was elected to the [[Connecticut Senate]] and began service in 1987. He was elected as [[Connecticut Attorney General|Attorney General of Connecticut]] in 1990, and served for twenty years. During this period political observers speculated about him as a contender for [[Governor of Connecticut]], but he never pursued the office.
 
 Blumenthal announced his 2010 run for [[United States Senate|U.S. Senate]] after [[incumbent]] [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] [[United States Senate|Sen.]] [[Chris Dodd]] announced his retirement. He faced [[Linda McMahon]], a [[professional wrestling]] magnate, in the [[United States Senate election in Connecticut, 2010|2010]] election, winning by a 12-point margin with 55 percent of the vote. He was sworn in on January 5, 2011. He was assigned to the [[United States Senate Committee on Armed Services|Senate Armed Services]]; [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary|Judiciary]]; [[United States Senate Special Committee on Aging|Aging]]; and [[United States Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions|Health, Education, Labor and Pensions]] committees. After the retirement of [[Joe Lieberman]] in 2013, Blumenthal became senior senator for the state. He won re-election in [[United States Senate election in Connecticut, 2016|2016]] with 63.2% of the vote, becoming the first person to receive more than one million votes in a statewide election in Connecticut.
 
+
+
 ==Early life and education==
 Blumenthal was born into a Jewish family in [[Brooklyn, New York]], the son of Jane (''née'' Rosenstock) and Martin Blumenthal. He has a brother, [[David Blumenthal]], who became President of the [[Commonwealth Fund]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.commonwealthfund.org/Bios/B/Blumenthal-David.aspx|title=David Blumenthal, M.D.|website=commonwealthfund.org|access-date=January 30, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140301165215/http://www.commonwealthfund.org/Bios/B/Blumenthal-David.aspx|archive-date=March 1, 2014|url-status=dead|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Their father became president of a commodities trading firm.<ref name=ny81>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/29/style/miss-malkin-plans-bridal.html | work=The New York Times | title=Miss Malkin Plans Bridal | date=November 29, 1981 | access-date=May 22, 2010}}</ref><ref>Hladky, Gregory B. [http://www.hartfordadvocate.com/featured-news/see-dick-run A Closer Look At Richard Blumenthal.] ''Hartford Advocate.'' April 27, 2010.</ref><ref>[https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/biography/Richard_Blumenthal.html Jewish Virtual Library: Richard Blumenthal], retrieved December 22, 2011</ref> His maternal grandfather, Fred "Fritz" Rosenstock, raised cattle on his farm, where Blumenthal and his brother often visited as youths. Their father Martin had immigrated to the United States alone at the age of 17 from [[Frankfurt, Germany]].<ref name="courant">{{cite news|last1=Hamilton|first1=Elizabeth|title=The Public And Private Life Of Dick Blumenthal|url=http://www.courant.com/politics/hc-richard-blumenthal-profile-2004-story.html|access-date=January 10, 2017|work=[[The Hartford Courant]]|date=October 3, 2004}}</ref>
 
 Blumenthal attended [[Riverdale Country School]] in the [[Riverdale, The Bronx|Riverdale]] section of [[the Bronx]] before graduating from [[Harvard College]] with an [[Bachelor of Arts|A.B.]] degree ''[[magna cum laude]]'' as a member of [[Phi Beta Kappa]]. As an undergraduate, he was editorial chairman of ''[[The Harvard Crimson]]''.<ref>Plotz, David. [http://www.slate.com/id/2240729 Just Call Him Senator: An assessment of Richard Blumenthal, the man most likely to replace Connecticut's Christopher Dodd.] ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]].'' January 6, 2010.</ref> Blumenthal was a summer intern reporter for ''[[The Washington Post]]'' in the London Bureau.<ref name="ctpost.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.ctpost.com/news/article/Attorney-General-Richard-Blumenthal-timeline-311842.php|title=Attorney General Richard Blumenthal timeline|publisher=|date=January 7, 2010}}</ref> Blumenthal was selected for a Fiske Fellowship, which allowed him to study at the [[University of Cambridge]] in England for one year after graduation from Harvard College.
 
 In 1973, Blumenthal received his [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] degree from [[Yale Law School]], where he was editor-in-chief of the ''[[Yale Law Journal]]''.<ref>[http://yalelawjournal.org/images/mastheads/82.pdf Volume 82, Number 4, March 1973.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110602235503/http://www.yalelawjournal.org/images/mastheads/82.pdf |date=June 2, 2011 }} ''The Yale Law Journal.''</ref> While at Yale, he was classmates with [[Bill Clinton]], future [[US President|President]], and [[Hillary Clinton]], future [[Secretary of State]].<ref>[http://www.masslive.com/news/index.ssf/2010/09/bill_clinton_stumps_for_richar.html "Bill Clinton stumps for Richard Blumenthal in Conn. Senate race"], The Associated Press, September 26, 2010.</ref> One of his co-editors on the ''Yale Law Journal'' was [[Robert Reich]], future [[United States Secretary of Labor]]. He was also classmate of [[Clarence Thomas]], later appointed as Associate Justice on the Supreme Court, and radio host [[Michael Medved]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/clinton/interviews/reich.html |title=Interviews – Robert Reich | The Clinton Years | FRONTLINE |publisher=PBS |date=January 16, 2001 |access-date=May 26, 2012}}</ref>
 
 ==Military service==
 Blumenthal received five [[Selective Service System#1969 to 1975|draft deferments]] during the [[Vietnam War]],<ref name="auto">{{cite news |last=Pershing |first=Ben |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/05/18/AR2010051802208.html |title=Senate Hopeful Richard Blumenthal Addresses Report He Lied About Vietnam Record |newspaper=Washington Post |date=May 19, 2010}}</ref> obtaining first educational deferments, and then deferments based on his occupation.<ref>{{cite news |last=Taranto |first=James |date=May 18, 2010 |title=Dick Blumenthal, Reporting for Duty |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703957904575252483864076618 |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |location=New York, NY |ref={{sfnRef|"Dick Blumenthal, Reporting for Duty"}}}}</ref> With part-time service in the reserves or National Guard generally regarded as an alternative for those wishing to avoid serving in Vietnam,{{sfn|"Dick Blumenthal, Reporting for Duty"}} in April 1970 Blumenthal enlisted in the [[United States Marine Corps Reserve]].<ref name=dd/> He served in units in Washington, D.C., and Connecticut from 1970 to 1976,<ref>{{cite news |last=Dixon |first=Ken |url=http://www.ctpost.com/news/article/Blumenthal-an-easy-victor-495994.php |title=Blumenthal an easy victor |newspaper=Connecticut Post |date=May 22, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=He served in the Marine Reserve. |work=Photo page |publisher=The New York Times |date=May 28, 2010 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/imagepages/2010/05/18/nyregion/18blumenthal_CA4.html |access-date=February 9, 2017}}</ref> attaining the rank of [[Sergeant#United States|sergeant]].<ref>[http://news.yale.edu/2012/04/02/senator-blumenthal-honored-yale-graduate-school-diversity-conference "Senator Blumenthal Honored at Yale Graduate School Diversity Conference"], ''Yale News'', April 2, 2012.</ref>
 
 During his [[#2010 election|2010 Senate campaign]], news report videos that showed Blumenthal claim that he'd served "in Vietnam" created a controversy.<ref>{{cite news |last=Adams |first=Richard |date=May 18, 2010 |title= Richard Blumenthal's Vietnam fight-back: Democratic candidate Richard Blumenthal is battling on over accusations he falsely claimed military service in Vietnam |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/richard-adams-blog/2010/may/18/richard-blumenthal-vietnam-connecticut-senate |work=The Guardian |location=New York, NY}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Hernandez |first=Raymond |date=May 17, 2010 |title=Candidate's Words on Vietnam Service Differ From History |url=https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/2010/05/18/nyregion/18blumenthal.html |work=The New York Times |location=New York, NY}}</ref> Blumenthal denied having intentionally misled voters, but acknowledged having occasionally "misspoken" about his service record.<ref>{{cite news |last=Mann |first=Ted |date=May 19, 2010 |title=Blumenthal defends service record |url= https://www.theday.com/article/20100519/NWS12/305199926 |work=[[The Day (New London)|The Day]] |location=New London, CT |quote="Attorney General Richard Blumenthal Tuesday acknowledged having "misplaced words" in 2008 when describing his service during the Vietnam War, but he forcefully denied that he had intentionally misled voters into thinking he saw combat in Southeast Asia."}}</ref> He later apologized to voters for remarks about his military service which he said had not been "clear or precise".<ref>{{cite news |last=Condon |first=Stephanie |date=May 24, 2010 |title=Richard Blumenthal Apologizes for Exaggerating Military Service |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/richard-blumenthal-apologizes-for-exaggerating-military-service/ |work=CBS.com |location=New York, NY}}</ref>
 
 ==Early political career==
 Blumenthal served as administrative assistant to [[United States Senate|Sen.]] [[Abraham A. Ribicoff]], as aide to [[Daniel P. Moynihan]] when Moynihan was Assistant to President [[Richard Nixon]], and as a law clerk to Judge [[Jon O. Newman]], [[United States District Court for the District of Connecticut|U.S. District Court of the District of Connecticut]], and to [[Supreme Court Justice]] [[Harry A. Blackmun]].

edits.entity: Dick Durbin

@@ -90,31 +90,31 @@
 * [[Senate Ukraine Caucus]] (Co-Chair)<ref>{{cite news|title=Portman and Durbin Launch Senate Ukraine Caucus|url=http://www.portman.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2015/2/portman-and-durbin-launch-senate-ukraine-caucus|publisher=Rob Portman United States Senator for Ohio|accessdate=February 11, 2015|date=February 9, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150211073945/http://www.portman.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2015/2/portman-and-durbin-launch-senate-ukraine-caucus|archive-date=February 11, 2015|url-status=dead|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
 *[[Afterschool Caucuses]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Members|author=|url=http://www.afterschoolalliance.org/policyCongressionalCaucuses.cfm|format=|publisher=Afterschool Alliance|date=|accessdate=April 17, 2018}}</ref>
 *[[Congressional NextGen 9-1-1 Caucus]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Members|author=|url=http://www.ng911institute.org/about-the-congressional-nextgen-9-1-1-caucus|format=|publisher=Congressional NextGen 9-1-1 Caucus|date=|accessdate=June 8, 2018}}</ref>
 
 === Leadership ===
 [[File:Obama,Biden,Richard Durbin and Steny,Hoyer.jpg|thumb|right|Durbin eating lunch with President [[Barack Obama]], Vice President [[Joe Biden]], and House Majority Leader [[Steny Hoyer]].]]
 In November 1998, Senate Minority Leader [[Tom Daschle]] appointed Durbin as his Assistant Democratic Whip. Following the [[2004 United States Senate election|2004 election]], Durbin became the [[United States Senate Democratic Whip|Democratic Whip]] in the [[109th United States Congress|109th Congress]]. He became the first senator from Illinois to serve as a Senate Whip since [[Everett Dirksen]] did so in the late 1950s, and the fifth to serve in Senate Leadership.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenation.com/issue/february-14-2005|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20120912044945/http://www.thenation.com/issue/february-14-2005|url-status=dead|title=February 14, 2005 - The Nation|date=September 12, 2012|archivedate=September 12, 2012|website=archive.is}}</ref> Durbin served as Assistant Minority Leader from 2005 until 2007 when the Democrats became the Majority Party in the Senate. He then assumed the role of Assistant Majority Leader, or Majority Whip.
 
 In addition to his caucus duties, Durbin is Chairman of the Subcommittee on Human Rights and the Subcommittee on Financial Services and General Government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.votesmart.org/bio.php?can_id=26847 |title=Dick Durbin's Biography - The Voter's Self Defense System |publisher=Vote Smart |date=November 21, 1944 |accessdate=August 1, 2016}}</ref>
 
 In 2000, Democratic presidential nominee [[Al Gore]] reportedly considered asking Durbin to be his [[running mate]] and candidate for [[Vice President of the United States]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2000-08-04/news/0008040244_1_vice-president-al-gore-democratic-sources-mate|title=Durbin Off The VP List; Indiana's Bayh Still On|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|author=August 4, 2000|accessdate=September 16, 2020}}</ref> Gore ultimately selected [[Connecticut]] Senator [[Joe Lieberman]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0008/08/ip.00.html |title=CNN Transcript - Inside Politics: Joseph Lieberman Accepts Al Gore's Offer to Join the Democratic Ticket - August 8, 2000 |website=Transcripts.cnn.com |date=August 8, 2000 |accessdate=August 1, 2016}}</ref>
 
 When Majority Leader [[Harry Reid]] faced a difficult re-election fight in 2010, some pundits predicted a possibly heated fight to succeed him between his assistant Durbin and Senator [[Chuck Schumer]], who is well known for his fund-raising prowess.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/29/us/politics/29schumer.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=February 5, 2011 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131113100032/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/29/us/politics/29schumer.html |archivedate=November 13, 2013  }}</ref> Reid's re-election victory, however, rendered such speculation moot.
 
 ==Political positions==
-Durbin is allegedly one of the most [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberal]] members of Congress. ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'' has called him a "top [[United States Senate|Senate]] liberal."<ref>Khimm, Suzy (December 8, 2010) [http://motherjones.com/mojo/2010/12/durbin-obama-acted-leader-tax-cuts Top Senate Liberal Defends Obama on Tax Cuts], ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]''</ref> His voting record is very similar to the Democratic caucus position, consistent with his leadership position as Whip, which has the duty of persuading senators to follow the party line in their votes.
+Durbin is considered one of the most [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberal]] members of Congress.{{Better source needed|date=October 2020}} ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'' has called him a "top [[United States Senate|Senate]] liberal."<ref>Khimm, Suzy (December 8, 2010) [http://motherjones.com/mojo/2010/12/durbin-obama-acted-leader-tax-cuts Top Senate Liberal Defends Obama on Tax Cuts], ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]''</ref> His voting record is very similar to the Democratic caucus position, consistent with his leadership position as Whip, which has the duty of persuading senators to follow the party line in their votes.
 As a [[trial lawyer]], Durbin has excellent debating abilities, so much so that majority leader [[Harry Reid]] called him "the best debater" in the U.S. senate.{{citation needed|date=January 2013}}
 
 === Abortion ===
 As a congressman, Durbin voted consistently to uphold existing restrictions on abortion or impose new limitations, including supporting a Constitutional amendment that would have nullified ''[[Roe v. Wade]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrlc.org/Judicial/Durbin/index.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=August 4, 2006 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060913222115/http://www.nrlc.org/Judicial/Durbin/index.html |archivedate=September 13, 2006  }}</ref> He reversed his position in 1989 and has since voted to maintain access to abortion, including support for Medicaid funding of it, and opposition to any limitation he considers a practical or potential encroachment upon ''Roe''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.massscorecard.org/Social/Richard_Durbin_Abortion.htm |title=Richard Durbin on Abortion |website=Massscorecard.org |date= |accessdate=August 1, 2016}}</ref> Durbin has maintained that this reversal came about due to personal reflection and his growing awareness of potentially harmful implications of his previous policy with respect to women facing dangerous pregnancies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrlc.org/Judicial/Durbin/DurbinMeetPress.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=August 4, 2006 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060914032545/http://www.nrlc.org/Judicial/Durbin/DurbinMeetPress.html |archivedate=September 14, 2006  }}</ref> While visiting a home for abused children in [[Quincy, Illinois]], the director, a friend, asked him to speak with two girls who were about to turn 18 and be turned out of state care. Talking with those girls, victims of gang rape and incest, made him reconsider his position on the subject. He says, "I still oppose abortion and would try my best to convince any woman in my family to carry the baby to term. But I believe that ultimately the decision must be made by the woman, her doctor, her family, and her conscience."<ref name="tribmag">{{Cite news|last=Parsons|first=Christi|title=Dick Durbin's Challenge|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|pages=15–19, 26–27|date=December 2, 2007}}</ref>
 
 In September 2020, Durbin voted to confirm pro-life judges Stephen McGlynn and David Dugan to lifetime appointments to the federal judiciary in Illinois.<ref>https://www.rollcall.com/2020/09/18/illinois-senators-split-on-judge-votes-exposing-division/</ref>
 
 === Child care ===
 In 2019, Durbin and 34 other senators introduced the Child Care for Working Families Act, a bill that created 770,000 new child care jobs and that ensured families under 75 percent of the state median income did not pay for child care with higher-earning families having to pay "their fair share for care on a sliding scale, regardless of the number of children they have." The legislation also supported universal access to high-quality preschool programs for all 3 and 4-year-olds and gave the child care workforce a changed compensation and training to aid both teachers and caregivers.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://urbanmilwaukee.com/pressrelease/u-s-senator-tammy-baldwin-helps-introduce-legislation-to-ensure-child-care-for-all/|title=U.S. Senator Tammy Baldwin Helps Introduce Legislation to Ensure Child Care for All|date=March 1, 2019|publisher=urbanmilwaukee.com}}</ref>
 
 === China ===
 In April 2017, Durbin was one of 8 Democratic senators to sign a letter to President Trump noting government-subsidized Chinese steel had been placed into the American market in recent years below cost and had hurt the domestic steel industry and the iron ore industry that fed it, calling on Trump to raise the steel issue with [[President of the People's Republic of China]] [[Xi Jinping]] in his meeting with him.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.twincities.com/2017/04/06/klobuchar-franken-among-senators-asking-trump-to-press-china-on-steel/|title=Klobuchar, Franken among senators asking Trump to press China on steel|date=April 6, 2017|first=John|last=Myers|publisher=twincities.com}}</ref>
 
 === Criminal justice reform ===
 In July 2017, along with [[Cory Booker]], [[Elizabeth Warren]], and [[Kamala Harris]], Durbin was one of four senators to introduce the Dignity for Incarcerated Women Act, legislation implementing a ban on the shackling of pregnant women and mandating the Bureau of Prisons to form superior visitation policies for parents along with providing parenting classes and offering health products such as tampons and pads for free. The bill also restricted prison employees from entering restrooms of the opposite sex with the exception of pressing circumstances.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://thehill.com/regulation/court-battles/342506-kamala-harris-slams-sessions-on-criminal-justice|title=Kamala Harris slams Sessions on criminal justice|author=Wheeler, Lydia|date=July 18, 2017|newspaper=The Hill}}</ref>

@@ -38,30 +38,32 @@
 |birth_date   = {{birth date and age|1944|11|21}}
 |birth_place  = [[East St. Louis, Illinois]], U.S.
 |death_date   = 
 |death_place  = 
 |party        = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]]
 |spouse       = {{marriage|Loretta Schaefer|1967}}
 |children     = 3
 |education    = [[Georgetown University]] ([[Bachelor of Science|BS]], [[Juris Doctor|JD]])
 |website      = {{url|durbin.senate.gov|Senate website}}
 |signature    = Dick Durbin Signature.svg
 }}
 '''Richard Joseph Durbin''' (born November 21, 1944) is an American attorney and politician serving as [[Seniority in the United States Senate|the senior]] [[United States Senator]] from [[Illinois]], a seat he was first elected to [[1996 United States Senate election in Illinois|in 1996]]. He has been the [[Senate Democratic Whip]] since 2005, the second-highest position in the Democratic leadership in the U.S. Senate.
 
 Durbin was born in [[East St. Louis, Illinois]]. He graduated from the [[Edmund A. Walsh School of Foreign Service|School of Foreign Service]] and [[Georgetown University Law Center]]. Working in state legal counsel throughout the 1970s, he made an unsuccessful run for [[lieutenant governor of Illinois]] in 1978. Durbin was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives [[1982 United States House of Representatives elections|in 1982]], representing the [[Springfield, Illinois|Springfield]]-based [[Illinois's 20th congressional district|20th congressional district]]. In 1996, he won election to the U.S. Senate. Durbin has served as the Senate Democratic Whip since 2005, and from 2007 to 2015, served as the [[Senate Majority Whip]]. He is currently the Senate Minority Whip. He is also dean of the Illinois congressional delegation.
 
+
+
 ==Early life, education and career==
 Durbin was born in [[East St. Louis, Illinois]], to an [[Irish-American]] father, William Durbin, and a [[Lithuanians|Lithuanian]]-born mother, Anna (''née'' Kutkin; Lithuanian: Ona Kutkaitė).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.com/~battle/senators/durbin.htm |title=durbin |website=Freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.com |date=November 21, 1944 |accessdate=August 1, 2016}}</ref> He graduated from Assumption High School in East St. Louis in 1962. During his high school years he worked at a meatpacking plant. He earned a [[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]] from the [[Edmund A. Walsh School of Foreign Service|School of Foreign Service]] at [[Georgetown University]] in 1966. He was an intern in the office of Senator [[Paul Douglas]] of Illinois during his senior year in college. Durbin earned his [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] from [[Georgetown University Law Center]] in 1969 and was admitted to the Illinois [[bar (law)|bar]] later that year.
 
 After graduating from law school, Durbin started a law practice in [[Springfield, Illinois|Springfield]]. He was legal counsel to [[Lieutenant Governor of Illinois|Lieutenant Governor]] [[Paul Simon (politician)|Paul Simon]] from 1969 to 1972, and then legal counsel to the [[Illinois State Senate]] Judiciary Committee from 1972 to 1982. Durbin was an unsuccessful Democratic candidate for a seat in the Illinois State Senate in 1976.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.votesmart.org/bio.php?can_id=26847 |title=Senator Dick Durbin - Biography - Project Vote Smart |publisher=Votesmart.org |date=November 21, 1944 |accessdate=September 15, 2012}}</ref> He ran for Lieutenant Governor in 1978 as the running mate of State Superintendent of Schools [[Michael Bakalis]]. They were defeated by [[United States Republican Party|Republican]] incumbents [[James R. Thompson|Jim Thompson]] and [[Dave O'Neal]]. Durbin then worked as an adjunct professor at the [[Southern Illinois University]] School of Medicine for five years while maintaining his law practice.
 
 ===U.S. House of Representatives===
 In 1982, Durbin won the Democratic nomination for the now-eliminated [[Illinois's 20th congressional district|20th congressional district]], which included Macon and most of Springfield. He scored a 1,400 vote victory, defeating 22-year incumbent [[Paul Findley]], a U.S. Navy veteran, whose district lines had been substantially redrawn to remove rural farms and add economically depressed Macon, replacing 35-percent of the voters<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1982/10/31/the-1982-elections-the-illinois-20th-district-race/76e5660e-4e40-4615-88b0-f012ad57000a/|title=THE 1982 ELECTIONS: THE ILLINOIS 20TH DISTRICT RACE|last=Bohlen|first=Celestine|date=October 31, 1982|work=Washington Post|access-date=July 10, 2018|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lib.niu.edu/1983/ii830218.html|title=redistricting and Reaganomics Feb 1983|website=lib.niu.edu|access-date=July 10, 2018}}</ref> and include more Democrats as part of the [[decennial]] [[redistricting]].  Durbin's campaign emphasized unemployment and financial difficulties facing farmers, and told voters that electing him would send "a message to Washington and to President Reagan that our economic policies are not working." Durbin benefited from donations by pro-Israel groups from around the United States, in particular, concentrated support from [[AIPAC]] supporters,<ref>The Israel Lobby, p. 157, by John Mearsheimer and Stephen Walt</ref> that were opposed to Findley's advocacy on behalf of the [[Palestine Liberation Organization]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-09-17/how-obama-out-muscled-aipac|title=How Obama Out-Muscled Aipac|last=Reprints|first=Eli Lake EliLake Josh Rogin joshrogin Subscribe|website=Bloomberg.com|access-date=August 31, 2016}}</ref> in the year prior to the election. Durbin was re-elected six times, rarely facing serious opposition, and winning more than 55% of the vote in each election except 1994.<ref>{{cite news|last=Malcolm|first=Andrew|title=The Midwest|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/05/us/the-midwest.html|accessdate=February 1, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=September 5, 1982}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Clymer|first=Adam|title=Democrats Shaping Election as Referendum on Economy|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/03/us/democrats-shaping-election-as-referendum-on-economy.html|accessdate=February 1, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=October 3, 1982}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Clymer|first=Adam|title=GOP House Candidates Leading in Fundraising|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/30/us/gop-house-candidates-leading-in-fund-raising.html|accessdate=February 1, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=October 30, 1982}}</ref>
 
 ==U.S. Senate==
 [[File:Dick Durbin DNC 2008.jpg|thumb|right|Durbin speaks during the final night of the [[2008 Democratic National Convention]] in [[Denver, Colorado|Denver]], [[Colorado]], introducing his party's nominee, fellow Illinoisan [[Barack Obama]]]]
 In [[1996 United States Senate election in Illinois|1996]], Durbin defeated [[Pat Quinn (politician)|Pat Quinn]] to become the Democratic Party's nominee to replace the retiring Democratic incumbent, Senator [[Paul Simon (politician)|Paul Simon]], a long-time friend. He faced Republican [[Illinois House of Representatives|State Representative]] [[Al Salvi]] in the November general election. Although the election had been expected to be competitive, Durbin benefited from [[Bill Clinton]]'s 18-point win in Illinois that year and was able to capture a 15-point margin over his opponent.  He has since been re-elected in [[2002 United States Senate election in Illinois|2002]], [[2008 United States Senate election in Illinois|2008]] and [[2014 United States Senate election in Illinois|2014]], each time by at least 10%.
 
 ===Committees===
 * '''[[United States Senate Committee on Appropriations|Committee on Appropriations]]'''
 ** [[United States Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies|Subcommittee on Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies]]

Curran|Margaret Curran]] |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1955|10|20}} |birth_place = {{nowrap|[[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S.}} |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |spouse = {{marriage|Sandra Thornton|1986}} |children = 2 |parents = [[Charles S. Whitehouse]]
Mary Rand |education = [[Yale University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[University of Virginia]] ([[Juris Doctor|JD]]) |website = {{url|https://whitehouse.senate.gov|Senate website}} |signature = Sheldon Whitehouse Signature.svg }} '''Sheldon Whitehouse''' (born October 20, 1955) is an American lawyer and politician serving as the junior United States Senator from Rhode Island since 2007. He is a member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] and previously served as a [[United States Attorney]] from 1993 to 1998 and as the [[Attorney General of Rhode Island]] from 1999 to 2003. + + ==Early life and education== Whitehouse was born on October 20, 1955, in [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]],{{cite web |title=About Sheldon |url=https://www.whitehouse.senate.gov/about/biography |website=Sheldon Whitehouse |accessdate=21 January 2020}} the son of Mary Celine (née Rand) and career diplomat [[Charles S. Whitehouse|Charles Sheldon Whitehouse]], and grandson of diplomat [[Sheldon Whitehouse (diplomat)|Sheldon Whitehouse]] (1883–1965). Among his great-great-grandfathers were Episcopalian bishop [[Henry John Whitehouse]] and railroad magnate [[Charles Crocker]], who was among the founders of the [[Central Pacific Railroad]]. Whitehouse graduated from [[St. Paul's School (Concord, New Hampshire)|St. Paul's School]] in [[Concord, New Hampshire|Concord]], [[New Hampshire]], and from [[Yale College]] in 1978. He received his [[Juris Doctor]] (J.D.) from the [[University of Virginia School of Law]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.senate.gov/about/biography|title=About Sheldon {{!}} U.S. Senator Sheldon Whitehouse of Rhode Island|website=www.whitehouse.senate.gov|language=en|access-date=July 21, 2017}} in 1982. == Early career == Whitehouse worked as a clerk for Judge [[Richard Neely]] of the [[Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia]] from 1982 to 1983. He also worked in the [[Attorney General of Rhode Island|Rhode Island Attorney General]]'s office as a special assistant attorney general from 1985 to 1990, chief of the Regulatory Unit (which oversaw utilities) from 1988 to 1990, and as an assistant attorney general from 1989 to 1990.{{cite web|url=http://wasearch.loc.gov/e22k/20020901083307/http://www.electsheldonwhitehouse.com/about_sheldon.html |title=Sheldon Whitehouse for Governor, "About Sheldon" (cached 9/1/2002) |publisher=Wasearch.loc.gov |date= |accessdate=April 13, 2014}} Whitehouse worked as Rhode Island Governor [[Bruce Sundlun]]'s Executive Counsel beginning in 1991, and was later tapped to serve as Director of Policy. He oversaw the state's response to the [[Rhode Island banking crisis]][http://www.uri.edu/library/special_collections/registers/political_papers/sundlun/seriesV.html] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051120093828/http://www.uri.edu/library/special_collections/registers/political_papers/sundlun/seriesV.html |date=November 20, 2005 }} that took place soon after Sundlun took office. In 1992 Sundlun appointed Whitehouse the state's Director of Business Regulation, where he oversaw a drastic reform in the state's workers' compensation insurance system. ==Early political career== ===U.S. Attorney=== President [[Bill Clinton]] appointed Whitehouse [[United States Attorney]] for Rhode Island in 1994. Whitehouse held the position for four years. With the 1996 extortion conviction of mobster [[Gerard Ouimette]], he was the first prosecutor to convict a member of organized crime under Clinton's "[[three strikes law]]". Whitehouse also initiated the investigation into [[Political corruption|municipal corruption]] in Rhode Island that led to [[Operation Plunder Dome]], in which [[Mayor of Providence, Rhode Island|Mayor]] of [[Providence, Rhode Island|Providence]] [[Vincent Cianci|Vincent "Buddy" Cianci]] was eventually convicted on conspiracy charges.[http://www.ricancercouncil.org/about/members/Whitehouse.php Rhode Island Cancer Council, "Sheldon Whitehouse"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050907204100/http://www.ricancercouncil.org/about/members/Whitehouse.php |date=September 7, 2005 }} As U.S. Attorney for Rhode Island, Whitehouse oversaw an increase in environmental protection efforts, including an investigation into a Narragansett Bay oil spill that yielded the largest fine in state history.{{cn|date=May 2020}} ===State Attorney General=== In 1998, Whitehouse was elected [[Rhode Island Attorney General]]. He initiated a lawsuit against the [[lead paint]] industry that ended in a mistrial; the state later won a second lawsuit against former lead paint manufacturers [[Sherwin-Williams]], Millennium Holdings, and NL Industries that found them responsible for creating a public nuisance.Peter B. Lord, "3 companies found liable in lead-paint nuisance suit," ''[[The Providence Journal]]'', February 23, 2006.[http://www.projo.com/news/content/projo_20060223_lead23.180686c3.html] This decision, however, was unanimously overturned by the [[Rhode Island Supreme Court]] on July 1, 2008. The Court found that under Rhode Island law it is the responsibility of property owners to abate and mitigate lead hazards.{{cn|date=May 2020}}

edits.entity: United States presidential elections in South Carolina
edits.diff:
--- +++ @@ -173,62 +173,62 @@ Vote allocated by legislature. ==Elections from 1788-89 to 1856== In all elections from 1792 to 1860, South Carolina did not conduct a popular vote. Each Elector was appointed by the state legislature. The election of 1824 was a complex realigning election following the collapse of the prevailing [[Democratic-Republican Party]], resulting in four different candidates each claiming to carry the banner of the party, and competing for influence in different parts of the country. The election was the only one in history to be decided by the House of Representatives under the provisions of the Twelfth Amendment to the United States Constitution after no candidate secured a majority of the electoral vote. It was also the only presidential election in which the candidate who received a plurality of electoral votes ([[Andrew Jackson]]) did not become President, a source of great bitterness for Jackson and his supporters, who proclaimed the election of Adams a [[corrupt bargain]]. {| class="sortable wikitable" |- !  The election of 1860 was a complex realigning election in which the breakdown of the previous two-party alignment culminated in four parties each competing for influence in different parts of the country. edits.entity: Polish Constitutional Tribunal crisis (2015 – ongoing)
edits.diff:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -1,25 +1,84 @@
 {{Update|date=September 2017 | inaccurate=yes}}
 {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2019}}
 [[File:Demonstracja Komitetu Obrony Demokracji 04.JPG|thumb|200px|A [[Committee for the Defence of Democracy]] protest in Warsaw against Poland's new government, 12 December 2015]]
 The '''Polish Constitutional Court crisis of 2015''' is a political conflict which began in [[Poland]] in October 2015 with the appointment of five [[Constitutional Tribunal (Poland)|Constitutional Tribunal]] judges by the [[Civic Platform]] (Platforma Obywatelska, PO) party. {{As of|2017|12|20}}, the crisis had, according to the [[European Commission]], extended to include "13 laws affecting the entire structure of the justice system in Poland".<ref name="CE_20171220" /> The Constitutional Tribunal changes included the replacement of three judges whose terms were not due to expire until after the first possible date of meeting of the new parliament and two judges whose terms were not due to expire until after the last possible date of meeting of the new parliament. According to the Polish law, judges of the [[Constitutional Tribunal (Poland)|Constitutional Tribunal]] are to be elected by the parliament which is sitting when the terms of the previous judges expire.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sejm.gov.pl/prawo/konst/polski/kon1.htm|title=Konstytucja Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej|website=www.sejm.gov.pl}}</ref>{{failed verification|date=August 2019}}
 
 Civic Platform was predicted to lose the upcoming elections. After the [[Law and Justice]] (Prawo i Sprawiedliwość, PiS) party won the [[2015 Polish parliamentary election|parliamentary election]], it made its own appointments to the court, arguing that the previous appointments of the five judges by PO were unconstitutional. In December, PiS changed the court's decision-making power by prescribing a two-thirds majority vote and mandatory participation of at least 13 of the 15 judges on the Constitutional Tribunal. The appointments and amendments caused domestic protests and counter-protests in late December and early January; one of the most significant outcomes was the creation of the [[Committee for the Defence of Democracy]] protest movement. The law changes were criticized by [[European Commission]] as threatening the rule of law and the human rights of Polish citizens.<ref name="CE_20171220" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/europe/article/2016/01/13/bruxelles-lance-une-enquete-preliminaire-inedite-sur-la-situation-de-l-etat-de-droit-en-pologne_4846618_3214.html|title=Bruxelles lance une enquête préliminaire inédite sur la situation de l'Etat de droit en Pologne|date=2016-01-13|newspaper=Le Monde.fr|language=fr|issn=1950-6244|access-date=2016-12-04}}</ref>
 
-== Background ==
-On 25 June 2015, the government adopted a new law regarding the constitutional court.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://fakty.interia.pl/raporty/raport-spor-wokol-tk/komentarze/news-spor-o-tk-katastrofa-europejskiego-projektu-integracyjnego,nId,2212494|title=Spór o TK "katastrofą europejskiego projektu integracyjnego"?|date=2 June 2016|work=Fakty.Interia.pl}}</ref> Later, the Constitutional Tribunal found this law to be partly unconstitutional.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://trybunal.gov.pl/postepowanie-i-orzeczenia/wyroki/art/8748-ustawa-o-trybunale-konstytucyjnym/|title=Trybunał Konstytucyjny: Ustawa o Trybunale Konstytucyjnym|website=trybunal.gov.pl}}</ref> It was signed by president [[Bronisław Komorowski]] on 21 July 2015 (about one month before end of his presidency).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.obserwatorkonstytucyjny.pl/trybunal/prezydent-podpisal-ustawe-o-trybunale-konstytucyjnym/|title=Prezydent podpisał ustawę o Trybunale Konstytucyjnym|work=Obserwator Konstytucyjny|date=2015-07-22}}</ref> On 8 October 2015 the outgoing Polish Parliament ([[Sejm]]), on last meeting day,  led by Civic Platform (PO) as the main party of the governing coalition, elected five new [[Constitutional Tribunal (Poland)|Constitutional Tribunal]] judges. Three of them replaced judges whose nine-year terms were to expire on 6 November (almost two weeks after elections), while two were to replace judges whose terms were due to expire in December.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rp.pl/Sedziowie-i-sady/311069942-Wygasaja-kadencje-trojga-sedziow-Trybunalu-Konstytucyjnego.html/|title=Wygasają kadencje trojga sędziów Trybunału Konstytucyjnego
-|language=pl|date=6 November 2015|work=[[Rp.pl]]}}</ref> The judges were chosen on the basis of a law passed earlier in the summer, by the PO-controlled Sejm. At the time of the judges' election, opinion polls had shown that the Civic Platform was likely to lose the upcoming [[2015 Polish parliamentary election|Polish parliamentary election]] on 25 October.<ref name=fakt>{{cite web|url=http://www.fakt.pl/politycy/awantura-o-trybunal-konstytucyjny,artykuly,593265.html|title=Awantura o Trybunał Konstytucyjny|date=2015-11-26|work=Fakt.pl}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://polska.newsweek.pl/ustawa-pis-o-trybunale-konstytucyjnym-zaskarzona-do-trybunalu-konstytucyjnego,artykuly,374563,1.html|title=Ustawa PiS o Trybunale Konstytucyjnym zaskarżona do Trybunału Konstytucyjnego|work=Newsweek.pl|date=2015-11-23|language=pl|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151226170346/http://polska.newsweek.pl/ustawa-pis-o-trybunale-konstytucyjnym-zaskarzona-do-trybunalu-konstytucyjnego,artykuly,374563,1.html|archive-date=2015-12-26}}</ref> If the judges appointed by PO had taken their seats on the Tribunal, the result would have been that 14 out of 15 Constitutional Tribunal judges would have been selected by the Civic Platform.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polsatnews.pl/wiadomosc/2015-12-04/jaki-o-tk-14-z-15-sedziow-bylo-zwiazanych-z-po/|title=Jaki o TK: 14 z 15 sędziów było związanych z PO|date=2015-12-04|language=pl|work=Polsat News}}</ref> However, the President of Poland, [[Andrzej Duda]], refused to swear in these judges<ref name="ppb">{{Cite web|url=https://polishpoliticsblog.wordpress.com/2015/12/31/who-is-winning-polands-constitutional-tribunal-war/|title=Who is winning Poland's 'constitutional tribunal war'?|date=31 December 2015|work=The Polish Politics Blog|first=Aleks|last=Szczerbiak}}</ref> stating that they had been chosen "in contravention of democratic principles".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.polsatnews.pl/wiadomosc/2015-11-16/po-apeluje-do-dudy-o-zaprzysiezenie-sedziow-trybunalu-konstytucyjnego/|title=PO apeluje do Dudy o zaprzysiężenie sędziów Trybunału Konstytucyjnego|work=Polsat News|language=pl|date=2015-11-16}}</ref> On 25 October, the [[Law and Justice]] (Prawo i Sprawiedliwość, PiS) party won an unprecedented absolute majority of seats in the [[2015 Polish parliamentary election|Polish parliamentary election]].<ref name=POL/> On 16 November, new Prime Minister [[Beata Szydło]] and her Cabinet took power.<ref name=slt>{{cite news|first=Vanessa|last=Gera|url=http://www.sltrib.com/home/3254986-155/new-polish-government-sparks-constitutional-crisis|title=New Polish government sparks constitutional crisis|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|date=2 December 2015|access-date=22 January 2015}}</ref>
+== Composition of the Court ==
+{| class="wikitable" align=right style="font-size:90%;line-height:15px;"
