+
+=== Partisan struggle ===
+The [[2015 Polish presidential election|Polish presidential election]], held in May 2015, gave candidate [[Andrzej Duda]], backed by [[Law and Justice]] (PiS), a surprise victory over incumbent President [[Bronisław Komorowski]], backed by the [[Civic Platform]] (PO), which was the then-[[Cabinet of Ewa Kopacz|government]]'s major party. 
+
+President-elect Duda was set to take office in August 2015. Coincidentally, a [[2015 Polish parliamentary election|parliamentary election]] was also due to be held in October. Opinion polls were now showing that PO was likely to lose to PiS.<ref name=fakt>{{cite web|url=http://www.fakt.pl/politycy/awantura-o-trybunal-konstytucyjny,artykuly,593265.html|title=Awantura o Trybunał Konstytucyjny|date=2015-11-26|work=Fakt.pl}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://polska.newsweek.pl/ustawa-pis-o-trybunale-konstytucyjnym-zaskarzona-do-trybunalu-konstytucyjnego,artykuly,374563,1.html|title=Ustawa PiS o Trybunale Konstytucyjnym zaskarżona do Trybunału Konstytucyjnego|work=Newsweek.pl|date=2015-11-23|language=pl|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151226170346/http://polska.newsweek.pl/ustawa-pis-o-trybunale-konstytucyjnym-zaskarzona-do-trybunalu-konstytucyjnego,artykuly,374563,1.html|archive-date=2015-12-26}}</ref>, meaning PO could lose both government and Presidency to PiS, within five months. 
+
+Judges of the [[Constitutional Tribunal (Poland)|Constitutional Tribunal]] are nominated by the [[Sejm|Lower House]], meaning that the partisan influence of the judicial branch was also in play. At the start of the events, 9 of the 15 members had been nominated by PO and its allies during their two terms in government ([[Cabinet of Donald Tusk|Tusk Cabinet]]), while the remaining 6 had been nominated in 2006 and 2007 by PiS and its allies ([[Cabinet of Jarosław Kaczyński|Kaczyński Cabinet]]), and they were the most senior: five of them were due to be replaced in late 2015 (see table).
+
+The Constitution mandates that judges are "chosen individually by the Sejm for a term of office of 9 years" (Article 194)<ref name="pl_konst"/>, but it does not specify what happens when a seat is vacant when the Sejm is itself in recess (during the campaign and before the oaths of office)
+
+The [[List of Sejm members (2011–15)|7th Sejm]]'s session lasted from 8 November 2011 to 11 November 2015, and its last meeting was held on 8–9 October 2015. The election of the [[List of Sejm members (2015–19)|8th Sejm]] was held on 25 October, and the oaths of office were taken starting 12 November.
+
+=== First nominations ===
+On 25 June 2015, the PO government and parliament adopted a new law regarding the constitutional court.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://fakty.interia.pl/raporty/raport-spor-wokol-tk/komentarze/news-spor-o-tk-katastrofa-europejskiego-projektu-integracyjnego,nId,2212494|title=Spór o TK "katastrofą europejskiego projektu integracyjnego"?|date=2 June 2016|work=Fakty.Interia.pl}}</ref> Later, the Constitutional Tribunal found this law to be partly unconstitutional.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://trybunal.gov.pl/postepowanie-i-orzeczenia/wyroki/art/8748-ustawa-o-trybunale-konstytucyjnym/|title=Trybunał Konstytucyjny: Ustawa o Trybunale Konstytucyjnym|website=trybunal.gov.pl}}</ref> It was signed by President [[Bronisław Komorowski]] on 21 July 2015 (about one month before end of his presidency).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.obserwatorkonstytucyjny.pl/trybunal/prezydent-podpisal-ustawe-o-trybunale-konstytucyjnym/|title=Prezydent podpisał ustawę o Trybunale Konstytucyjnym|work=Obserwator Konstytucyjny|date=2015-07-22}}</ref> 
+
+On 8 October 2015, 17 days before the elections, the outgoing Polish Parliament's last meeting was opened. The Sejm elected five new judges. Three of them replaced judges whose nine-year terms were to expire on 6 November (12 days after the elections, but 5 days before the end of the legislature), while two were to replace judges whose terms were due to expire in December.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rp.pl/Sedziowie-i-sady/311069942-Wygasaja-kadencje-trojga-sedziow-Trybunalu-Konstytucyjnego.html/|title=Wygasają kadencje trojga sędziów Trybunału Konstytucyjnego
+|language=pl|date=6 November 2015|work=[[Rp.pl]]}}</ref> 
+
+The judges were chosen on the basis of a law passed earlier in the summer, by the PO-controlled Sejm. 
+
+If the judges appointed by PO had taken their seats on the Tribunal, the result would have been that 14 out of 15 Constitutional Tribunal judges would have been selected by the Civic Platform.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polsatnews.pl/wiadomosc/2015-12-04/jaki-o-tk-14-z-15-sedziow-bylo-zwiazanych-z-po/|title=Jaki o TK: 14 z 15 sędziów było związanych z PO|date=2015-12-04|language=pl|work=Polsat News}}</ref> However, the new President of Poland, [[Andrzej Duda]], refused to swear in these judges<ref name="ppb">{{Cite web|url=https://polishpoliticsblog.wordpress.com/2015/12/31/who-is-winning-polands-constitutional-tribunal-war/|title=Who is winning Poland's 'constitutional tribunal war'?|date=31 December 2015|work=The Polish Politics Blog|first=Aleks|last=Szczerbiak}}</ref> stating that they had been chosen "in contravention of democratic principles".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.polsatnews.pl/wiadomosc/2015-11-16/po-apeluje-do-dudy-o-zaprzysiezenie-sedziow-trybunalu-konstytucyjnego/|title=PO apeluje do Dudy o zaprzysiężenie sędziów Trybunału Konstytucyjnego|work=Polsat News|language=pl|date=2015-11-16}}</ref> 
+
+On 25 October, the [[Law and Justice]] (Prawo i Sprawiedliwość, PiS) party won an unprecedented absolute majority of seats in the [[2015 Polish parliamentary election|Polish parliamentary election]].<ref name=POL/> On 16 November, new Prime Minister [[Beata Szydło]] and [[Cabinet of Beata Szydło|her Cabinet]] took office.<ref name=slt>{{cite news|first=Vanessa|last=Gera|url=http://www.sltrib.com/home/3254986-155/new-polish-government-sparks-constitutional-crisis|title=New Polish government sparks constitutional crisis|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|date=2 December 2015|access-date=22 January 2015}}</ref>
 
 ==Election of Constitutional Court judges==
 On 19 November 2015 the new Sejm passed an amendment to the existing law, and mandated the appointment of five new judges, set term limits for the president and vice president of the court, and stipulated term limits for two sitting judges. The president, [[Andrzej Duda]], signed the amendment on 20 November, but the law was challenged at the Constitutional Tribunal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polskieradio.pl/5/3/Artykul/1546853,Prezydent-Andrzej-Duda-podpisal-nowelizacje-ustawy-o-Trybunale-Konstytucyjnym-Wejdzie-w-zycie-5-grudnia |title=Prezydent Andrzej Duda podpisał nowelizację ustawy o Trybunale Konstytucyjnym. Wejdzie w życie 5 grudnia |website=PolskieRadio.pl |language=pl |date= 20 November 2015|accessdate=2016-01-14}}</ref>
 
 On 2 December, the Sejm elected five new judges to the 15-member tribunal, claiming it would prevent the previously appointed five from taking office;<ref name=slt/> these were sworn into office by President Duda in a closed ceremony held after midnight.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.politico.eu/article/law-vs-justice-poland-constitution-judges/|title=Poland's 'overnight court' breaks all the rules|last=Kisilowski|first=Maciej|date=2015-12-08|website=POLITICO|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/is-poland-taking-an-authoritarian-turn-its-new-president-explains/2016/03/24/f29e8830-f114-11e5-89c3-a647fcce95e0_story.html|title=Is Poland taking an authoritarian turn? Its new president explains.|last=Weymouth|first=Lally|date=2016-03-24|newspaper=The Washington Post|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286|access-date=2016-03-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160328015003/https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/is-poland-taking-an-authoritarian-turn-its-new-president-explains/2016/03/24/f29e8830-f114-11e5-89c3-a647fcce95e0_story.html|archive-date=2016-03-28|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wyborcza.pl/1,75478,19285794,nocne-sluby-sedziow-pis-u-prezydenta.html|title=Nocne śluby sędziów PiS u prezydenta|last=Wroński|first=Paweł|date=2015-12-03|website=wyborcza.pl|publisher=[[Gazeta Wyborcza]]|language=pl|trans-title=Night oaths of judges of PiS in President's place|access-date=2016-03-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wiadomosci.onet.pl/kraj/prezydent-andrzej-duda-odebral-slubowanie-od-sedziow-trybunalu-konstytucyjnego/yjvxss|title=Prezydent Andrzej Duda odebrał ślubowanie od sędziów Trybunału Konstytucyjnego|date=2015-12-03|website=Onet Wiadomości|publisher=[[Onet]]|language=pl-PL|trans-title=President Andrzej Duda takes the oath of Constitutional Court judges|access-date=2016-03-30}}</ref> PiS delegates argued that the previous appointments made by PO contradicted existing law and the Polish constitution.
 
 On 3 December, the Constitutional Court ruled that out of the five judges elected by PO, the election of three judges was valid, while the appointment of the other two breached the law. Again, President Duda refused to swear any of these judges into office.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wbj.pl/president-duda-wont-implement-constitutional-tribunal-ruling/| title=President Duda won't implement constitutional tribunal ruling|work=[[Warsaw Business Journal]]| date=8 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160105182813/http://wbj.pl/president-duda-wont-implement-constitutional-tribunal-ruling/|archive-date=2016-01-05|access-date=2015-12-27}}</ref> According to his spokesman, Duda refused to swear these three judges into office, because the number of Constitutional Court judges would then be unconstitutional.<ref name=POL>{{cite web|url= http://www.politico.eu/article/poland-constitution-crisis-kaczynski-duda/ |title=Poland's constitutional crisis goes international |first=Jan| last=Cienski| work=[[Politico]] |date=24 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/polands-ruling-party-seeks-to-replace-judges-who-have-final-say-on-laws-1448547025|title=Poland's Ruling Party Seeks to Replace Judges Who Have Final Say on Laws |work=The Wall Street Journal |first=Martin|last=Sobczyk|date=26 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/poland-constitution-idUSL8N13R2LD20151203 | title=Tussle over judges turns into constitutional crisis in Poland| publisher=Reuters| first1=Wiktor |last1=Szary |first2=Justyna |last2=Pawlak |date=3 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/europe/constitutional-crisis-in-poland-intensifies-over-judicial-jobs-1.2463635 |title=Constitutional crisis in Poland intensifies over judicial jobs |first=Derek| last=Scally| publisher=The Irish Times |date=12 December 2015}}</ref><ref name=WP>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/polands-new-right-wing-leaders-cross-a-line/2015/12/22/54d42ea4-a8d3-11e5-8058-480b572b4aae_story.html| title= Poland's new right-wing leaders have crossed a line| work=[[The Washington Post]]| date=22 December 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151223012811/https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/polands-new-right-wing-leaders-cross-a-line/2015/12/22/54d42ea4-a8d3-11e5-8058-480b572b4aae_story.html |archive-date=2015-12-23 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=DW>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/polish-government-policies-risk-civil-war-former-leader-walesa-says/a-18926068| title=Polish government policies risk 'civil war,' former leader Walesa says| publisher=[[Deutsche Welle]]| date=18 December 2015}}</ref>
 
 On 4 December, Law and Justice leader [[Jaroslaw Kaczyński]], who had called the Constitutional Court "the bastion of everything in Poland that is bad"<ref name=POL/> questioned the legitimacy of the Court's decision, because it was supposedly made by fewer judges than required by law. Kaczyński announced changes in the law regarding the Constitutional Court, but gave no details.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/battle-between-polish-government-and-top-court-escalates-1449859307 |title=Battle Between Polish Government and Top Court Escalates |work=The Wall Street Journal |first=Martin|last=Sobczyk|date=14 December 2015}}</ref>
 
 On 11 January 2016, the Constitutional Court rejected a complaint by Civic Platform questioning the appointment of the five new judges by the new Parliament.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polskatimes.pl/artykul/9278445,trybunal-konstytucyjny-umorzyl-skarge-na-uchwaly-sejmu,id,t.html |title=Trybunał Konstytucyjny umorzył skargę na uchwały Sejmu |website=Polska Times |date=11 January 2016 |first=Tomasz |last=Skłodowski  |accessdate=2016-01-14}}</ref> Three of the Court's judges dissented, including [[Andrzej Rzepliński]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://fakty.interia.pl/raporty/raport-spor-wokol-tk/newsy/news-trybunal-konstytucyjny-umorzyl-sprawe-dot-powolania-5-sedzio,nId,1952685 |title=Trybunał Konstytucyjny umorzył sprawę dot. powołania 5 sędziów |website=Fakty.interia.pl |date= |accessdate=2016-01-14}}</ref>
 
 ==Constitutional court law changes==
 [[File:Warszawa t konstytucyjny.jpg|thumb|The Constitutional Court in Warsaw]]
 On 22 December 2015, the Sejm passed a law which reorganised the Constitutional Court. The new law introduced a two-thirds majority<ref name=Guardian/> and the mandatory participation of at least 13, instead of 9, of the 15 judges.<ref name=Goe>{{cite web|url= https://www.reuters.com/article/poland-constitution-crisis-idUSL8N14B2UG20151222|title=Polish parliament passes contentious amendment to top court law| publisher=Reuters| first=Marcin |last=Goettig |date=22 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvn24.pl/wiadomosci-z-kraju,3/projekt-nowalizacji-ustawy-o-tk-w-sejmie,603330.html |title=Projekt nowalizacji ustawy o TK w Sejmie |website=Tvn24.pl |date=2015-12-16 |accessdate=2016-01-14}}</ref> Art. 190 (5) of the [[Constitution of Poland|Polish Constitution]] requires only the majority of votes.<ref name=NZZ>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzz.ch/international/europa/in-polen-waechst-der-widerstand-1.18666282|title=In Polen wächst der Widerstand|first=Meret|last=Baumann|publisher=[[Neue Zürcher Zeitung]] |date=21 December 2015|language=German}}</ref>

 {{Elections in Maine}}
 The '''2020 United States House of Representatives elections in Maine''' will be held on November 3, 2020, to elect the two [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representatives]] from the [[U.S. state|state]] of [[Maine]], one from each of the state's two [[Maine's congressional districts|congressional districts]]. The elections will coincide with the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 U.S. presidential election]], as well as [[United States House of Representatives elections, 2020|other elections]] to the House of Representatives, [[2020 United States Senate elections|elections]] to the [[United States Senate]] and various [[2020 United States elections#State elections|state]] and [[2020 United States elections#Local elections|local elections]].  The election will be conducted with [[ranked choice voting]], as per the result of [[2016 Maine Question 5|a referendum]] passed in 2016.
 
 Party Primaries were initially scheduled to take place on June 9, 2020.  They were rescheduled by Gov. [[Janet Mills]] to July 14, 2020, due to the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Maine|COVID-19 pandemic]].  Mills' executive order also expanded the ability to request absentee ballots, which may now be done up to and on election day.<ref>{{cite news|last=Andrews|first=Caitlin|date=December 18, 2019| url=https://bangordailynews.com/2020/04/10/politics/mills-officially-pushes-back-june-elections-to-july-14/ |title=Mills officially pushes back June elections to July 14|work=[[Bangor Daily News]]|accessdate=April 10, 2020}}</ref> Parties currently qualified to participate in the 2020 Primary Election are the Democratic Party, the Green Independent Party, and the Republican Party. Two candidates in District 1 and four candidates in district 2 filed petitions with the Secretary of State by March 16, 2020.<ref>{{cite web |title=Candidates Listing (xls) |url=https://www.maine.gov/sos/cec/elec/upcoming/candlistprim20.xlsx |website=www.maine.gov/sos/cec/elec/upcoming/ |accessdate=25 March 2020}}</ref> Non-party candidates can also file petitions to be included on the ballot by June 1, 2020.<ref>{{cite web |title=Candidate's Guide |url=https://www.maine.gov/sos/cec/elec/candidate/pdfs/2020guide.pdf |website=www.maine.gov/sos/cec/elec/ |accessdate=12 March 2020}}</ref>

edits.entity: Timeline of investigations into Donald Trump and Russia (July–December 2018)
edits.diff:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -60,31 +60,33 @@
 * '''July 23''':
 ** Senators [[Ron Wyden]], [[Robert Menendez]], and [[Sheldon Whitehouse]] send Treasury Secretary [[Steven Mnuchin]] a letter demanding the "production of any documents relevant to financial links between the NRA, its associated entities and Ms. Butina and any entities or individuals related to her." The letter is a follow-up to a similar letter Wyden sent Mnuchin in February.<ref>{{cite web|title=Who met with Maria Butina?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/right-turn/wp/2018/07/24/who-met-with-maria-butina/|website=[[The Washington Post]]|last=Rubin|first=Jennifer|date=July 24, 2018|access-date=July 26, 2018}}</ref>
 ** After initial denials,<ref name=RussianBillionaireBackedButinaWapo20180722>{{cite web|title=Russian billionaire with U.S. investments backed alleged agent Maria Butina, according to a person familiar with her Senate testimony|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/russian-billionaire-with-us-investments-backed-alleged-agent-maria-butina-according-to-a-person-familiar-with-her-senate-testimony/2018/07/22/dcaa7f48-8c58-11e8-a345-a1bf7847b375_story.html|website=[[The Washington Post]]|date=July 22, 2018|access-date=July 26, 2018|last=Helferman|first=Rosalind S.|last2=Crites|first2=Alice|last3=Hamburger|first3=Tom|last4=Jackman|first4=Tom|last5=Ferris-Rotman|first5=Amie|last6=Timberg|first6=Craig}}</ref> a spokesperson for Russian billionaire [[Konstantin Nikolaev]] confirms that Nikolaev funded "Right to Bear Arms" from 2012 to 2014.<ref name=AllegedSpyToldSenatePanelCNN20180723>{{cite news|title=Alleged spy told Senate panel about backing from Russian billionaire|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/07/22/politics/butina-konstantin-nikolaev/index.html|website=[[CNN]]|date=July 23, 2018|access-date=July 26, 2018|last1=Watkins|first1=Eli|last2=Herb|first2=Jeremy|last3=Kiley|first3=Sam|author-link3=Sam Kiley|last4=Burrows|first4=Emma}}</ref>
 ** Mueller's team interviews Sarah Sanders for the third of three times.{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-II|p=115}}
 * '''July 24''': Jury selection in the first Manafort trial begins.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-07-24/manafort-jury-pool-takes-first-step-to-hearing-high-profile-case |title=Manafort Jury Pool Takes First Step to Hearing High-Profile Case |author=David Voreacos |date=July 24, 2018 |website=Bloomberg.com |access-date=October 8, 2019}}</ref>
 * '''July 25''':
 ** Articles of impeachment against [[Rod Rosenstein]] are introduced in the House of Representatives by [[Freedom Caucus]] members [[Mark Meadows (North Carolina politician)|Mark Meadows]], [[Jim Jordan (American politician)|Jim Jordan]], and nine other cosponsors. The articles say Rosenstein should have recused himself from overseeing the Mueller investigation because he signed the [[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act|FISA warrant applications]] for surveilling Carter Page, and accuse Rosenstein of withholding documents from Congress.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://time.com/5349251/rod-rosenstein-gop-articles-of-impeachment |title=GOP Lawmakers File Articles of Impeachment Against Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein |date=July 25, 2018 |access-date=July 26, 2018 |last=Reilly|first=Katie |website=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=GOP lawmakers introduce articles of impeachment against Rosenstein|url=http://thehill.com/policy/national-security/398902-gop-lawmakers-introduce-impeachment-resolution-against-rosenstein|website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|date=July 25, 2018|access-date=July 26, 2018|last=Beavers|first=Olivia|last2=Lillis|first2=Mike}}</ref> House speaker [[Paul Ryan]] opposes the articles and convinces Meadows and Jordan not to try to force a floor vote.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/07/26/ryan-rejects-conservative-push-to-impeach-rosenstein-743487|title=Ryan rejects conservative push to impeach Rosenstein|website=[[Politico]]|date=July 26, 2018|access-date=July 26, 2018|last1=Cheney|first1=Kyle|last2=Bade|first2=Rachael|last3=Morin|first3=Rebecca}}</ref>
 ** Senator Chuck Grassley asks Gubarev's lawyers in a letter to provide a copy of the Steele [[Deposition (law)|deposition]] to the Senate Judiciary Committee. Steele was deposed in London on June 18 as part of Gubarev's libel suit against ''BuzzFeed''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.judiciary.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/2018-07-25%20CEG%20to%20Gurvits%20(Steele%20Deposition).pdf|title=Letter to Valentin Gurvatis, Esq.|date=July 25, 2018|access-date=September 6, 2018|last=Grassley|first=Charles|author-link=Charles Grassley|website=[[U.S. Senate]]}}</ref><ref name=ChristopherSteeleAgainEludesAtlantic20180906>{{cite web|title=Christopher Steele Again Eludes His Republican Pursuers|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2018/09/christopher-steele-again-eludes-his-republican-pursuers/569515/|website=[[The Atlantic]]|date=September 6, 2018|access-date=September 6, 2018|last=Bertrand|first=Natasha}}</ref>
 * '''July 26''':
 ** ''CNN'' reports that Cohen claims that Trump was informed by Donald Trump Jr. of the Russians' offer of dirt on Hillary Clinton in advance of [[Timeline of Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections#April–June 2016|the 2016 June 9 meeting]] with [[Veselnitskaya meeting|Veselnitskaya]], contradicting claims by Trump and Trump Jr. that Trump only learned of the meeting shortly before it was reported by the ''New York Times'' in July 2017.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sciutto |first1=Jim |last2=Bernstein |first2=Carl |last3=Cohen |first3=Marshall |title=Cohen claims Trump knew in advance of 2016 Trump Tower meeting |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/07/26/politics/michael-cohen-donald-trump-june-2016-meeting-knowledge/index.html |accessdate=2018-07-27 |work=CNN |date=2018-07-26}}</ref>
 ** The ''Wall Street Journal'' reports that longtime [[Trump Organization]] finance executive [[Allen Weisselberg]] has been subpoenaed to testify before a federal grand jury in Cohen's ongoing criminal investigation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-organization-finance-chief-called-to-testify-before-federal-grand-jury-1532622947|title=Trump Organization Finance Chief Called to Testify Before Federal Grand Jury|last=O’Brien|first=Rebecca Davis|date=2018-07-26|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-07-28|last2=Ballhaus|first2=Rebecca|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660|last3=Rothfeld|first3=Michael|last4=Berzon|first4=Alexandra}}</ref>
 ** ''The Daily Beast'' reports that Senator [[Claire McCaskill]]'s [[United States Senate election in Missouri, 2018|reelection campaign]] was targeted by [[Fancy Bear]] for a [[phishing attack]] in August 2017. This is the first [[2018 United States elections|2018 midterm campaign]] publicly identified as a Russian hacking target.<ref>{{cite web|title=Russian Hackers' New Target: a Vulnerable Democratic Senator|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/russian-hackers-new-target-a-vulnerable-democratic-senator|website=[[Daily Beast]]|date=July 26, 2018|access-date=July 26, 2018|last1=Desiderio|first1=Andrew|last2=Poulsen|first2=Kevin|author-link2=Kevin Poulsen}}</ref>
 ** ''The New York Times'' reports that Mueller is examining Trump's tweets about Sessions and Comey as part of his search for possible evidence of obstruction of justice.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mueller Examining Trump's Tweets in Wide-Ranging Obstruction Inquiry|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/26/us/politics/trump-tweets-mueller-obstruction.html|website=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 26, 2018|access-date=January 7, 2019|last1=Schmidt|first1=Michael S.|author-link1=Michael S. Schmidt|last2=Haberman|first2=Maggie|author-link2=Maggie Haberman}}</ref>
 [[File:Disinformation and 'fake news' interim report.pdf|thumb|"Disinformation and ‘fake news’: Interim Report" by the Digital, Culture, Media and Sports Committee]]
 * '''July 28''': The U.K. [[Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee]] releases its interim report on disinformation and "fake news". The report's topics include the activities of Cambridge Analytica, SCL, Facebook, Russia, and the Leave.EU campaign.<ref>{{cite web|title='Plucky little panel' that found the truth about fake news, Facebook and Brexit|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/jul/28/dcms-committee-report-finds-truth-fake-news-facebook-brexit|website=[[The Guardian]]|date=July 28, 2018|access-date=August 12, 2018|last=Cadwalladr|first=Carole}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Disinformation and 'fake news': Interim Report|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201719/cmselect/cmcumeds/363/36302.htm|website=parliament.uk|date=July 29, 2018|access-date=August 12, 2018|author=Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee|author-link=Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee}}</ref>
-* '''July 30''': Devin Nunes tells the audience at a fundraiser for Representative [[Cathy McMorris Rodgers]] that the Rosenstein [[Impeachment in the United States|impeachment]] effort is on hold until after [[Brett Kavanaugh Supreme Court nomination|Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh]] is [[Appointment and confirmation to the Supreme Court of the United States|voted on by the Senate]]. He says that if the House votes to impeach Rosenstein, the Senate will have to drop everything, including consideration of Kavanaugh, until they vote on the impeachment, and putting Kavanaugh on the Supreme Court is more important than removing Rosenstein. Nunes also tells the audience that it is illegal for a candidate to use stolen emails in their campaign. The fundraiser is a private event that excludes the press, but an attendee secretly records Nunes's comments and gives the recording to MSNBC's ''[[The Rachel Maddow Show]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Secret recording shows GOP's Nunes saying Rosenstein impeachment would delay Supreme Court pick|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/secret-recording-shows-gop-s-nunes-saying-rosenstein-impeachment-would-n899031|website=[[NBC News]]|date=August 8, 2018|access-date=August 9, 2018|last=Helsel|first=Phil}}</ref>
+* '''July 30''':
+** Devin Nunes tells the audience at a fundraiser for Representative [[Cathy McMorris Rodgers]] that the Rosenstein [[Impeachment in the United States|impeachment]] effort is on hold until after [[Brett Kavanaugh Supreme Court nomination|Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh]] is [[Appointment and confirmation to the Supreme Court of the United States|voted on by the Senate]]. He says that if the House votes to impeach Rosenstein, the Senate will have to drop everything, including consideration of Kavanaugh, until they vote on the impeachment, and putting Kavanaugh on the Supreme Court is more important than removing Rosenstein. Nunes also tells the audience that it is illegal for a candidate to use stolen emails in their campaign. The fundraiser is a private event that excludes the press, but an attendee secretly records Nunes's comments and gives the recording to MSNBC's ''[[The Rachel Maddow Show]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Secret recording shows GOP's Nunes saying Rosenstein impeachment would delay Supreme Court pick|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/secret-recording-shows-gop-s-nunes-saying-rosenstein-impeachment-would-n899031|website=[[NBC News]]|date=August 8, 2018|access-date=August 9, 2018|last=Helsel|first=Phil}}</ref>
+** The Senated Intelligence Committee interviews someone whose name is redacted from volume 5 of their report on Russian interference.{{r|SenatIntelCommitReportVol5|p=490}}
 * '''July 31''':
 ** Paul Manafort's trial for bank and tax fraud charges starts in [[Alexandria, Virginia]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Day one of the Paul Manafort trial: Jury selection, first witness called and a $15,000 ostrich jacket|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/local/wp/2018/07/31/paul-manafort-trial-live-coverage/|website=[[The Washington Post]]|date=July 31, 2018|access-date=July 31, 2018|last1=Weiner|first1=Rachel|last2=Jouvenal|first2=Justin|last3=Helderman|first3=Rosalind S.|last4=Zapotosky|first4=Matt}}</ref>
 ** Facebook announces they have shut down eight pages, 17 profiles, and seven Instagram accounts related to "bad actors" identified recently with activity profiles similar to the IRA. The company says it doesn't have enough information to attribute the accounts, groups, and events to the IRA, but that a known IRA account was briefly an administrator of the "Resisters" group.<ref>{{cite web|title=Removing Bad Actors on Facebook|url=https://newsroom.fb.com/news/2018/07/removing-bad-actors-on-facebook/|publisher=Facebook|date=July 31, 2018|access-date=July 31, 2018|last1=Gleicher|first1=Nathaniel|last2=Stamos|first2=Alex|author-link2=Alex Stamos}}</ref> The "Resisters" group was the first organizer on Facebook of the upcoming "No Unite The Right 2 – DC" protest scheduled in Washington, D.C., for August 10. Some of the event's other organizers insist they started organizing before "Resisters" created the event's Facebook page.<ref>{{cite news|title=Facebook Identifies an Active Political Influence Campaign Using Fake Accounts|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/31/us/politics/facebook-political-campaign-midterms.html|website=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 31, 2018|access-date=July 31, 2018|last1=Fandos|first1=Nicholas|last2=Roose|first2=Kevin|last3=Savage|first3=Charlie|last4=Frenkel|first4=Sheera|author-link2=Kevin Roose|author-link3=Charlie Savage}}</ref>
 ** Andrew Miller, a former associate of Roger Stone, loses his attempt to challenge a subpoena from Mueller by asserting Mueller's appointment was unconstitutional. U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia Chief Judge [[Beryl A. Howell]] rules Mueller's appointment was constitutional and that the subpoena is therefore valid and Miller must appear "at the earliest date available to the grand jury, and to complete production of the subpoenaed records promptly."<ref>{{cite news|title=Judge orders Stone associate to testify before Mueller grand jury|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/08/02/politics/mueller-subpoena-grand-jury/index.html|website=[[CNN]]|date=August 2, 2018|access-date=August 2, 2018|last1=Polantz|first1=Katelyn|last2=Herb|first2=Jeremy|last3=Murray|first3=Sara}}</ref>
 
 ===August===
 {{see|Trials of Paul Manafort}}
 * '''August 1''':
 ** ''CNN'' reports that over the past few months Mueller referred three people and their firms to the [[U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York|U.S. Attorney for the SDNY]] for further investigation into [[Foreign Agents Registration Act|failing to register]] as lobbyists for a foreign government. The referrals include [[Tony Podesta]], former U.S. Representative [[Vin Weber]] (MN-R), and former Obama White House counsel [[Greg Craig]]. Manafort paid all three, and their firms, through the [[European Centre for a Modern Ukraine]] to lobby on behalf of the [[Ukrainian government]]. Craig worked at the same firm as [[Alex van der Zwaan]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Exclusive: Mueller refers foreign agent inquiries to New York prosecutors|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/07/31/politics/mueller-investigation-foreign-agent-referrals-new-york/index.html|website=[[CNN]]|date=August 1, 2018|access-date=August 1, 2018|last=Orden|first=Erica}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=New York prosecutors eye illicit foreign lobbying|url=https://www.apnews.com/21afe1c9d2cb416db84f9c508d9649ca|website=[[Associated Press]]|date=August 1, 2018|access-date=December 6, 2018|last1=Hays|first1=Tom|last2=Horwitz|first2=Jeff}}</ref>
 ** Trump makes a series of tweets related to Manafort,<ref>{{cite web|title=Trump calls Manafort prosecution 'a hoax,' says Sessions should stop Mueller investigation 'right now'|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-calls-manafort-prosecution-a-hoax-says-sessions-should-stop-mueller-investigation/2018/08/01/8deb579e-958e-11e8-810c-5fa705927d54_story.html|website=[[The Washington Post]]|date=August 1, 2018|access-date=August 1, 2018|last1=Wagner|first1=John|last2=Barrett|first2=Devlin|last3=Leonnig|first3=Carol D.|author-link=Carol D. Leonnig|last4=DeBonis|first4=Mike|last5=Kim|first5=Seung Min|last6=Werner|first6=Erica}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Trump claims Manafort case has 'nothing to do with collusion' |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/08/01/trump-manafort-trail-755442 |website=[[Politico]] |date=August 1, 2018 |access-date=November 15, 2019 |last=Nelson |first=Louis}}</ref>{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-II|p=125}} including calling for Sessions to end the Mueller investigation immediately<ref>{{cite tweet|title=..This is a terrible situation and Attorney General Jeff Sessions should stop this Rigged Witch Hunt right now, before it continues to stain our country any further. Bob Mueller is totally conflicted, and his 17 Angry Democrats that are doing his dirty work are a disgrace to USA!|number=1024646945640525826|user=realDonaldTrump|author=Donald J. Trump|author-link=Donald Trump|date=August 1, 2018|access-date=August 1, 2018}}</ref> and complaining that Manafort is being treated worse than [[Al Capone]].<ref>{{Cite tweet |title=Looking back on history, who was treated worse, Alfonse Capone, legendary mob boss, killer and "Public Enemy Number One," or Paul Manafort, political operative & Reagan/Dole darling, now serving solitary confinement - although convicted of nothing? Where is the Russian Collusion? |number=1024680095343108097 |date=August 1, 2018 |access-date=November 20, 2019 |user=realDonaldTrump |authorlink=Donald Trump |author=Donald J. Trump}}</ref> His tweets are widely reported in the press, and, in 2019, the [[Mueller Report]] cites them as evidence of attempted [[jury tampering]].{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-II|pp=125, 131–132}}
 ** The Senate votes to allow the Senate Intelligence Committee to share the transcript of Butina's testimony before the committee with the prosecutorial and defense teams in her criminal case.<ref>{{cite web|title=Senate OKs sharing Intel panel documents on alleged Russian agent with DOJ, her lawyers|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/senate/399997-senate-oks-sharing-intel-panel-documents-on-alleged-russian-agent-with-doj|website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|date=August 1, 2018|access-date=August 1, 2018|last1=Carney|first=Jordain}}</ref>
 ** Mueller's team interviews Kristin M. Davis.<ref>{{cite web|title='Manhattan Madam' Kristin Davis met with Special Counsel Mueller's team|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/crime-courts/manhattan-madam-kristin-davis-met-special-counsel-mueller-s-team-n897466|website=[[NBC News]]|date=August 3, 2018|access-date=August 3, 2018|last1=Schecter|first1=Anna|last2=Winter|first2=Tom |last3=Welker|first3=Kristen|author-link3=Kristen Welker|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Infamous 'Manhattan Madam' Kristin Davis interviewed by Mueller's team of investigators|url=https://www.latimes.com/la-na-pol-manhattan-madam-mueller-20180803-story.html|website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=August 3, 2018|access-date=August 5, 2018|last=Slattery|first=Denis |df=mdy-all}}</ref>
 ** The Senate Intelligence Committee sends Assange an invitation to testify before the committee.<ref>{{cite web|title=Senate Asks Julian Assange to Testify in Russia Investigation|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/senate-asks-julian-assange-to-testify-in-russia-investigation|website=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=August 8, 2018|access-date=January 5, 2019|last=Ackerman|first=Spencer|author-link=Spencer Ackerman}}</ref>
 * '''August 2''':
 ** Sanders, Bolton, Coats, Nielsen, Wray, and Nakasone hold a White House news briefing that confirms that Russia interfered in US elections and that the threat is real.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/us-politics/la-na-pol-trump-election-20180802-story.html |title=On the defensive, White House showcases top officials to attest to its efforts to bolster election security |author=Eli Stokols |date=August 2, 2018 |newspaper=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]] |access-date=August 8, 2018}}</ref>

@@ -89,30 +89,31 @@
 ** Mueller's team interviews Kristin M. Davis.<ref>{{cite web|title='Manhattan Madam' Kristin Davis met with Special Counsel Mueller's team|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/crime-courts/manhattan-madam-kristin-davis-met-special-counsel-mueller-s-team-n897466|website=[[NBC News]]|date=August 3, 2018|access-date=August 3, 2018|last1=Schecter|first1=Anna|last2=Winter|first2=Tom |last3=Welker|first3=Kristen|author-link3=Kristen Welker|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Infamous 'Manhattan Madam' Kristin Davis interviewed by Mueller's team of investigators|url=https://www.latimes.com/la-na-pol-manhattan-madam-mueller-20180803-story.html|website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=August 3, 2018|access-date=August 5, 2018|last=Slattery|first=Denis |df=mdy-all}}</ref>
 ** The Senate Intelligence Committee sends Assange an invitation to testify before the committee.<ref>{{cite web|title=Senate Asks Julian Assange to Testify in Russia Investigation|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/senate-asks-julian-assange-to-testify-in-russia-investigation|website=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=August 8, 2018|access-date=January 5, 2019|last=Ackerman|first=Spencer|author-link=Spencer Ackerman}}</ref>
 * '''August 2''':
 ** Sanders, Bolton, Coats, Nielsen, Wray, and Nakasone hold a White House news briefing that confirms that Russia interfered in US elections and that the threat is real.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/us-politics/la-na-pol-trump-election-20180802-story.html |title=On the defensive, White House showcases top officials to attest to its efforts to bolster election security |author=Eli Stokols |date=August 2, 2018 |newspaper=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]] |access-date=August 8, 2018}}</ref>
 ** Mueller's team interviews [[Petr Aven]].{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-I|pp=146–147, 163, 165–166}}
 ** Mueller's team interviews Kelly.{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-II|p=91, 114-118}}
 * '''August 3''': Lawyers for [[Concord Management and Consulting]] ask District Court Judge [[Dabney Friedrich]] to declare Mueller's appointment invalid. When Friedrich says she should follow Supreme Court [[precedent]], lawyer James Martin asks her to "be brave" and ignore it.<ref>{{cite web|title='Be brave': Russian firm urges judge to nix Mueller indictment|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/08/03/russian-company-mueller-probe-be-brave-761787|website=[[Politico]]|date=August 3, 2018|access-date=August 12, 2018|last=Cheney|first=Kyle}}</ref>
 * '''August 5''': In a tweet, Trump admits publicly for the first time that the June 2016 Trump Tower meeting was about getting dirt on Hillary Clinton.<ref>{{cite web |title=Trump just made 2 problematic admissions about the Trump Tower meeting |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2018/08/05/trump-just-made-2-problematic-admissions-about-the-trump-tower-meeting |website=[[The Washington Post]] |date=August 5, 2018 |access-date=August 5, 2018 |last=Blake|first=Aaron}}</ref><ref>{{cite tweet|title=Fake News reporting, a complete fabrication, that I am concerned about the meeting my wonderful son, Donald, had in Trump Tower. This was a meeting to get information on an opponent, totally legal and done all the time in politics – and it went nowhere. I did not know about it!|date=August 5, 2018|access-date=August 5, 2018|user=realDonaldTrump|author=Donald J. Trump|author-link=Donald Trump|number=1026084333315153924}}</ref>
 * '''August 6''': ''Politico'' reports that almost all of the money contributed to The Patriot Legal Expense Fund Trust, the legal fund established in February to help Trump campaign, transition, and White House aides, came from four donors closely linked to Trump.<ref name=TrumpAlliesBackFundPolitico20180906>{{cite web|title=Trump allies back fund for aides' legal defense in Mueller probe|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/08/06/trump-allies-legal-defense-fund-russia-probe-764851|website=[[Politico]]|date=August 6, 2018|access-date=August 12, 2018|last1=Cheney|first1=Kyle|last2=Woellert|first2=Lorraine}}</ref>
 * '''August 7''':
 ** Senator [[Elizabeth Warren]] sends Secretary of Commerce [[Wilbur Ross]] a letter inquiring about the details of the exemption to [[aluminum]] tariffs granted to Rusal America Corporation on July 19. Rusal America Corporation is a subsidiary of [[Rusal]], which is under sanctions for its financial ties to Deripaska.<ref name=LetterRossWarren20180807 /><ref name=HowABlacklistedNYT20180809 /><ref name=SenWarrenAsksForVox20180829 />
 ** Mueller's team interviews Cohen for the first time.{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-I|pp=72–73, 115}}{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-II|pp=17–18, 134–135}}
 * '''August 8''':
 ** ''The Hill'' reports the White House is drafting an [[executive order]] allowing the president to impose sanctions on "10 of the 30 largest businesses" in a country whose nationals are found to have meddled in U.S. elections.<ref>{{cite web|title=White House working on executive order to punish election interference: report|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/401012-white-house-working-on-executive-order-to-allow-trump-to-punish|website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|date=August 8, 2018|access-date=August 12, 2018|last=Samuels|first=Brett}}</ref>
 ** The [[Commerce Department]] reverses its decision to grant an [[Trump tariffs#Steel and aluminum|aluminum tariffs]] exemption to Rusal America Corporation a day after Senator Warren inquired about the exemption. The department claims the original grant was a clerical error.<ref name=HowABlacklistedNYT20180809 /><ref name=SenWarrenAsksForVox20180829 /><ref>{{cite web|title=Warren Investigation Forces Trump Administration to Reverse Tariff Exemption for U.S. Subsidiary of Sanctioned Russian Company|url=https://www.warren.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/warren-investigation-forces-trump-administration-to-reverse-tariff-exemption-for-us-subsidiary-of-sanctioned-russian-company-|website=[[U.S. Senate]]|date=August 9, 2018|access-date=August 30, 2018}}</ref>
+** The Senate Intelligence Committee interviews [[Leon Black]].{{r|SenatIntelCommitReportVol5|p=642}}
 * '''August 9''':
 ** ''The Hill'' reports House Judiciary Committee Chairman [[Bob Goodlatte]] is preparing subpoenas for people connected to the Steele dossier, including Nellie and [[Bruce Ohr]], Glenn Simpson, and former FBI and DOJ officials [[James A. Baker (government attorney)|Jim Baker]], Sally Moyer, Jonathan Moffa, and George Toscas.<ref>{{cite web|title=GOP chairman readies Steele dossier subpoenas|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/house/401193-gop-chairman-set-to-issue-steele-dossier-subpoenas|website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|date=August 9, 2018|access-date=August 12, 2018|last=Beavers|first=Olivia}}</ref>
 ** ''The Daily Beast'' reports that Igor Pisarky, the founder and chairman of the Russian public relations firm R.I.M. Porter Novelli, was Butina's point of contact for the funding she received from billionaire [[Konstantin Nikolaev]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/exclusive-this-is-accused-russian-spy-maria-butinas-secret-money-man-in-moscow-sources-say|title=Exclusive: This Is Accused Russian Spy Maria Butina's Secret Money Man in Moscow, Sources Say|website=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=August 9, 2018|access-date=December 28, 2018|last1=Woodruff|first1=Betsy|last2=Quinn|first2=Allison|last3=Nemtsova|first3=Anna}}</ref>
 * '''August 10''':
 ** Judge Howell rules Andrew Miller is in [[contempt of court]] for refusing to appear before one of Mueller's grand juries. Howell [[Stay of proceedings|stays]] the contempt order to allow an appeal to proceed. After the closed hearing, Miller's lawyer Paul Kamenar says he asked the court for the contempt ruling so that he can file an appeal challenging the legality of the Mueller investigation.<ref name=JudgeHoldsRogerStoneWapo20180810>{{cite web|title=Judge holds Roger Stone associate in contempt for refusing to testify in Russia investigation|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/witness-in-mueller-probe-refuses-to-appear-before-grand-jury/2018/08/10/73e27130-9ca4-11e8-843b-36e177f3081c_story.html|website=[[The Washington Post]]|date=August 10, 2018|access-date=August 10, 2018|last1=Hsu|first1=Spencer S.|last2=Barrett|first2=Devlin}}</ref> Miller's challenge is being funded by the [[National Legal and Policy Center]] because, they say, they share his concerns about the constitutionality of the Mueller investigation.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Real Reason Roger Stone Crony Andrew Miller Ducked Robert Mueller's Subpoena? To Challenge the Special Counsel's Legitimacy.|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/the-real-reason-roger-stone-crony-andrew-miller-ducked-robert-muellers-subpoena-to-challenge-the-special-counsels-legitimacy|website=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=August 10, 2018|access-date=December 27, 2018|last=Woodruff|first=Betsy}}</ref>
 ** Rick Davis appears before one of Mueller's grand juries.<ref name=LifelongPoliticalScrapperNYT20180810>{{cite news|title=A Lifelong Political Scrapper, Roger Stone Is Fighting for His Own Legal Future|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/10/us/politics/roger-stone-russia-investigation.html|website=[[The New York Times]]|date=August 10, 2018|access-date=August 11, 2018|last1=Feuer|first1=Alan|last2=Haberman|first2=Maggie|author-link2=Maggie Haberman}}</ref>
 ** [[Randy Credico]]'s lawyer says Credico is scheduled to appear before Mueller's grand jury on September 7.<ref name=LifelongPoliticalScrapperNYT20180810 />
 ** DNC lawyers use Twitter to serve WikiLeaks with the [[Democratic National Committee v. Russian Federation|lawsuit it filed in April]].<ref>{{cite web|title=WikiLeaks hit with DNC lawsuit – over Twitter|url=http://thehill.com/policy/technology/401324-wikileaks-hit-with-dnc-lawsuit-over-twitter|website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|date=August 10, 2018|access-date=August 12, 2018|last=Bowden|first=John}}</ref>
 ** The Senate Intelligence Committee interviews [[Michael Glassner]].{{r|SenatIntelCommitReportVol5|p=533}}
 * '''August 13''':
 ** FBI Deputy Director [[David Bowdich]] overrules the recommendation of the [[Office of Professional Responsibility]] (OPR) and fires FBI agent [[Peter Strzok]] for violating bureau policies. The OPR had recommended demotion and a 60-day suspension. The firing contradicts FBI Director [[Christopher A. Wray|Christopher Wray]]'s assurances to Congress that the FBI would follow its regular processes.<ref>{{cite news|title=F.B.I. Agent Peter Strzok, Who Criticized Trump in Texts, Is Fired|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/13/us/politics/peter-strzok-fired-fbi.html|website=[[The New York Times]]|date=August 13, 2018|access-date=August 13, 2018|last1=Goldman|first1=Adam|last2=Schmidt|first2=Michael S.|author-link1=Adam Goldman|author-link2=Michael S. Schmidt}}</ref> Trump heralds the firing on Twitter.<ref>{{cite tweet|number=1029036065158557701|author=Donald J. Trump|author-link=Donald Trump|user=realDonaldTrump|date=August 13, 2018|access-date=August 13, 2018|title=Agent Peter Strzok was just fired from the FBI – finally. The list of bad players in the FBI & DOJ gets longer & longer. Based on the fact that Strzok was in charge of the Witch Hunt, will it be dropped? It is a total Hoax. No Collusion, No Obstruction - I just fight back!}}</ref><ref>{{cite tweet|number=1029037282676957185|author=Donald J. Trump|author-link=Donald Trump|user=realDonaldTrump|date=August 13, 2018|access-date=August 13, 2018|title=Just fired Agent Strzok, formerly of the FBI, was in charge of the Crooked Hillary Clinton sham investigation. It was a total fraud on the American public and should be properly redone!}}</ref>
 ** Judge [[Dabney Friedrich|Friedrich]] rules that Mueller's appointment was constitutional. The ruling is in response to a motion lawyers for [[Concord Management and Consulting]] made on August 3 to dismiss Mueller's charges against the company.<ref>{{cite web|title=US judge rejects Russian company's bid to dismiss Mueller charges|url=http://thehill.com/policy/national-security/401543-us-judge-rejects-russian-companys-bid-to-dismiss-mueller-charges|website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|date=August 13, 2018|access-date=August 13, 2018|last=Chalfant|first=Morgan}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=United States of America v. Concord Management & Consulting LLC, Memorandum Opinion|url=https://assets.documentcloud.org/documents/4754543/Memorandum-Opinion.pdf|via=[[DocumentCloud]]|date=August 13, 2018|access-date=August 13, 2018|last=Friedrich|first=Dabney L.|author-link=Dabney L. Friedrich}}</ref>
 * '''August 15''': Trump strips former CIA director [[John O. Brennan]] of his security clearance.<ref name=WhiteHouseDraftsMoreWapo20180817>{{cite web|title=White House drafts more clearance cancellations demanded by Trump|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/former-intelligence-officials-rebuke-trump-for-pulling-brennans-security-clearance/2018/08/17/ea8382f2-a20d-11e8-8e87-c869fe70a721_story.html|website=[[The Washington Post]]|date=August 17, 2018|access-date=August 17, 2018|last1=DeYoung|first1=Karen|last2=Dawsey|first2=Josh|last3=Wagner|first3=John|last4=Harris|first4=Shane|author-link1=Karen DeYoung|author-link4=Shane Harris}}</ref>
 * '''August 16''':
 ** In an interview with the ''Wall Street Journal'', Trump connects his revoking of John Brennan's security clearance to the Russia investigation.<ref name=WhiteHouseDraftsMoreWapo20180817 />

@@ -60,31 +60,33 @@
 ** ''[[Bloomberg News]]'' reports that Mueller is investigating Trump's business transactions.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/07/20/trump-set-a-red-line-for-robert-mueller-and-now-mueller-has-reportedly-crossed-it/ |title=Trump set a red line for Robert Mueller. And now Mueller has reportedly crossed it. |date=July 20, 2017 |work=[[The Washington Post]]|last=Blake|first=Aaron}}</ref>
 ** ''The Washington Post'' reports Trump is asking his attorneys about his ability to pardon himself and other key aides and family members.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trumps-lawyers-seek-to-undercut-muellers-russia-investigation/2017/07/20/232ebf2c-6d71-11e7-b9e2-2056e768a7e5_story.html |title=Trump team seeks to control, block Mueller's Russia investigation |last4=Hamburger |first4=Tom |work=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=July 24, 2018|last1=Leonnig|first1=Carol D.|author-link1=Carol D. Leonnig|last2=Parker|first2=Ashley|author-link2=Ashley Parker|first3=Ashley|last3=Parker}}</ref>
 ** Paul Behrends is removed from his position as staff director for a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee chaired by Rohrabacher. The move comes after news reports about Behrends's and Rohrbacher's [[Timeline of Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections#April–June 2016|trip to Moscow in April 2016]].<ref name=BehrendsFiredTheAlantic20170720>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/07/top-rohrabacher-aide-fired-after-russia-revelations/534288/|title=A Top Rohrabacher Aide Is Ousted After Russia Revelations|website=[[The Atlantic]]|date=July 20, 2017|access-date=July 12, 2018|last=Gray|first=Rosie}}</ref>
 ** Senator [[Chuck Grassley]] sends the Justice Department a letter calling for an investigation into alleged coordination between Chalupa and the Ukrainian government to interfere in the 2016 election. He cites the [[Timeline of post-election transition following Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections#20170111|January 11]] ''Politico'' report on alleged Ukrainian interference as evidence.<ref name="TheGOPTheoryThatWaPo-20191008">{{Cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2019/10/08/gop-theory-that-ukraine-set-up-trump/ |title=The GOP theory that Ukraine 'set up' Trump |last=Kessler |first=Glenn |authorlink=Glenn Kessler (journalist) |date=October 8, 2019 |website=[[The Washington Post]] |access-date=October 14, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.grassley.senate.gov/news/news-releases/grassley-raises-further-concerns-over-foreign-agent-registration |title=Grassley Raises Further Concerns over Foreign Agent Registration |last=Grassley |first=Charles E. |authorlink=Charles Grassley |date=September 30, 2017 |website=[[United States Senate]] |access-date=October 15, 2019}}</ref>
 ** Mueller's team interviews Yates's top deputy Matthew S. Axelrod.{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-II|p=30}}<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/05/business/dealbook/matthew-axelrod-justice-dept-linklaters-law-firm.html |title=Former Deputy at the Justice Dept. Joins Linklaters Law Firm |last=Olson |first=Elizabeth |date=March 5, 2017 |website=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=October 22, 2019}}</ref>
 * '''July 21''':
 ** ''The Washington Post'' reports Sessions discussed Trump campaign-related matters with Kislyak.<ref name=SessionsKislyakDiscussionsWapo20170721>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/sessions-discussed-trump-campaign-related-matters-with-russian-ambassador-us-intelligence-intercepts-show/2017/07/21/3e704692-6e44-11e7-9c15-177740635e83_story.html |title=Sessions discussed Trump campaign-related matters with Russian ambassador, U.S. intelligence intercepts show |last=Nakashima |first=Ellen |last2=Miller |first2=Greg |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=July 21, 2017 |access-date=July 21, 2017}}</ref>
 ** The Senate Judiciary Committee requests all communications between Trump Jr. and a group of people, including Jill Stein. She publicly describes the notion that she communicated with Trump Jr. as "an obvious smear designed to generate a fake news feeding frenzy".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://thehill.com/policy/national-security/343292-jill-stein-looped-into-widening-investigation-of-russia-and-trump-jr |title=Jill Stein looped into widening investigation of Russia and Trump Jr. connections |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |date=July 22, 2017|last=Cohn|first=Alicia}}</ref>
 ** [[John M. Dowd]] replaces Marc Kasowitz at the head of Trump's legal team, following personal threats made by Kasowitz.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/trump-lawyer-marc-kasowitz-reduced-role-article-1.3343960 |title=Trump lawyer Marc Kasowitz taking reduced White House role amid legal team shake up |newspaper=[[New York Daily News]] |date=July 21, 2017|last=Cullen|first=Terence}}</ref> Legal spokesman Mark Corallo resigns.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-40678397 |title=Trump legal team spokesman Mark Corallo resigns amid 'shake-up' |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=July 21, 2017}}</ref> [[Michael Wolff (journalist)|Michael Wolff]] later reports that Corallo had been instructed not to speak to the press or to answer his telephone, and that he privately stated his belief that the Air Force One meeting on July 8, 2017 represented likely [[obstruction of justice]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/01/03/the-wildest-claims-about-trump-from-michael-wolffs-fire-and-fury.html |title=10 wild claims about Trump's White House from the upcoming book 'Fire and Fury' |date=January 3, 2018 |publisher=CNBC|last=Wilkie|first=Christina}}</ref>
 ** A complaint is filed against [[United States House of Representatives|Representative]] [[Dana Rohrabacher]] with the [[Office of Foreign Assets Control]] alleging violations of [[Magnitsky Act]] sanctions.<ref name=RohrabacherComplaint20170721>{{cite web|title=Notice of Apparent Violations of Magnitsky Act Sanctions by U.S. Persons Providing Services to SDN Viktor Grin|url=http://russian-untouchables.com/docs/OFAC%20complaint%20filed_Redacted.pdf|date=July 21, 2017|author=Hermitage Capital Management|publisher=Russian Untouchables|access-date=March 19, 2018|author-link=Hermitage Capital Management}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Rep. Dana Rohrabacher accused of violating Russian sanctions by backer of Russian sanctions law|url=https://www.latimes.com/politics/essential/la-pol-ca-essential-politics-updates-complaint-filed-over-rohrabacher-s-2016-1501179754-htmlstory.html|website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=July 27, 2017|access-date=March 19, 2018|last=Wire|first=Sarah D.}}</ref> In April 2016, Rohrabacher received a document directly from [[Prosecutor General of Russia|Russian Deputy Prosecutor]] Viktor Grin, an individual under sanctions, and used it in attempts to weaken the [[Magnitsky Act]].<ref name="RohrabacherDirectionFromMoscowDB20170719">{{cite web|title=GOP Lawmaker Got Direction From Moscow, Took It Back to D.C.|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/gop-lawmaker-got-direction-from-moscow-took-it-back-to-dc|website=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=July 19, 2017|access-date=March 19, 2018|last=Hines|first=Nico}}</ref> The allegation is that the work Rohrabacher performed was a "service" provided to Grin in violation of the sanctions against Grin.<ref name=RohrabacherComplaint20170721 />
 ** Priebus calls Hunt in the evening to discuss whether Sessions will be fired or resign in the wake of the ''Washington Post'' article.  Hunt tells him that Sessions has no intentions of resigning. She points out that Trump will still be under investigation without Sessions.{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-II|pp=94-95}}
 ** The Senate Intelligence Committee interviews Susan Rice.<ref name=SenatIntelCommitReportVol5>{{Cite web |title=Report of the Select Committee on Intelligence United States Senate on Russian Active Measures Campaigns and Interference in the U.S. Election Volume 5: Counterintelligence Threats and Vulnerabilities |url=https://www.intelligence.senate.gov/sites/default/files/documents/report_volume5.pdf |format=PDF |website=[[United States Senate]] |author=Select Committee on Intelligence |author-link=Select Committee on Intelligence |date=2020 |access-date=August 19, 2020}}</ref>{{rp|761}}
 * '''July 22''':
 ** Trump asserts "complete power" to [[List of people granted executive clemency by Donald Trump|pardon anyone]] in relation to the Russia investigation.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/22/us/politics/donald-trump-jeff-sessions.html |title=Trump Says He Has 'Complete Power' to Pardon |work=[[The New York Times]] |first=Peter |last=Baker |date=July 22, 2017 |access-date=July 22, 2017}}</ref>
 ** Trump orders Priebus to tell Sessions that he has "no choice" and "must immediately resign." Priebus then calls McGahn for advice. McGahn tells him to ignore Trump's order, and the two discuss the possibility of resigning instead of carrying out Trump's order to fire Sessions. When Trump follows-up with Priebus in the afternoon, Priebus tells him he will get Sessions to resign. Trump follows-up again. Priebus convinces him to hold off on the resignation because Rosenstein and Associate Attorney General [[Rachel Brand]] would also resign and Trump would probably never get another Attorney General confirmed by Congress.{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-II|pp=95-96}}
-* '''July 24''': After a closed-door meeting with the Senate Intelligence Committee, Kushner issues a statement denying any collusion with Russian officials.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-russia-idUSKBN1A90CF |title=Jared Kushner details Russia contacts, denies collusion |agency=[[Reuters]] |first1=Jeff |last1=Mason |first2=Patricia |last2=Zengerle |date=July 24, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Siegel">{{cite news |last=Siegel |first=Benjamin |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/jared-kushner-set-face-questions-russia-probe-day/story?id=48833151 |title=Jared Kushner faced second day of questioning on the Hill in Russia probe |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=July 25, 2017 |accessdate=August 16, 2017}}</ref>
+* '''July 24''':
+** After a closed-door meeting with the Senate Intelligence Committee, Kushner issues a statement denying any collusion with Russian officials.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-russia-idUSKBN1A90CF |title=Jared Kushner details Russia contacts, denies collusion |agency=[[Reuters]] |first1=Jeff |last1=Mason |first2=Patricia |last2=Zengerle |date=July 24, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Siegel">{{cite news |last=Siegel |first=Benjamin |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/jared-kushner-set-face-questions-russia-probe-day/story?id=48833151 |title=Jared Kushner faced second day of questioning on the Hill in Russia probe |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=July 25, 2017 |accessdate=August 16, 2017}}</ref>
+** The Senate Intelligence Committee interviews Kushner.{{r|SenatIntelCommitReportVol5|p=93}}
 * '''July 25''':
 ** Kushner meets with the House Intelligence Committee in a closed-door meeting.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-russia-kushner-idUSKBN1AA2BU |title=Kushner interviewed by House intelligence panel |date=July 25, 2017 |agency=[[Reuters]]|access-date=August 9, 2017|last1=Becker|first1=Amanda|last2=Walsh|first2=Eric}}</ref><ref name="Siegel"/>
 ** Manafort meets with members of the Senate Intelligence Committee and turns over contemporaneous notes of the June 9, 2016 meeting.<ref name=WP090817/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jul/25/paul-manafort-trump-campaign-chair-russia-senate |title=Ex-Trump campaign chair Paul Manafort tells Senate panel of Russia meeting |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=July 26, 2017|agency=Associated Press}}</ref>
 ** In an Oval Office interview with ''The Wall Street Journal''{{'}}s [[Gerard Baker]], Trump states that there was "nobody on the campaign that saw anybody from Russia".<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/08/01/trump-wall-street-journal-interview-full-transcript-241214 |title=Full transcript: Trump's Wall Street Journal interview |work=[[Politico]] |date=August 1, 2017|last1=Dawsey|first1=Josh|last2=Gold|first2=Hadas}}</ref>
 * '''July 26''': The FBI conducts a predawn raid on Manafort's home, seizing documents and electronic devices.<ref name="WP090817"/><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.thenation.com/article/could-paul-manafort-bring-down-the-whole-trump-family/ |title=Could Paul Manafort Bring Down the Whole Trump Family? |work=[[The Nation]] |date=August 14, 2017|last=Dreyfuss|first=Bob|author-link=Robert Dreyfuss}}</ref> The raid happens on the day Manafort was scheduled to testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2017/08/10/trump-says-he-was-surprised-by-fbi-raid-of-manaforts-home-which-sent-a-very-strong-signal/ |title=Trump says he was surprised by FBI raid of Manafort's home, which sent a 'very strong signal' |work=[[The Washington Post]] |access-date=August 10, 2017|last1=Wagner|first1=John|last2=Hamburger|first2=Tom|date=August 10, 2017}}</ref>
 * '''July 27''': Papadopoulos is arrested upon arrival at [[Washington Dulles International Airport]].<ref name=cnbc-20171030 />
 * '''July 28''': Trump indicates his intention to sign the bill passed by overwhelming veto-proof majorities in both houses of Congress taking the sanctions in place against Russia out of the president's control.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/30/us/politics/putins-bet-on-a-trump-presidency-backfires-spectacularly.html |title=Putin's Bet on a Trump Presidency Backfires Spectacularly |last=Sanger |first=David E. |date=July 30, 2017 |work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=July 31, 2017 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/28/us/trump-to-sign-russia-sanctions-bill-white-house-says.html |title=Trump to Sign Russia Sanctions Bill, White House Says |last=Baker |first=Peter |date=July 28, 2017 |work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=July 31, 2017 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
 * '''July 30''': Putin, responding to sanctions, orders a cut in U.S. diplomatic staff by 755, and bars U.S. officials from entering a warehouse in Moscow used by the [[Embassy of the United States, Moscow|United States Embassy]] and to a site along the [[Moskva River|Moscow River]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/28/world/europe/us-russia-sanctions.html |title=Russia Seizes 2 U.S. Properties and Orders Embassy to Cut Staff |last=Macfarquhar |first=Neil |date=July 28, 2017 |work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=July 31, 2017 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
 * '''July 31''': ''The Washington Post'' reports that Trump personally dictated a statement for Donald Trump Jr. stating that the Veselnitskaya meeting “primarily discussed a program about the adoption of Russian children”.<ref name=TrumpDictated20170731 />
 * '''Late July''': Mueller removes senior FBI investigator [[Peter Strzok]] from his team following the discovery of private texts exchanged with FBI lawyer Lisa Page during the Clinton investigation and the election campaign. According to ''The Washington Post'', the texts contain pro-Clinton comments, are critical of Congress and the media, and call Trump an "idiot" and a "loathsome human".<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/special-counsels-russia-probe-loses-top-fbi-investigator/story?id=49249486 |title=Special counsel's Russia probe loses top FBI investigator |date=August 16, 2017 |publisher=[[ABC News]]|last=Levine|first=Mike}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/02/us/politics/mueller-removed-top-fbi-agent-over-possible-anti-trump-texts.html |title=Mueller Removed Top F.B.I. Agent Over Possible Anti-Trump Texts |date=December 2, 2017 |work=[[The New York Times]]|last1=Schmidt|first1=Michael S.|author-link1=Michael S. Schmidt|last2=Apuzzo|first2=Matt|author-link2=Matt Apuzzo|last3=Goldman|first3=Adam|author-link3=Adam Goldman}}</ref><ref name=wapo-20171212>{{cite news |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/fbi-texts-reveal-anti-trump-pro-clinton-comments/2017/12/12/e0685f80-dfa4-11e7-bbd0-9dfb2e37492a_story.html |title=FBI texts reveal anti-Trump, pro-Clinton comments |date=December 12, 2017 |work=[[The Washington Post]]|last=Barrett|first=Devlin}}</ref>
 
 === August ===
 * '''August 1'''
 ** ''The Washington Post'' reports that Rod Wheeler has filed a lawsuit claiming the Trump White House was directly involved in the publication of a ''Fox News'' story about the [[murder of Seth Rich#conspiracy theories|Seth Rich conspiracy theory]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Bump |first=Philip |date=August 1, 2017 |title=A timeline of the explosive lawsuit alleging a White House link in the Seth Rich conspiracy |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/politics/wp/2017/08/01/a-timeline-of-the-explosive-lawsuit-alleging-a-white-house-link-in-the-seth-rich-conspiracy/ |work=[[The Washington Post]] |location=|access-date=August 1, 2017}}</ref>
 ** [[White House Press Secretary]] [[Sarah Huckabee Sanders]] comments<ref>{{Cite web |title=White House Daily Briefing |url=https://www.c-span.org/video/?432014-1/white-house-president-dictate-sons-russia-meeting-statement |website=[[C-SPAN]] |date=August 1, 2017 |access-date=December 19, 2019 |last=Sanders |first=Sarah Huckabee |author-link=Sarah Huckabee Sanders}}</ref> on ''[[The Washington Post]]'' article from the day before claiming Trump dictated the response about the [[Trump Tower meeting]]. She clarifies that Trump "certainly didn't dictate, ... but he weighed in, offered suggestion, like any father would do, based on the limited information that he had."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Nelson |first1=Louis |title=Sanders: Trump 'weighed in' on initial statement about son's Russia meeting |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/08/01/trump-sanders-son-russia-statement-241209 |work=[[Politico]] |accessdate=August 1, 2017|last2=Samuelsohn|first2=Darren|date=August 1, 2017}}</ref>{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-II|p=105}}

edits.entity: Timeline of investigations into Donald Trump and Russia (July–December 2017)
edits.diff:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -65,31 +65,31 @@
 * '''July 21''':
 ** ''The Washington Post'' reports Sessions discussed Trump campaign-related matters with Kislyak.<ref name=SessionsKislyakDiscussionsWapo20170721>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/sessions-discussed-trump-campaign-related-matters-with-russian-ambassador-us-intelligence-intercepts-show/2017/07/21/3e704692-6e44-11e7-9c15-177740635e83_story.html |title=Sessions discussed Trump campaign-related matters with Russian ambassador, U.S. intelligence intercepts show |last=Nakashima |first=Ellen |last2=Miller |first2=Greg |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=July 21, 2017 |access-date=July 21, 2017}}</ref>
 ** The Senate Judiciary Committee requests all communications between Trump Jr. and a group of people, including Jill Stein. She publicly describes the notion that she communicated with Trump Jr. as "an obvious smear designed to generate a fake news feeding frenzy".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://thehill.com/policy/national-security/343292-jill-stein-looped-into-widening-investigation-of-russia-and-trump-jr |title=Jill Stein looped into widening investigation of Russia and Trump Jr. connections |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |date=July 22, 2017|last=Cohn|first=Alicia}}</ref>
 ** [[John M. Dowd]] replaces Marc Kasowitz at the head of Trump's legal team, following personal threats made by Kasowitz.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/trump-lawyer-marc-kasowitz-reduced-role-article-1.3343960 |title=Trump lawyer Marc Kasowitz taking reduced White House role amid legal team shake up |newspaper=[[New York Daily News]] |date=July 21, 2017|last=Cullen|first=Terence}}</ref> Legal spokesman Mark Corallo resigns.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-40678397 |title=Trump legal team spokesman Mark Corallo resigns amid 'shake-up' |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=July 21, 2017}}</ref> [[Michael Wolff (journalist)|Michael Wolff]] later reports that Corallo had been instructed not to speak to the press or to answer his telephone, and that he privately stated his belief that the Air Force One meeting on July 8, 2017 represented likely [[obstruction of justice]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/01/03/the-wildest-claims-about-trump-from-michael-wolffs-fire-and-fury.html |title=10 wild claims about Trump's White House from the upcoming book 'Fire and Fury' |date=January 3, 2018 |publisher=CNBC|last=Wilkie|first=Christina}}</ref>
 ** A complaint is filed against [[United States House of Representatives|Representative]] [[Dana Rohrabacher]] with the [[Office of Foreign Assets Control]] alleging violations of [[Magnitsky Act]] sanctions.<ref name=RohrabacherComplaint20170721>{{cite web|title=Notice of Apparent Violations of Magnitsky Act Sanctions by U.S. Persons Providing Services to SDN Viktor Grin|url=http://russian-untouchables.com/docs/OFAC%20complaint%20filed_Redacted.pdf|date=July 21, 2017|author=Hermitage Capital Management|publisher=Russian Untouchables|access-date=March 19, 2018|author-link=Hermitage Capital Management}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Rep. Dana Rohrabacher accused of violating Russian sanctions by backer of Russian sanctions law|url=https://www.latimes.com/politics/essential/la-pol-ca-essential-politics-updates-complaint-filed-over-rohrabacher-s-2016-1501179754-htmlstory.html|website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=July 27, 2017|access-date=March 19, 2018|last=Wire|first=Sarah D.}}</ref> In April 2016, Rohrabacher received a document directly from [[Prosecutor General of Russia|Russian Deputy Prosecutor]] Viktor Grin, an individual under sanctions, and used it in attempts to weaken the [[Magnitsky Act]].<ref name="RohrabacherDirectionFromMoscowDB20170719">{{cite web|title=GOP Lawmaker Got Direction From Moscow, Took It Back to D.C.|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/gop-lawmaker-got-direction-from-moscow-took-it-back-to-dc|website=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=July 19, 2017|access-date=March 19, 2018|last=Hines|first=Nico}}</ref> The allegation is that the work Rohrabacher performed was a "service" provided to Grin in violation of the sanctions against Grin.<ref name=RohrabacherComplaint20170721 />
 ** Priebus calls Hunt in the evening to discuss whether Sessions will be fired or resign in the wake of the ''Washington Post'' article.  Hunt tells him that Sessions has no intentions of resigning. She points out that Trump will still be under investigation without Sessions.{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-II|pp=94-95}}
 ** The Senate Intelligence Committee interviews Susan Rice.<ref name=SenatIntelCommitReportVol5>{{Cite web |title=Report of the Select Committee on Intelligence United States Senate on Russian Active Measures Campaigns and Interference in the U.S. Election Volume 5: Counterintelligence Threats and Vulnerabilities |url=https://www.intelligence.senate.gov/sites/default/files/documents/report_volume5.pdf |format=PDF |website=[[United States Senate]] |author=Select Committee on Intelligence |author-link=Select Committee on Intelligence |date=2020 |access-date=August 19, 2020}}</ref>{{rp|761}}
 * '''July 22''':
 ** Trump asserts "complete power" to [[List of people granted executive clemency by Donald Trump|pardon anyone]] in relation to the Russia investigation.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/22/us/politics/donald-trump-jeff-sessions.html |title=Trump Says He Has 'Complete Power' to Pardon |work=[[The New York Times]] |first=Peter |last=Baker |date=July 22, 2017 |access-date=July 22, 2017}}</ref>
 ** Trump orders Priebus to tell Sessions that he has "no choice" and "must immediately resign." Priebus then calls McGahn for advice. McGahn tells him to ignore Trump's order, and the two discuss the possibility of resigning instead of carrying out Trump's order to fire Sessions. When Trump follows-up with Priebus in the afternoon, Priebus tells him he will get Sessions to resign. Trump follows-up again. Priebus convinces him to hold off on the resignation because Rosenstein and Associate Attorney General [[Rachel Brand]] would also resign and Trump would probably never get another Attorney General confirmed by Congress.{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-II|pp=95-96}}
 * '''July 24''':
 ** After a closed-door meeting with the Senate Intelligence Committee, Kushner issues a statement denying any collusion with Russian officials.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-russia-idUSKBN1A90CF |title=Jared Kushner details Russia contacts, denies collusion |agency=[[Reuters]] |first1=Jeff |last1=Mason |first2=Patricia |last2=Zengerle |date=July 24, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Siegel">{{cite news |last=Siegel |first=Benjamin |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/jared-kushner-set-face-questions-russia-probe-day/story?id=48833151 |title=Jared Kushner faced second day of questioning on the Hill in Russia probe |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=July 25, 2017 |accessdate=August 16, 2017}}</ref>
 ** The Senate Intelligence Committee interviews Kushner.{{r|SenatIntelCommitReportVol5|p=93}}
 * '''July 25''':
 ** Kushner meets with the House Intelligence Committee in a closed-door meeting.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-russia-kushner-idUSKBN1AA2BU |title=Kushner interviewed by House intelligence panel |date=July 25, 2017 |agency=[[Reuters]]|access-date=August 9, 2017|last1=Becker|first1=Amanda|last2=Walsh|first2=Eric}}</ref><ref name="Siegel"/>
-** Manafort meets with members of the Senate Intelligence Committee and turns over contemporaneous notes of the June 9, 2016 meeting.<ref name=WP090817/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jul/25/paul-manafort-trump-campaign-chair-russia-senate |title=Ex-Trump campaign chair Paul Manafort tells Senate panel of Russia meeting |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=July 26, 2017|agency=Associated Press}}</ref>
+** Manafort meets with members of the Senate Intelligence Committee and turns over contemporaneous notes of the June 9, 2016 meeting.<ref name=WP090817/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jul/25/paul-manafort-trump-campaign-chair-russia-senate |title=Ex-Trump campaign chair Paul Manafort tells Senate panel of Russia meeting |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=July 26, 2017|agency=Associated Press}}</ref>{{r|SenatIntelCommitReportVol5|p=348}}
 ** In an Oval Office interview with ''The Wall Street Journal''{{'}}s [[Gerard Baker]], Trump states that there was "nobody on the campaign that saw anybody from Russia".<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/08/01/trump-wall-street-journal-interview-full-transcript-241214 |title=Full transcript: Trump's Wall Street Journal interview |work=[[Politico]] |date=August 1, 2017|last1=Dawsey|first1=Josh|last2=Gold|first2=Hadas}}</ref>
 * '''July 26''': The FBI conducts a predawn raid on Manafort's home, seizing documents and electronic devices.<ref name="WP090817"/><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.thenation.com/article/could-paul-manafort-bring-down-the-whole-trump-family/ |title=Could Paul Manafort Bring Down the Whole Trump Family? |work=[[The Nation]] |date=August 14, 2017|last=Dreyfuss|first=Bob|author-link=Robert Dreyfuss}}</ref> The raid happens on the day Manafort was scheduled to testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2017/08/10/trump-says-he-was-surprised-by-fbi-raid-of-manaforts-home-which-sent-a-very-strong-signal/ |title=Trump says he was surprised by FBI raid of Manafort's home, which sent a 'very strong signal' |work=[[The Washington Post]] |access-date=August 10, 2017|last1=Wagner|first1=John|last2=Hamburger|first2=Tom|date=August 10, 2017}}</ref>
 * '''July 27''': Papadopoulos is arrested upon arrival at [[Washington Dulles International Airport]].<ref name=cnbc-20171030 />
 * '''July 28''': Trump indicates his intention to sign the bill passed by overwhelming veto-proof majorities in both houses of Congress taking the sanctions in place against Russia out of the president's control.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/30/us/politics/putins-bet-on-a-trump-presidency-backfires-spectacularly.html |title=Putin's Bet on a Trump Presidency Backfires Spectacularly |last=Sanger |first=David E. |date=July 30, 2017 |work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=July 31, 2017 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/28/us/trump-to-sign-russia-sanctions-bill-white-house-says.html |title=Trump to Sign Russia Sanctions Bill, White House Says |last=Baker |first=Peter |date=July 28, 2017 |work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=July 31, 2017 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
 * '''July 30''': Putin, responding to sanctions, orders a cut in U.S. diplomatic staff by 755, and bars U.S. officials from entering a warehouse in Moscow used by the [[Embassy of the United States, Moscow|United States Embassy]] and to a site along the [[Moskva River|Moscow River]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/28/world/europe/us-russia-sanctions.html |title=Russia Seizes 2 U.S. Properties and Orders Embassy to Cut Staff |last=Macfarquhar |first=Neil |date=July 28, 2017 |work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=July 31, 2017 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
