Gubarev is seeking information on the Steele dossier to help his libel suit against ''BuzzFeed''.<ref>{{cite web|title="Mr. Steele Appeared": The Ex-Spy Behind the Infamous Golden-Shower Dossier Gets Deposed in London|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2018/06/the-ex-spy-behind-the-golden-shower-dossier-gets-deposed-in-london|website=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|date=June 19, 2018|access-date=August 21, 2018|last=Pompeo|first=Joe}}</ref>
 * '''June 20''': Mueller's team interviews Dearborn for the second and final time.{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-II|p=91–93}}
 * '''June 21''': U.S. District Court Judge Amy Berman Jackson rejects a [[motion to suppress evidence]] found in a search of Manafort's storage locker on May 27, 2017. The defense argued the evidence was improperly collected because the FBI entered the locker without a search warrant, even though the FBI left and returned with a warrant after seeing the locker's contents. The judge ruled the evidence was properly collected because the Manafort associate who opened the locker was on the lease, had a key, and voluntarily let the FBI in.<ref>{{cite web|title=Judge rejects Manafort bid to suppress storage-unit evidence|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/06/21/paul-manafort-search-evidence-trial-662748|website=[[Politico]]|date=June 21, 2018|access-date=June 27, 2018|last=Samuelsohn|first=Darren}}</ref>
 * '''June 22''': Judge Jackson rejects a request to toss out a money laundering charge against Manafort. His lawyers argued that receiving tens of millions of dollars for lobbying while an unregistered foreign agent was not illegal in itself. Instead, they argued, failing to register was the illegal act. The judge ruled, "It is a crime to 'act' [as a foreign agent] 'unless' one has registered – the statute does not simply state that the failure to register is unlawful[.]"<ref>{{cite web|title=Judge turns down Manafort's bid to nix money laundering charge|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/06/22/paul-manafort-money-laundering-charge-664793|website=[[Politico]]|date=June 22, 2018|access-date=June 27, 2018|last=Gerstein|first=Josh}}</ref>
 * '''June 24''': Credico tells [[Jimmy Dore]] that he received a request from Mueller for a voluntary interview. Credico tells ''The Daily Beast'' that he will refuse to speak to Mueller's team unless he is subpoenaed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Robert Mueller Wants to Talk to Roger Stone's Comedian Frenemy|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/robert-mueller-wants-to-talk-to-roger-stones-comedian-frenemy|website=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=June 24, 2018|access-date=July 9, 2018|last=Woodruff|first=Betsy}}</ref>
 * '''June 25''':
 ** ''[[ABC News]]'' reports that Erik Prince gave Mueller's team "total access to his phones and computer."<ref>{{cite web|title=Special counsel obtains Trump ally Erik Prince's phones, computer|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/special-counsel-obtains-trump-ally-erik-princes-phones/story?id=56143477|website=[[ABC News]]|date=June 25, 2018|access-date=June 25, 2018|last=Meek|first=James Gordon}}</ref>
 ** Mueller's team interviews Trump campaign policy director [[John Mashburn]].{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-I|pp=125-127}}
 * '''June 27''': The [[Office of Legal Counsel]] holds a brown-bag lunch at the Department of Justice with [[William Barr]] as featured speaker. When ''The Guardian'' reports on the lunch in April 2019, a spokesperson for the department insists that Barr's invitation was routine and that his June 8 memo was not discussed at the lunch.<ref name=DoJOfficialsToldOfBarrTheGuardian20190405 />
 * '''June 28''': The House of Representatives passes H. [[Resolution (law)|Res]] 970 subpoenaing FISA surveillance on a party line vote with Congressman [[Justin Amash]] voting present.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-resolution/970|title=H.Res.970 – Insisting that the Department of Justice fully comply with the requests, including subpoenas, of the Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence and the subpoena issued by the Committee on the Judiciary relating to potential violations of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act by personnel of the Department of Justice and related matters.|date=June 28, 2018|website=congress.gov}}</ref>

edits.entity: Timeline of investigations into Donald Trump and Russia (January–June 2018)
edits.diff:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -354,30 +354,31 @@
 ** Mueller's team interviews [[Annie Donaldson]] for the second and final time.{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-II|pp=81, 86–87}}
 * '''April 3''':
 ** Dutch attorney [[Alex van der Zwaan]] is sentenced to 30 days in federal prison and ordered to pay a $20,000 fine for lying to the [[FBI]] about his contacts with a former [[GRU]] officer and for withholding documents from the Mueller investigation.<ref>{{cite web|title=First sentence handed down in Mueller probe |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/first-sentence-handed-down-in-mueller-special-counsel-probe/2018/04/03/23e9b21e-3693-11e8-acd5-35eac230e514_story.html |website=[[The Washington Post]]|date=April 3, 2018|access-date=April 3, 2018|last=Hsu|first=Spencer S.}}</ref>
 ** Facebook closes the Federal Agency of News (FAN) account. The FAN is a sister organization to the IRA located in the same building in St. Petersburg.<ref name=RussianTrollsSueFacebookDailyBeast20181120>{{cite web|title=Russian Trolls Sue Facebook, Their Old Propaganda Machine|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/russian-trolls-sue-facebook-their-old-propaganda-machine|website=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=November 20, 2018|access-date=January 4, 2019|last1=Ackerman|first1=Spencer|author-link1=Spencer Ackerman|last2=Poulsen|first2=Kevin|author-link2=Kevin Poulsen}}</ref>
 ** Mueller's team interviews Priebus for the third of three times.{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-II|p=50-51, 81, 87, 93, 95-96, 99-100, 115, 123}}
 ** Outspoken Mueller critic U.S. Representative [[Matt Gaetz]] criticizes the Mueller investigation on ''[[Lou Dobbs Tonight]]''. During the interview, Flynn sends Gaetz a Twitter direct message saying, "You stay on top of what you're doing. Your leadership is so vital for our country now. Keep the pressure on." In May 2019, the message is revealed in a court filing as evidence of Flynn's outreach to Mueller's critics while he was cooperating with the investigation.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Flynn contacted GOP Mueller critic while cooperating with special counsel |url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/05/17/politics/michael-flynn-mueller-matt-gaetz/index.html?no-st=1558139400 |website=[[CNN]] |date=May 17, 2019 |access-date=January 23, 2020 |last1=Brown |first1=Pamela |author-link=Pamela Brown (journalist) |last2=Herb |first2=Jeremy |last3=Polantz |first3=Katelyn |last4=Collins |first4=Kaitlan |author-link4=Kaitlan Collins}}</ref>
 * '''April 4''':
 ** CNN reports that Mueller has been questioning Russian oligarchs who traveled into the US, stopping one and searching electronic devices when the private jet landed at a New York area airport.<ref>{{Cite news|url= https://www.cnn.com/2018/04/04/politics/mueller-special-counsel-investigation-russian-oligarchs/index.html|title=Exclusive: Mueller's team questioning Russian oligarchs|last=Scannell|first=Kara|date=April 4, 2018|publisher=CNN|access-date=April 4, 2018|last2=Prokupecz|first2=Shimon}}</ref>
 ** [[Facebook]] CEO [[Mark Zuckerberg]], in a call to reporters, says the personal information of up to 87 million people, most of them Americans, may have been improperly shared with [[Cambridge Analytica]] during the 2016 election.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/04/technology/mark-zuckerberg-testify-congress.html|title=Facebook Says Cambridge Analytica Harvested Data of Up to 87 Million Users|last=Kang|first=Cecilia|date=April 4, 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=April 4, 2018|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Facebook announces sweeping changes to many of its [[Application programming interface|APIs]]—software plugins that allow outside businesses and developers to collect data directly from Facebook.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://newsroom.fb.com/news/2018/04/restricting-data-access/|title=An Update on Our Plans to Restrict Data Access on Facebook|website=[[Facebook Newsroom]]|access-date=April 4, 2018|language=en|date=April 4, 2018|last=Schroepfer|first=Mike|author-link=Mike Schroepfer}}</ref>
 ** ''The Washington Post'' reports that the Trump administration is going to implement new economic sanctions designed to target oligarchs with ties to Putin.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/trump-administration-to-impose-fresh-sanctions-against-russia/2018/04/04/bc09e0b8-3851-11e8-b57c-9445cc4dfa5e_story.html|title=Trump administration to impose fresh sanctions against Russia|last1=Hudson|first1=John|date=April 4, 2018|work=Washington Post|access-date=April 5, 2018|last2=Dawsey|first2=Josh|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286|last3=Harris|first3=Shane}}</ref>
 ** Roger Stone tells ''CNN'' that he did not travel to London and dine with Julian Assange in August 2016. His statement contradicts an email he sent to Sam Nunberg at the time.<ref name=StoneDevastatingWikiLeaksCNN20180404>{{cite news|title=Stone, on day he sent Assange dinner email, also said 'devastating' WikiLeaks were forthcoming|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/04/04/politics/roger-stone-julian-assange-email-wikileaks/index.html|website=[[CNN]]|last1=Kaczynski|first1=Andrew|last2=Borger|first2=Gloria|author-link1=Andrew Kaczynski|author-link2=Gloria Borger|date=April 4, 2018|access-date=July 6, 2018}}</ref>
 ** Kilimnik reaches out to Eckart Sager and [[Alan Friedman]] in an effort to coach them on what to say about their work with Manafort in Ukraine. Later, Sager and Friedman inform the FBI of Kilimnik's inappropriate contacts, and Kilimnik and Manafort are subsequently charged with [[witness tampering]] in June. Manafort pleads guilty in September. In [[commons:File:Paul Manafort statement of the offense and other acts 17-201-01(ABJ)).pdf|Manafort's statement of the offense]], Friedman is identified as "Person D1", and Sager as "Person D2".<ref name=ManafortWilCooperateWithWaPo20180914 /><ref name=MuellerHasRevealedTheBusinessInsider20180613 /><ref name=ManafortStatementOfOffense20180914 />
 ** Mueller's team interviews Kushner's executive assistant Catherine Vargas.{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-I|pp=119, 160}}
 ** Mueller's team interviews Giorgi Rtskhiladze, a Russian business executive involved in the Trump Tower Moscow project, for the first of two times.{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-II|pp=28, 138}}
 ** Mueller's team interviews Erik Prince for the first of two times.{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-I|p=64, 148-149, 151, 154-156}}
+** The Senate Intelligence Committee interviews Sater.{{r|SenatIntelCommitReportVol5|p=409}}
 * '''April 5''': ''Politico'' reports Mueller moved to seize bank accounts at three different financial institutions last year the day before Manafort was indicted.<ref name=MuellerSeizedAccountsPolitico20180405>{{Cite news|url= https://www.politico.com/story/2018/04/05/manafort-mueller-moves-to-seize-bank-accounts-505307|title=Mueller moved to seize bank accounts in Manafort probe|work=[[Politico]]|access-date=April 8, 2018|date=April 5, 2018|last=Gerstein|first=Josh}}</ref>
 [[File:Cohen-v-US-Govt-Opposition-to-TRO-Request.pdf|thumb|Cohen v US – Gov't Opposition to TRO Request]]
 * '''April 6'''
 ** The United States Treasury implements economic sanctions on seven Russian oligarchs and 12 companies they control, along with 17 top Russian officials, a state-owned weapons-trading company and a subsidiary bank. The high-profile names on the list include [[Oleg Deripaska]], a billionaire with links to Manafort, and [[Kirill Shamalov]], Putin's ex-son-in-law. The press release says, "Deripaska has been investigated for money laundering, and has been accused of threatening the lives of business rivals, illegally wiretapping a government official, and taking part in extortion and racketeering. There are also allegations that Deripaska bribed a government official, ordered the murder of a businessman, and had links to a Russian organized crime group."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/04/06/us-sanctions-russians-including-oligarch-linked-to-former-trump-campaign-chief-paul-manafort.html|title=US sanctions several Russians, including oligarch linked to former Trump campaign chief Paul Manafort|last=Calia|first=Amanda Macias, Mike|date=April 6, 2018|work=CNBC|access-date=April 6, 2018}}</ref>
 ** ''McClatchy'' reports Mueller's team spent the week interviewing a Trump Organization associate involved in overseas deals, including Trump-branded properties.<ref name=MuellerTrumpBusinessPartnersMcClatchyDC20180409 />
 ** Mueller's team interviews Lewandowski.{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-II|p=91-94}}
 [[File:Michael Cohen search warrants publicly released on 2019-03-19.pdf|thumb|Michael Cohen search warrants]]
 * '''April 9''':
 ** ''ProPublica'' reports that [[Jeff Sessions]] sought out [[Elliott Broidy|Elliott Broidy's]] advice on how the [[United States Attorney|U.S. attorneys]] should be replaced.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.propublica.org/article/elliott-broidy-sessions-turned-to-convicted-fundraiser-for-advice-on-attorneys|title=Sessions Turned to Convicted Fundraiser for Advice on U.S. Attorneys|date=April 9, 2018|website=ProPublica|language=en-us|first=Robert|last=Faturechi|access-date=April 9, 2018}}</ref>
 ** ''The New York Times'' reports that Mueller is investigating a payment of $150,000 to the [[Donald J. Trump Foundation]] by Ukrainian billionaire [[Victor Pinchuk]] for a September 2015 speech by Trump at the [[Victor Pinchuk#Yalta European Strategy|Yalta European Strategy]] conference that took place in [[Kiev]].<ref name=Ukraine150kToTrumpNYT20180409>{{cite news|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/09/us/politics/trump-mueller-ukraine-victor-pinchuk.html|title=Mueller Investigating Ukrainian's $150,000 Payment for a Trump Appearance|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=April 9, 2018| last1=Schmidt| first1=Michael S.|authorlink=Michael S. Schmidt|last2=Haberman|first2=Maggie|access-date=April 9, 2018| issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref name=YESTrumpYouTube20150911>{{cite web|title=YES-2015_MP3EN_20150911.20-46|url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S60nubH47Ac|date=September 11, 2015|access-date=April 9, 2018|publisher=[[YouTube]]| type=video}}</ref>
 ** Based on a referral from Mueller's office, the [[U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York]] (SDNY) executes a series of search warrants at the law offices, safety deposit box, and hotel room of Cohen, Trump's longtime personal attorney,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/09/us/politics/fbi-raids-office-of-trumps-longtime-lawyer-michael-cohen.html|title=F.B.I. Raids Office of Trump's Longtime Lawyer Michael Cohen; Trump Calls It 'Disgraceful' |date=April 9, 2018|website=[[The New York Times]]|last1=Apuzzo|first1=Matt|author-link1=Matt Apuzzo|first2=Maggie|last2=Haberman|author-link2=Maggie Haberman|first3=Michael D.|last3=Shear}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/04/09/politics/michael-cohen-fbi/index.html|title=FBI raids Trump lawyer Michael Cohen's office, seizes Stormy Daniels documents, bank records|first=Eli|last=Watkins|date=April 9, 2018|website=[[CNN]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2019/03/19/mueller-investigation-michael-cohen-1226983 |title=Mueller's office began investigating Michael Cohen as early as July 2017 |authors=Kyle Cheney and Darren Samuelsohn |date=March 19, 2019 |website=Politico.com |publisher= |access-date=20 March 2019 |quote=}}</ref> in relation to the [[Stormy Daniels–Donald Trump scandal|Stormy Daniels affair]] and other matters.
 * '''April 10''':
 ** NRA general counsel John Frazer informs Senator [[Ron Wyden]] in a letter that the NRA accepted $2,512.85 from people with Russian addresses between 2015 and 2018. He says $525 came from contributions by two individuals, and the rest came from membership dues from 23 individuals. He notes that some of the individuals may be U.S. citizens. He acknowledges that Alexander Torshin is a life member of the NRA. Information in the letter contradicts earlier statements by the NRA.<ref>{{cite web|title=NRA, In New Document, Acknowledges More Than 20 Russian-Linked Contributors|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/04/11/601534305/nra-in-new-document-acknowledges-more-than-20-russian-linked-contributors|website=[[NPR]]|date=April 11, 2018|access-date=June 29, 2018|last=Mak|first=Tim}}</ref>
 ** ''The Hill'' reports that Boente received an interview request from Mueller a day after the FBI raided Cohen's office.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ex-acting deputy AG Boente was asked to interview with Mueller: report|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/382594-ex-acting-deputy-ag-boente-asked-to-interview-with-mueller|website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|date=April 10, 2018|access-date=July 5, 2018|last=Manchester|first=Julia}}</ref>
 ** ''NJ.com'' reports that Mueller is investigating a series of previously unreported January 2017 meetings in the [[Seychelles]] in addition to the reported meeting between Erik Prince and Dmitriev. The meetings include politically-connected individuals from Russia, France, Saudi Arabia, and South Africa, and are part of a larger gathering hosted by UAE Crown Prince [[Mohammed bin Zayed Al Nahyan]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Trump Russia probe is expanding, as Mueller looks into new meetings in the Seychelles: exclusive|url=https://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2018/04/exclusive_robert_muellers_team_in_charge_of_invest.html|website=[[NJ.com]]|date=April 10, 2018|access-date=September 12, 2018|last=Banco|first=Erin}}</ref>

edits.entity: Timeline of investigations into Donald Trump and Russia (January–June 2018)
edits.diff:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -332,30 +332,31 @@
 * '''March 27''':
 ** [[Christopher Wylie]] tells U.K. lawmakers that [[Palantir Technologies|Palantir]], a secretive company co-founded by high-profile Trump supporter [[Peter Thiel]], worked with Cambridge Analytica on their ad-targeting in the 2016 election.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/27/palantir-worked-with-cambridge-analytica-on-the-facebook-data-whistleblower.html|title=Peter Thiel's Palantir worked with Cambridge Analytica on the Facebook data, whistleblower alleges|last=Kharpal|first=Arjun|date=March 27, 2018|publisher=[[CNBC]]|access-date=March 27, 2018}}</ref>
 ** [[Ted Malloch]] is served with a [[search warrant]] to clone all of the electronic devices in his possession when he walks off the plane after flying from [[Heathrow Airport|London's Heathrow]] to [[Logan International Airport|Boston's Logan]] airport, and is subsequently interrogated by the FBI, who ask about his involvement in the Trump campaign and connections to [[Nigel Farage]] and Stone. The FBI agents “seemed to know everything about me,” Malloch says later in a statement about his experience.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.politico.eu/article/nigel-farage-ally-ted-malloch-to-testify-in-donald-trump-russia-mueller-probe/|title=Farage ally Ted Malloch to testify in Trump-Russia probe|date=March 30, 2018|work=[[Politico]]|access-date=March 31, 2018|language=en-US|last=Hervey|first=Ginger}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/mar/30/fbi-questions-ted-malloch-trump-campaign-figure-and-farage-ally|title=FBI questions Ted Malloch, Trump campaign figure and Farage ally|last=Kirchgaessner|first=Stephanie|date=March 30, 2018|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=March 31, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Federal investigators question Ted Malloch in special counsel probe|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/03/30/politics/fbi-malloch-questions-mueller/index.html|website=CNN|date=March 30, 2018|access-date=May 27, 2018|last1=Prokupecz|first1=Shimon|last2=Herb|first2=Jeremy}}</ref> Mueller compels Malloch to testify about the Russian cyber-intrusions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/mueller-subpoenas-ted-malloch-to-testify-in-the-russia-probe-2018-3|title=A 'significant figure' linked to Roger Stone has been compelled to testify in the Russia probe as Mueller homes in on the DNC hack|work=[[Business Insider]]|access-date=March 31, 2018|last=Sheth|first=Sonam|date=March 30, 2018}}</ref>
 ** Mueller's team interviews Simes for the second of two times.{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-I|p=104, 109, 164}}
 ** Mueller's team refers the [[Bijan Rafiekian]] and [[Kamil Ekim Alptekin]] investigations to the [[United States Department of Justice National Security Division|DoJ National Security Division]], which later passes the investigations to the [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia|Eastern District of Virginia]].{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-II|p=D-1}}
 * '''March 28''':
 ** ''The New York Times'' reports that in 2017 Trump's attorney [[John M. Dowd|John Dowd]] discussed the [[List of people pardoned or granted clemency by the President of the United States|idea of Trump pardoning]] Flynn and Manafort with their attorneys.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/28/us/politics/trump-pardon-michael-flynn-paul-manafort-john-dowd.html|title=Trump's Lawyer Raised Prospect of Pardons for Flynn and Manafort as Special Counsel Closed In|last=Schmidt|first=Michael S.|authorlink=Michael S. Schmidt|date=March 28, 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=March 28, 2018|last2=Becker|first2=Jo|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331|last3=Mazzetti|first3=Mark| last4=Haberman|first4=Maggie| last5=Goldman|first5=Adam}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url= https://www.vox.com/2017/8/29/16211784/trump-pardons-manafort-flynn-mueller|title=10 legal experts on why Trump can't pardon his way out of the Russia investigation|work=[[Vox (website)|Vox]]|access-date=March 28, 2018|date=March 28, 2018|last=Illing|first=Sean}}</ref>
 ** Evidence related to the sentencing of [[Alex van der Zwaan]] is filed in court. "Person A" is revealed to be [[Konstantin Kilimnik]], a former Ukraine-based aide to Gates and Manafort.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2018/03/28/mueller-just-drew-the-most-direct-line-to-date-between-the-trump-campaign-and-russia/|title=Mueller just drew his most direct line to date between the Trump campaign and Russia|last=Blake|first=Aaron|date=March 28, 2018|work=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=March 28, 2018|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
 ** ''[[ProPublica]]'' reports that Senate Judiciary Committee chief investigative counsel Jason Foster, empowered by chairman [[Chuck Grassley|Charles Grassley]], has been pseudonymously disparaging the FBI and Mueller's investigation for a year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.propublica.org/article/jason-foster-the-senate-staffer-behind-the-attack-on-the-trump-russia-investigation|title=A Partisan Combatant, a Remorseful Blogger: The Senate Staffer Behind the Attack on the Trump-Russia Investigation |last=Faturechi| first=Robert|date=March 28, 2018|website=[[ProPublica]]|language=en-us|access-date=March 28, 2018}}</ref>
 ** [[Ecuador]] cuts [[Julian Assange]]'s internet and telephone access at its London embassy, where Assange has been living for nearly six years.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/mar/28/julian-assange-internet-connection-ecuador-embassy-cut-off-wikileaks|title=Ecuador cuts off Julian Assange's internet access at London embassy|last=Henley|first=Jon|date=March 28, 2018|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=March 29, 2018}}</ref>
 ** Sessions announces the [[United States Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General|inspector general]] will investigate FBI surveillance of Carter Page.<ref name=JusticeDeptInvestigatedOverSurveillance20180328>{{cite news|title=Justice Dept. Will Be Investigated Over Surveillance of Trump Campaign Official|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/28/us/politics/justice-department-carter-page-surveillance.html|website=[[The New York Times]]|date=March 28, 2018|access-date=June 27, 2018|last1=Fandos|first1=Nicholas|last2=Benner|first2=Katie}}</ref>
 ** NRA outside counsel Steven Hart tells ''ABC News'' the NRA received only one contribution from a Russian since 2012, the life membership payment from Alexander Torshin.<ref>{{cite web|title=NRA says it received one contribution of less than $1000 from a Russian|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/nra-received-contribution-1000-russian/story?id=54080082|website=[[ABC News]]|date=March 28, 2018|access-date=June 29, 2018|last1=Turner|first1=Trish|last2=Mosk|first2=Matthew}}</ref>
 * '''March 29'''
 ** ''The Guardian'' reports that the FBI made inquiries before the 2016 election campaign into Trump's property dealings in the [[post-Soviet states]] including [[Latvia]] with individuals close to Putin.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/mar/29/trump-fbi-hotel-latvia-investigation-russia-links|title=FBI looked into Trump plans to build hotel in Latvia with Putin supporter|last=Swaine|first=Jon|date=March 29, 2018|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=March 29, 2018}}</ref>
 ** Sessions rejects requests by Senator [[Charles Grassley]], Representative [[Robert Goodlatte]], and Representative [[Trey Gowdy]] to appoint a [[special counsel]] to investigate FBI surveillance of Carter Page, saying the [[United States Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General|inspector general]] is already investigating the matter.<ref>{{cite web|title=Letter to Chairmen Grassley, Goodlatte, and Gowdy|url=https://assets.documentcloud.org/documents/4426661/AG-Letter-Re-IG-and-Huber-Reviews.pdf|via=DocumentCloud|date=March 29, 2018|access-date=June 27, 2018|last=Sessions III|first=Jefferson B.|author-link=Jeff Sessions}}</ref><ref name=JusticeDeptInvestigatedOverSurveillance20180328 />
+* '''March 30''': The Senate Intelligence Committee interviews Simes.{{r|SenatIntelCommitReportVol5|p=561}}
 
 === April ===
 * '''April''':
 ** Mueller begins asking witnesses to provide access to the encrypted [[messaging apps]] on their personal phones.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mueller's team is requesting that witnesses turn in their personal phones to inspect their encrypted messaging programs|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/06/06/mueller-team-zeroes-in-on-encrypted-apps-as-witness-turn-in-phones.html|website=[[CNBC]]|date=June 6, 2018|access-date=July 5, 2018|last=Schwartz|first=Brian}}</ref>
 ** Butina testifies before the [[Senate Intelligence Committee]] in a closed session for eight hours.<ref name=RussianAccusedOfUsingSexCNN20180722 /> She tells the committee that Russian billionaire [[Konstantin Nikolaev]] funded "Right to Bear Arms" from 2012 to 2014.<ref name=RussianBillionaireBackedButinaWapo20180722>{{cite web|title=Russian billionaire with U.S. investments backed alleged agent Maria Butina, according to a person familiar with her Senate testimony|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/russian-billionaire-with-us-investments-backed-alleged-agent-maria-butina-according-to-a-person-familiar-with-her-senate-testimony/2018/07/22/dcaa7f48-8c58-11e8-a345-a1bf7847b375_story.html|website=[[The Washington Post]]|date=July 22, 2018|access-date=July 26, 2018|last=Helferman|first=Rosalind S.|last2=Crites|first2=Alice|last3=Hamburger|first3=Tom|last4=Jackman|first4=Tom|last5=Ferris-Rotman|first5=Amie|last6=Timberg|first6=Craig}}</ref> In July, A spokesperson for Nikolaev confirms the funding support after initial denials.<ref name=RussianBillionaireBackedButinaWapo20180722 /><ref name=AllegedSpyToldSenatePanelCNN20180723>{{cite news|title=Alleged spy told Senate panel about backing from Russian billionaire|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/07/22/politics/butina-konstantin-nikolaev/index.html|website=[[CNN]]|date=July 23, 2018|access-date=July 26, 2018|last1=Watkins|first1=Eli|last2=Herb|first2=Jeremy|last3=Kiley|first3=Sam|author-link3=Sam Kiley|last4=Burrows|first4=Emma}}</ref>
 {{Trump–Ukraine scandal}}
 * '''Early April''': The [[Prosecutor General of Ukraine|Ukrainian chief prosecutor]] freezes the four Paul Manafort investigations his office is conducting and stops cooperating with the Mueller investigation. The timing is considered suspicious because it follows the [[Trump administration]]'s sale of [[FGM-148 Javelin|Javelin missiles]] to Ukraine.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ukraine, Seeking U.S. Missiles, Halted Cooperation With Mueller Investigation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/02/world/europe/ukraine-mueller-manafort-missiles.html|website=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 2, 2018|access-date=June 27, 2018|last1=Kramer|first1=Andrew E.|last2=Mendel |first2=Iuliia |author-link2=Iuliia Mendel  |last3=Mazetti|first3=Mark|author-link3=Mark Mazzetti}}</ref>
 * '''April 2'''
 ** The ''Wall Street Journal'' reports that Mueller is investigating Roger Stone's claim that he met with Assange in August 2016. In an email sent to Sam Nunberg on August 4, 2016, Stone wrote "I dined with Julian Assange last night." Stone denied the meeting took place.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Holliday|first1=Shelby|last2=Barry|first2=Rob|title=Roger Stone's Claim of a 2016 Julian Assange Meeting Draws Scrutiny|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/roger-stones-claim-of-a-2016-julian-assange-meeting-draws-scrutiny-1522695471|accessdate=April 4, 2018|work=Wall Street Journal|date=April 2, 2018}}</ref>
 ** Major Dmitry Dokuchaev of the [[Federal Security Service|FSB]] pleads guilty in Russia to transferring information to a foreign intelligence service. Dokuchaev is wanted by the FBI for his involvement in the [[Yahoo! data breaches#August 2013 breach|August 2013 data breach]] of 500 million Yahoo! user accounts. It is believed he was involved in the Russian hacking of U.S. election servers in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Report: Russian cyber spy wanted by FBI admits intel sharing|url=https://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/nation-world/national/article207723644.html|website=[[McClatchyDC]]|date=April 2, 2018|access-date=June 29, 2018|last=Hall|first=Kevin G.}}</ref>
 ** Mueller's team interviews [[Annie Donaldson]] for the second and final time.{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-II|pp=81, 86–87}}
 * '''April 3''':
 ** Dutch attorney [[Alex van der Zwaan]] is sentenced to 30 days in federal prison and ordered to pay a $20,000 fine for lying to the [[FBI]] about his contacts with a former [[GRU]] officer and for withholding documents from the Mueller investigation.<ref>{{cite web|title=First sentence handed down in Mueller probe |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/first-sentence-handed-down-in-mueller-special-counsel-probe/2018/04/03/23e9b21e-3693-11e8-acd5-35eac230e514_story.html |website=[[The Washington Post]]|date=April 3, 2018|access-date=April 3, 2018|last=Hsu|first=Spencer S.}}</ref>
 ** Facebook closes the Federal Agency of News (FAN) account. The FAN is a sister organization to the IRA located in the same building in St. Petersburg.<ref name=RussianTrollsSueFacebookDailyBeast20181120>{{cite web|title=Russian Trolls Sue Facebook, Their Old Propaganda Machine|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/russian-trolls-sue-facebook-their-old-propaganda-machine|website=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=November 20, 2018|access-date=January 4, 2019|last1=Ackerman|first1=Spencer|author-link1=Spencer Ackerman|last2=Poulsen|first2=Kevin|author-link2=Kevin Poulsen}}</ref>
 ** Mueller's team interviews Priebus for the third of three times.{{r|MUELLER-REPORT-VOL-II|p=50-51, 81, 87, 93, 95-96, 99-100, 115, 123}}

edits.entity: 2020 Wisconsin Senate election
edits.diff:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -216,29 +216,30 @@
 {{notelist|group=summary}}
 
 ==Outgoing incumbents==
 ===Retiring===
 *[[Luther Olsen]] (R–[[Ripon, Wisconsin|Ripon]]), representing District 14 since 2004, announced in February 2020 that he would not seek reelection, stating "there comes a time in life when it’s time to move on."<ref>{{cite web |last1=White |first1=Laurel |title=Longtime Republican State Sen. Luther Olsen Announces Retirement |url=https://www.wpr.org/longtime-republican-state-sen-luther-olsen-announces-retirement |website=Wisconsin Public Radio |accessdate=18 September 2020 |language=en |date=24 February 2020}}</ref>
 *[[Mark F. Miller]] (D–[[Monona, Wisconsin|Monona]]), representing District 16 since 2004, announced in January 2020 that he would not be running for reelection.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Johnson |first1=Shawn |title=Democrat Mark Miller Won't Seek Re-Election To Wisconsin Senate |url=https://www.wpr.org/democrat-mark-miller-wont-seek-re-election-wisconsin-senate |website=Wisconsin Public Radio |accessdate=18 September 2020 |language=en |date=21 January 2020}}</ref>
 *[[Fred Risser]] (D–[[Madison, Wisconsin|Madison]]), representing District 26 since 1962, announced in March 2020 that he would be stepping down from the Legislature. Upon his retirement, Risser was the longest-serving lawmaker in American history, having served in the Wisconsin House of Representatives and Senate for 64 years.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Vetterkind |first1=Riley |title=Sen. Fred Risser, longest-serving lawmaker in American history, to retire |url=https://madison.com/wsj/news/local/govt-and-politics/sen-fred-risser-longest-serving-lawmaker-in-american-history-to-retire/article_f0aa4ac0-7eb7-5117-9755-76f05bbcf95b.html |website=madison.com |accessdate=18 September 2020 |language=en}}</ref>
 *[[Dave Craig]] (R–[[Vernon, Wisconsin|Vernon]]), representing District 28 since 2016, announced that he would not seek reelection to a second term in order to get "a break from public life."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Rogan |first1=Adam |title=Conservative Sen. Dave Craig, who represents Waterford area, will not seek re-election |url=https://journaltimes.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/elections/conservative-sen-dave-craig-who-represents-waterford-area-will-not-seek-re-election/article_31b982ba-754f-5864-a889-173bb16b3efc.html |website=Journal Times |accessdate=18 September 2020 |language=en}}</ref>
 *[[Dave Hansen]] (D–[[Green Bay, Wisconsin|Green Bay]]), representing District 30 since 2000, announced in January 2020 that he would be retiring to spend more time with his family.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Johnson |first1=Shawn |title=Green Bay State Sen. Dave Hansen Won't Seek Re-election |url=https://www.wpr.org/green-bay-state-sen-dave-hansen-wont-seek-re-election |website=Wisconsin Public Radio |accessdate=18 September 2020 |language=en |date=9 January 2020}}</ref>
 
 ===Vacated office before term end===
 *[[Tom Tiffany]] (R–[[Hazelhurst, Wisconsin|Hazelhurst]]), who had represented District 12 since 2014, left office on May 18, 2020, after winning the [[2020 Wisconsin's 7th congressional district special election|special election]] for [[Wisconsin's 7th congressional district]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Axelrod |first1=Tal |title=Republican Tom Tiffany wins Wisconsin special election |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/496641-republican-tom-tiffany-wins-wisconsin-special-election |website=TheHill |accessdate=18 September 2020 |language=en |date=12 May 2020}}</ref>
 *[[Jennifer Shilling]] (D–[[La Crosse, Wisconsin|La Crosse]]), who had represented District 32 since 2011 and served as Minority Leader since 2015, resigned her seat on May 15, 2020 in order to explore "unspecified career opportunities."<ref>{{cite web |title=Former Wisconsin Senate minority leader Shilling quits Legislature |url=https://www.channel3000.com/former-wisconsin-senate-minority-leader-shilling-quits-legislature/ |website=Channel3000.com |accessdate=18 September 2020 |date=15 May 2020}}</ref>
